titleStmt.title: תלמוד ירושלמי מסכת שבת פרק יב דף יג עמוד ב /מ"ג
titleStmt.author: SERG

note.p: Biblical, see e.g. Num 1:11.

body.p:
1. O: abidwn
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . In Hebrew it would read אבידון. On the additional ו in the suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13. Ds: High priest
In Coptic – paryhereus. On this title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 29b II E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: אבודן
On the interchange of the letters י and ו see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.1, p. 13. Ds: Aaron (3)’s father?
See next note. F: Epitaph, Jerusalem, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 1389 E: Family?
Aaron is described as דמן אבודן (of Abudan) but no such place is recorded. Thus it may be a family name, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 46. D: 3rd-7th C
Suggested by CIIP 1/2 no. 881.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 14:1. אביה was the name of an Israelite prince. It is also the name of a biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:10.

body.p:
1. O: ابيه
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read אביה. Ds: Sectarian
On the Samaritan sects see Introduction 3.3.3. According to Abu’l Fath, the sect of this Abiah and Dositheus (1) is to be understood separately from the great Samaritan Dosithean heresy. F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 173 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 4th-7th C
On Abu’l Fath’s dating of Samaritan sects, see Introduction 7.2.2.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 22:20. אביתר was a priest under King David.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 9:1 13a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 53) E: – D: 3rd-4th C CE
Was a student of Rabbi Jonathan (1), who was also a teacher of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

2. O: <>
On the form see vol. 3, under Ebiathar (1) B/M, p. 1. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.6, p. 21. The fall of the  is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 30 E: –
Jewishness indicated both by his name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 60-1, and perhaps also because it is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, 35. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:5. אברהם is the name of the famous biblical patriarch, forefather of the Jewish people.

body.p:
1. O: 
On this form see vol. 3, Abraham (13) B/M, p. 72. Ds: Christian monk
The story of this person’s conversion to Judaism begins with the words:     (there was a certain exemplary monk). If this is the name he adopted after he converted, this is the first instance of the name Abraham serving for converts. Later on it became the standard name for male proselytes, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. F: – S: Antiochus Monachus, PG 89, 1692 E: Proselyte
See previous note and vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.3, p. 50. D: 6th-7th C
See H. Sivan, Palestine in Late Antiquity (Oxford 2008) 51.

2. O: 
For this form see under Abraham (9) B/M, vol. 3, p. 73, n. 23. Ds: Justus (2)’s brother F: – S: Doctrina Jacobi 3:2 E: – D: 7th C
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).

3. O: – Ds: Or (1)’s son, Shemta‘ima
שמטעימה, which is probably a nickname. leader
Appears in a list of leaders who were accorded territory by the Samaritan leader Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 130 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.

4. O: – Ds: Lollianus (6)’s son F: Inscription, Golden Gate, Jerusalem, Macalister S: CIJ 1397 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late, but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See Introduction 7.6.6 and previous note.

5. O: Abraha
For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Abraham, in which the Hebrew suffix fell because it was interpreted as belonging to a misunderstood case system, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12. Ds: The Syrian?
In Latin – Sir[..], see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Celeia,
Near Venice , in Italy. Diehl S: CIJ 91* E: Christian?
The name and provenance made editors consider it Jewish, but the name was also common among Syrian Christians, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

6. O: 
See above, n. 14. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1053 S: BS 2:42 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

7. O: 
In vol. 3 both the form  (see under Abraham [2] B/M, p. 72) and (see under Abraham [9] B/M, p. 72) are recorded. This is a combination of the two. Ds: Marmarius (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Tiberias S: Roth-Gerson, GISEI, no. 14 E: – D: 4th-7th C

8. O: 
See above, n. 14. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Hebron?
The inscription comes from the antiquities market. The man who traded this inscription claimed that it comes from a place associated with Abraham. Mordtmann understood this to refer to Hebron. S: Mordtmann, ZDPV 12 (1889) 132 E: Jew?
This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but is could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:3. אבשלום was David’s rebellious son.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Sipora (1)’s father F: – S: yGit 5:3 46d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 55) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His daughter is mentioned in association with Eleazar (8), see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: אבטולמוס
So in the printed version to bBB 68a, This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (3) G/M, p. 279. Perhaps this was his name, and אבשלום is a scribal “correction” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18./אבטלמס
So in the Vatican 115 Ms to bBB 68a, see previous note. On the form אבטולמוס see previous note. On the fall of the וs see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.4, p. 13./אבטלוס
So in the Florence II-I-9 Ms to bBB 68a, see above, n. 3. For this form see vol. 1, under Eutolmus (2) G/M, p. 279./אבישלום
So in the printed versions of bBer 7b, see above, n. 3. For this form see vol. 1, under Abshalom (6) B/M, p. 60. Ds: Simon (31)’s father F: – S: bBer 7b
Although mentioned only in BT, his son is designated רבי in all the traditions in which he is mentioned (bBer 7a; bMeg 14a and bBB 68a), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2 and transmits traditions in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1686) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: אבשלם
In Thamoudian script, see Introduction 2.5.3. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13. Ds: Burqai (2)’s father F: Epitaph, Samakiya
A village in Transjordan, near Karak. S: Milik, LA 9 (1958-9) 343 E: Jew?
Jewishness sugested based on name, see vol. 3, Intruduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However the region is not particularly Jewish and the inscription is in the Thamoudean script, see Intruduction 2.2.1.6. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

4. O: 
Althouth this form is not recorded elsewhere, it seems like a standard transliteration of this name into Greek. In vol. 1, under Abshalom (3) the form indicates the use of the letter  for this transliteration and the form  for שלום is found in the standard transliteration of the name שלמציון into Greek (e.g. in vol. 1, under Shalmzion [16] S-H/F, p. 427). The suffix is standard Greek, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.1, p. 18. Ds: Zedoqomo (1)’s son, architect
In Greek – . Because the inscription was found in the theatre of Beth She’an he may be the architect of the theatre. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Inscription, Beth She’an S: Applebaum, Isaac & Landau, SCI 4 (1978) 139 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 51. The region was not particularly Jewish in character, see Introduction 6.2.1.4. D: 2nd-3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 4:14. אהרון was the name of Moses’ brother, the first priest.

body.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Zohar (1)’s son, priest
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such titles see Introduction 3.3.2. F: – S: Tulida, 132 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the date of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He is his contemporary.

2. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Zebadi (1)’s son, priest
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 134 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 5

3. O: – Ds: Joseph (81)’s father F: Epitaph, Jerusalem, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 1389 E: – D: 3rd-7th C
Suggested by CIIP 1/2, no. 881.

4. O: 
On this form see vol. 3, Aaron (2) B/M, p. 75. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Hebron?
The inscription comes from the antiquities market. The man who produced this inscription claimed that it comes from a place associated with Abraham. Mordtmann understood this to refer to Hebron. S: Mordtmann, ZDPV 12 (1889) 132 E: Jew?
This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but is could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

5. O: עארון
The replacement of א with ע and of ה with א indicate the decline of the laryngeals, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.1, pp. 28-9 and vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.1, pp. 10. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Misgav & Stern, Tarbiz 74 (2005) no. 29 E: – D: 579
The inscription is dated to 509 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

אחי
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. The word אחא means brother in Aramaic. – Ahi

1. O: אחא
For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 61. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 70-5) E: – D: 3rd C
Was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: אהבה
So in BT. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56./אחוא
So in yErub 6:7, 23d, and see previous note. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56./אחייא
So in yBer 1:6, 3d, see above, n. 4. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. This is probably a variation of the biblical name אחיה, see below. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. Ds: Ze‘ira (4)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:6, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi,75) E: – D: 3rd C
Was associated with Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a student and contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Abba (9)’s father F: – S: yBer 3:4, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 11) E: – D: 3rd C
His son always cites Rabbi Judah the Patriarch (in vol. 1, Judah [36] B/M, p. 113), indicating that he came after him see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.

4. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Jacob (10)’s father F: – S: yBer 2:3, 4c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76-81) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s student, see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Hananiah (7)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:4, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

6. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Isaac (7)’s son F: – S: yBer 4:3, 8a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Isaac (5)’s father F: – S: yPea 5:1, 18d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.1, pp. 40-1 and Introduction 7.4.5.

8. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Pappus (4)’s son F: – S: yMSh 5:7, 56c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of the students of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Huna (4)’s father F: – S: yMSh 5:8, 56c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary Alexander (1) G/M, who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s students, see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: אחווא
So e.g. in yBer 5:1, 8d. For this form see vol. 4, under Ahi (1) B/M, p. 56. Ds: Ze‘ira (6)’s son F: – S: yShab 6:9, 8d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 75-6) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Rav’s son
This is his only appearance in rabbinic literature. He is the son of Abba (70) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311, but he was probably Palestinian, as his title רבי suggests. It is well known that his father spent many years in Palestine. He is not to be identified with Ahi (23) son of Abba (60) B/M (see vol. 4, p. 56), F: – S: yShab 7:2, 9d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Joseph (26)’s father F: – S: yEruv 5:1, 22b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]) see Introduction 7.4.3.

13. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Simon (22)’s son F: – S: yMeg 1:9, 71c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits a tradition in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

14. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Ḥiyya (18)’s father F: – S: yKet 4:10, 29a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits a tradition in the name of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

15. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Governor of the castle
In Hebrew – שר הבירה. On a possible interpretation of this name see Introduction 3.1.3.3.1. F: – S: bKet 88a
Although he appears only in BT he bears the title רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2) and is always mentioned in association with a place in Palestine (Usha – bKet 22a; bBB 146a) or Syria (Antioch – bYev 45a; bKet 88a; bArakh 22b). (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 132) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: אחא
See above, n. 2./אחיו
So in the Munich 95 Ms. On such a suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1. It could, however, be referring to the word “his brother” rather than to a name, see above, n. 1. Ds: Hidya (1)’s son F: – S: bGit 35a
Although he shows up only in BT, he is said to appear on a divorce bill from “there” (התם), which in BT always means Palestine. He is mistakenly listed in vol. 4, under Ahi (22) B/M, p. 56. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 136) E: – D: D: Pre-427
Mentioned in a divorce bill discussed by Rav Ashi (2), who died in this year, according to ShGa § 186, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.1, pp. 40-1.

17. O: אחאי
So only in the Vilna print. Elsewhere in the mss אחי. For this form see vol. 1, under Ahi (2) B/M, p. 61. Ds: Berrabbi
In Aramaic – בריבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: – S: bBekh 24b
Although mentioned only in BT, here, he is mentioned as a precedent in a tradition transmitted by Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 148) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

18. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Aiala (2)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 94:2 (Hyman. Toldoth, 124
In Hyman, Toldoth, 124, under this name, the author refers the reader to a person named אבא בר עולא. But no such person is discussed in the book. He mentions him under אבא בר עילאי (pp. 53-4).) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

19. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Hananiah (40)’s father F: – S: Lev Rab 3:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 478) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [29]) who was a companion of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

20. O: אחא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Sheila (5)’s son,
Probably also mentioned in Gen Rab 94:2, where he is recorded as בר אילא (in the London MS) and בר עולה (in the Vatican MS 30) but also as בר שילא (in the Munich 97 MS).of Kfar Tamarta
In Hebrew – איש כפר תמרתה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 375-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Est Rab 6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 132) E: – D: 3rd C-4th C
His father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 11:29. אחיה was a prophet.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:13 E: - D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 17:1. אליהו was the name of a prophet.

body.p:
1. O: 
For the form see vol. 3, under Elijah (1) B/M, p. 76. Ds: “Father”
In Greek – . On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2, p. 40. F: Dedicatory inscription, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 58 E: Jew?
This person has a biblical name but he could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Di Segni, Dated Greek Inscriptions from Palestine from the Roman and Byzantine Periods (PhD Thesis, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 1997) 458-60 claims that the building referred to in the inscription is civil and not religious and has pagan overtones. The title “beyond reasonable doubt … was a municiple functionary who had nothing to do with with the ecclesiastical hierarchy.” Despite the date – 1st indiction – the inscription cannot be dated. It could be early, before Christianity got a firm grip on Caesarea and the man, if not Christian, could be Jewish. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

2. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Elijah (3) B/M, p. 76. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 167 E: –
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35. D: 4th-7th C

3. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 169 E: –
See above, n. 7.. D: 4th-7th C

4. O: 
See above, n. 8. This is probably this form without the Greek suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. Ds: – F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 10 E: Jew?
In this inscription he is described as one of the friends ([]) of those who inscribed the text (identified by Di Segni as Armenian). Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 5th-6th C

5. O: 
See above, n. 8. Ds: Marble worker
In Greek – [](). On such title see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 23 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 5th-6th C

6. O: 
See above, n. 8. Ds: Mariam (12)’s husband F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 38 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested by Di Segni, based on name, and other possible features, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 5th-6th C

7. O: 
See below, n. 27. Ds: Official
In Greek –  (stewardship of Elius Magistrate – Offord’s translation). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.4. F: Boundary stone, Abel Beit Ma‘akha
In north Israel, on the source of the Jordan river. S: Offord, PEFQS 40 (1908) 260 E: Jew?
The inscription is dated to the time of Diocletian. A person named Elijah under his anti-Christian rule would have been Jewish, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However, this was the name of an administrative official, and it may not have been a rendition of Elijah, but rather of a Greek name, see e.g. WGE. 348-9. D: 293-305
The stone refers to the Diocletian at the time he assumed with Maximinus the title Augustus. These are the dates when this title would have been relevant, see Introduction 7.1.

8. O:[]
This form (with a spiritus asper) is recorded as the name of the sun-god in Greece, see WGE, 456-7, but in the Elijah’s Cave a recurrance of forms of this rare name is suggestive. It may be a variation on the name of the hero of the cave, see Appendix 4.3.3.1. Ds: His house?
In Hebrew, in Greek letters –  (בית). On this see Appendix 4.3.3.1.2. F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 8 E: Jew?
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7. Name?
See above, n. 23, and vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 46. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

9. O: 
This form is recorded as a mythical name of the founder of Helas, see WGE, 349, but in the Elijah’s Cave a recurance of forms of this rare name is suggestive. It may be a variation on the name of the hero of the cave, see Appendix 4.3.3.1. Ds: Cyrillus (5)’s father, the greatest, decurion of the colony Ptolemais
In Greek – [], []() (). On the titles see Introduction 3.1.3.1 and 3.1.3.4. On the regional designataion see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. And see also Appendix 4.3.3.1.1. F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 17 E: Jew?
See above, n. 24. D: Pre-8th C
See above, n. 26.

10. O: 
See above, n. 27. Ds: Julius (12) F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 27 E: Jew?
See above, n. 24. D: Pre-8th C
See above, n. 26.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:4.

body.p:
1. O: –
So in the printed edition, in Vatican 60 Ms and in other mss. In the Theodor-Albeck edition אליהו עינני, but this makes no sense. Ds: – F: – S: Gen Rab 51:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 150) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Samuel (3) transmits a tradition in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:20. אליקים was a king of Judah.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Joseph (52)’s father F: – S: bBer 9b
Although mentioned only in BT and only here, he is described as transmitting a tradition in the name of the Holy Community in Jerusalem (קהילא קדישא דבירושלם), see S. Safrai “The Holy Congregation in Jerusalem,” Scripta Hierosolymitana 23 (1972) 62-78, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 830) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits a tradition in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:12.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Isaac (11)’s father F: – S: yBer 7:1, 11a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 110) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: אלישע
So in the printed version, but in the mss אלישיב. This form is probably a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Abba (48)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 80:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 42) E: – D: 3rd C
His son comments on the words of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. אלישע was a prophet, and Elijah’s disciple.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 19 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is not possible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60. However, see also previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

body.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Priest (XXI)
On this list see Introduction 3.3.2.1. F: – S: Tulida, 119 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: Post-200
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

2. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Pelaḥ (1)’s son, priest
In Hebrew – כהן. On such designations see Introduction 3.3.2. F: – S: Tulida, 128 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.

3. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Mariam (1)’s father, priest (XXVII)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 142 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 4th C
See above, n. 5.

4. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXIX)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 144 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 5th C
See above, n. 5.

5. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXXI)
See above, n. 3. F: - S: Tulida, 146 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 5th C
See above, n. 5.

6. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXXIII)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 148 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: Pre-632
Described as officiating in the days when Muhammad came to power, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.3.2, p. 42.

7. O: – Ds: Menahem (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 128) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 112-26) E: – D: 4th C
Was associated with the general Ursicinus, who was active in Palestine in the year 351-2 (yBes 1:7, 60c), see Introduction 7.4.3.

9. O: – Ds: Abbin (2)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 51) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Judah (8), who was a student of Samuel (3), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

10. O: – Ds: Isaac (4)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 131-2) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: – Ds: Antigonus (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:6, 5b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 127) E: – D: 3rd C
His son cites traditions of the tanna, Eleazar (Eleazar [58] B/M in vol. 1, p. 66), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: – Ds: Hoshaiah (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 5:2, 9b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 69) E: Fictitious?
This person is only mentioned once (here) in the form ר' אלעזר ב"ר הושעיה. Elsewhere in PT we find the formula ר' אלעזר בשם ר' הושעיה (Rabbi Eleazar in the name of Rabbi Hoshaiah). Also Hyman does not record him. Yet in all the mss (Leiden, Vatican Paris, London) and in the Venice print here the first form is recorded. Only in the margins of the Leiden Ms is the text emended. I think this form is the lectio difficilior, but doubt lingers. D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

13. O: לעזר
For this form see vol. 1, Eleazar (82) B/M, p. 67. Ds: Of Darom
In Aramaic – דרומייה in yPeah 8:2, 20d and דרומיא in yYom 6:6, 44a and yMeg 1:8, 71b, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 212-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. In yGit 6:7, 48b he is designated דמן רומא, which may imply that his provenance is the city of Rome, but this is doubtful. Although Hyman, Toldoth, 214 makes a distinction between the two, because he thinks they date from different times, but I think the same sage is intended, and the mistake is in the transmission tradition. F: – S: yPea 8:2, 20d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 126) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]). See Introduction 7.4.3.

14. O: לעזר
See above, n. 33. Ds: Hananiah (23)’s son
Could be identified with Eleazar (61) B/M, in vol. 1, p. 66, but since both are so rare, and the names so common, this is unlikely. F: – S: yShab 3:7, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 127) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

15. O: – Ds: Jeremiah (8)’s father F: – S: yShab 6:9, 8d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 132) E: – D: Pre-400
See previous note.

16. O: לעזר
See above, n. 33. Ds: Hagai (3)’s son F: – S: ySheq 7:2, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 127) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

17. O: לעזר
See above, n. 33. Ds: Marom (1)’s son F: – S: yTaan 4:3, 68b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 128) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

18. O: אילעאי
For the form אלעי see vol. 1, Eleazar (32) B/M, p. 66. On the additional י and א vowels see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, and 2.5.3.1, p. 12. Ds: Joseph (36)’s father F: – S: yMeg 1:12, 72c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 91) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

19. O: – Ds: Tiridates (1)’s son F: – S: yGit 7:4, 48d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 131) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 38.

20. O: ליעזר
For the name אליעזר see vol. 1, under Eleazar (3) B/M, p. 65. On the fall of the initial א as a Palestinian-Aramaic linguistic phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29. Ds: Ishmael (7)’s son F: – S: yNaz 6:2 55a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 109) E: Fictitious?
Hyman, Toldoth, 185, claims there is no such person, because in his appearance in yTer 11:2, 47d, the text which runs: לעזר ביה ר' ישמעאל should be read לעזר בשם ר' ישמעאל. However, he does not refer to the text here, which runs רבי ליעזר בן ישמעאל. This notwithstanding, because both texts refer beforehand to the tanna Rabbi Yishmael (Ishmael [4] B/M. in vol. 1, p. 177), he may be correct, and no such person exists. D: Pre-400
See above, n. 38.

21. O: לעזר
See above, n. 33. Ds: Abbin (20)’s father F: – S: ySan 2:4, 20b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 40) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 38.

22. O: לעזר
See above, n. 33. Ds: Isaac (24)’s father F: – S: yBB 8:1, 15a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 40) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

23. O: – Ds: Milai (2)’s son F: – S: bShab 139a
Although mentioned only in BT, he is always designated by the Palestinian title רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 212) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

24. O: אילא
So in the Jerusalem Yad Harav Herzog 1 and the Munich 95 Mss to bTaan 10b. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this name, see vol. 1, Aila S-H/M, p. 361. This is probably a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18./אלעא
So in the Oxford Opp. Add. Fol. 23 Ms. to bTaan 10b and in the Jerusalem – Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms to bSot 49a, see previous note. On this form see vol. 4, Eleazar (6) B/M, p. 61./אלעאי
So in the Munich 140 Ms to bTaan 10b and in the Oxford – Bodl. Heb. d. 20 to bSot 49a, see above, n. 56. For this form see above, n. 44./עולא
So in the Spanish print to bTaan 10b, see above, n. 56. On this name see vol. 4 under Ulla S-H/M, pp. 389-90. This is probably a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Barachiah (2)’s son F: – S: bTaan 10b
Although he appears only in BT (here and in bSot 49 and in bSan 94b), he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, pp. 39-40, and transmits haggadic traditions, in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5-6. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 169) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

25. O: – Ds: Pedat (2)’s son F: - S: bTaan 25a
An amora by the name of ר' אלעזר (Eleazar [8]) is mentioned often in PT (e.g. yBer 2:1, 4b) but never as the son of a פדת. Thus he appears only in BT, and I assume he is a different person. Hyman, Toldoth, 192, claims that Eleazar ben Pedat was Babylonian, but does not bring clear cut evidence for this. That he was the father of Pedat (1) S-H/M, mentioned often in PT, is shown in yMeg 4:10, 75c. Thus I assume he is Palestinian. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 215-35) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

26. O: – Ds: Benjamin (10)’s son F: – S: bHul 19b
Although he appears only here in BT, he is consistently designated by the title רבי and transmits a tradition in Hebrew, see above, n. 60. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 212) E: –D: Pre-320
Naḥmani (1) B/M in vol. 4, p. 112 transmits in his name. This is the date of his death, see introduction 7.4.5.

27. O: לעיי
For the name אלעי see above, n. 44. On the fall of the initial א as a Palestinian-Aramaic linguistic phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Joseph (55)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 6:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 719
Hyman, ibid., and 753 identifies him with a יוסף בן עילאי mentioned in bSuk 26a, as a Babylonian, but a Babylonian provenance in Gen Rab is unlikely.) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

28. O: – Ds: Karsana (3)’s son F: - S: Gen Rab 18:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 160) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Aha (Ahi [1]), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

29. O: – Ds: Jonathan (18)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 95:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 701) E: – D: 3rd C
Samuel (3) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

30. O: – Ds: Of Bostra
In Aramaic – בצראה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1. F: – S: Lam Rab 4:23
Only in the Vilna edition. In the Buber edition this part of the midrash is missing. (Hyman, Toldoth, 159) E: – D: – 3rd C
See above, n. 69.

31. O: – Ds: Kalir, poet
In this composition Se‘adya Gaon explains the work of poets (אלשערא in Judeo-Arabic), and lists this one among them. And see Introduction 3.1.3.6. F: – S: Saadia Gaon, Ha’egron 155 E: – D: 4th-7th C
Zulay, Eretz Israel, 165, dates him to the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.5.5.

32. O: – Ds: Phineas (13)’s son, poet
Known to us through his “signature” (achrosticon) in his liturgical poems (piyutim), see Introduction 3.1.3.6. F: – S: Zulay, Eretz Israel, 164 E: – D: 4th-7th C
See above, n. 75.
33. O: – Ds: Joshua (22)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 897 E: – D: 3rd C

34. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, Eleazar (14) B/M, p. 65. Ds: Ḥiyya (29)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 899 E: – D: 3rd C

35. O: 
See above, n. 78. Ds: Simon (47)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 935 E: – D: 3rd C

36. O: 
See above, n.78. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea, Germer-Durand S: CIJ 938 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on names mentioned in the inscription but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see introduction 6.2.1.2. D: 3rd C

37. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. See above, n. 78. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Gaza, Germer-Durand S: CIJ 966 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

38. O: – Ds: Judah (68)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Bar‘am,
Village located north west of Safed, near the border to Lebanon. Renan S: CIJ 975 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

39. O: – Ds: Peraḥiah (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rama,
Located west of Safed, also known as Er-Ram. Ben Zvi S: CIJ 979 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

40. O: – Ds: Judah (73)’s father F: Sarcophagus, Gofna,
Now Jifna, north of Ramallah. Legrange S: CIJ 1171 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

41. O: 
For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Eleazar, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12. This is of course an abbreviation of the already corrupted form Lazarus, see above, n. 78. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1116 S: BS 2:93 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

42. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, Eleazar (174) B/M, p. 70. Ds: Joseph (93)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 15 S: BS 2:177 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 91.

43. O: אליעזר
For this form see vol. 1, Eleazar (30) B/M, p. 66. Ds: Gamaliel (10)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:26 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 91.

44. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Dabbûra,
In the Golan. Urman S: Naveh, OSM, no. 7 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

45. O: ליזר
For the name אליעזר see vol. 1, under Eleazar (3) B/M, p. 65. On the fall of the initial א as a Palestinian-Aramaic linguistic phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29. The fall of the ע may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20, or it may be an indication of the decline of the laryngals, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.1, p. 29. Ds: Hananiah (51)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Kfar Nevoraya,
In Upper Galilee. Renan S: Naveh, OSM, no. 13 E: – D: 564
The inscription is dated to the year 494 to the Destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

46. O: לעזר
See above, n. 52. Ds: Priest
In Aramaic –כהנא . On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: Synagogue inscription, Eshtamo‘a,
Now As-Samua in Judea, in southern Mount Hebron. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 74 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

47. O: לעזר
See above, n. 52. Ds: Simon (61)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Susya,
In southern Mount Hebron. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 81 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

48. O: לעזר
See above, n. 52. Ds: Simon (61)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Susya,
See above, n. 106. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 81 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

49. O: לעזר
See above, n. 52. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Susya,
See above, n. 106. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 85 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

50. O: []
See above, n. 82. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 188 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on names mentioned in the inscription but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2. D: –
See above, n. 83.

51. O: []
See above, n. 82. Ds: Anastasie (2)’s husband F: Dedicatory inscription, Coastal Plain
The exact location of this inscription is unknown. The editor claimed it was found somewhere between Jaffa and Gaza. S: Germer-Durand, RB 1 (1892) 248 E: Jew?
See above, n. 115. This a dedication of a  (Holy Place) which could be a church, but could also be a synagogue, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.4, p. 42. D: –
See above, n. 83.

52. O: אליעזר
See above, n. 94. Ds: Theodorus (14)’s son F: Dedicatory inscription, Er-Rāma
West of Safed, also known as Er-Ram. S: Ben Zvi, JPOS 13 (1933) 95 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

53. O: אלעז[ר]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Jacob (67)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Ben Zvi, BIES 10 (1943) 36 E: – D: 505
The inscription is dated to 435 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

54. O: 
The inscription is bilingual. So in Greek. The Hebrew has אלעזר. For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Eleazar, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12. This is of course an abbreviation of the already corrupted form Lazarus, see above, n. 92. New reading in CIIP IV/2 3850  Ds: Abba (59)’s son F: Epitaph, Lahav
Kibbutz in the north-eastern Negev. S: Meehan, ZDPV 96 (1980) 59 E: –
Jewishness indicated by the Aramaic part off the inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4. D: –
See above, n. 83.

55. O: לע[זר]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 52. Ds: Judah (110)’s father F: Inscription, Dabbûra
See above, n. 96. S: Urman, Tarbiz 65 (1996) 517 E: – D: –
See above, n. 83.

56. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, Eleazar (2) B/M, p. 65. Ds: Joseph (123)’s father, Sheila (11)’s son, of Horsha
In Greek – . The place is attested in Josephus and Ptolemaius, see Damati, ibid. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Damati, Atiqot 38 (1999) 91* E: Jew?
See above, n. 115. D: –
See above, n. 83.

57. O: [אלע]זר
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

58. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
See above, n. 138. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
See above, n. 139. E: – D: 4th-7th C

59. O: אלעי
See above, n. 44. Ds: Joseph (127)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
See above, n. 138. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
See above, n. 139. E: – D: 4th-7th C

60. O: לעזר
See above, n. 52. Ds: Sakhari (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
See above, n. 138. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
See above, n. 139. E: – D: 4th-7th C

61. O: – Ds: Esther (13)’s son, rabbi
In Aramaic – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Amulet, Horvat Kanaf
In the Golan, north east of the Sea of Galilee. S: AMB no. 3 E: – D: 350-500

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1Sam 1:1. אלקנה was the name of the prophet Samuel’s father.

body.p:
1. O: 
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 58. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Jaffa, Jaussen S: CIJ 913 E: – D: 3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:41.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Barachiah (7)’s son, the physician,
In Hebrew – הרופא. On this Jewish medical literature see Introduction 5.1.4.2. of Jericho
In Hebrew – הירחוני, according to Muntner, Assaph, 156. F: – S: Pines, PIASH 5 (1971-6) 258 E: Fictitious?
On the question of his historicity see Pines, ibid. D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, 33-7.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 48:5. אפרים was Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: The scribe?
In bBM 119a he is designated אפרים ספרא. For this title see Introduction 3.2.1.4. F: – S: yBM 10:8, 12d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 138) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: אבירים/אבירם
Both forms, as well as Epraim, are found in ms versions of Est Rab, see http://www.schechter.ac.il/pdf/ה.pdf. The name is unstable because the person was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. אבירם is also a biblical name, see Num 16:1. /בודי/בירי/ברי
All three forms are found in ms versions of Midrash Shmuel 13:6, which is the only other source in which he is mentioned, see previous note. Ds: Joshua (19)’s father F: – S: Est Rab 5:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 620-1) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: 
For this form as being an abbreviation of the biblical name Ephraim, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.3, pp. 19-20. Ds: Severianus (1)’s father, of Tyre
In Greek –  (in Lebanon). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Synagogue inscription, Sepphoris, Ewing S: CIJ 991 E: –D: 4th-5th C

4. O: אפר
On this sort of kern form see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She’an S: Naveh, OSM, p. 76 E: Samaritan
The inscription is in Greek, in Samaritan script, see Introduction 6.1.3. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:13. אשר was one of the twelve sons of Jacob.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Levi (33)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Naveh
In the Bashan (Transjordan south of the Golan). (Samuel Bar Simson 1210) S: Naveh, OSM, no. 36 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

2. O: אשור
On the additional ו as representing a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 19 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is not possible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60. However, see previous note.

3. O: –
The inscription is in Greek, but the report is in Hebrew. Ds: – F: Chancel screen inscription, synagogue, Gaza S: Ovadiah, AN 24 (1968) 11 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:11. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 111.

body.p:
1. O: בבא
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On this form see vol. 1, Babi (3) B/M, p. 80. Ds: The Great
In Aramaic – רבא. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 122 E: Samaritan
He is the great leader of the Samaritans, see Introduction 7.2.3.. D: 3rd-4th C
These are his dates according to Cowley, The Samaritan Liturgy, xxi, and see also Introduction 7.2.3.

2. O: ביבא
So e.g. in Gen Rab 20:16. On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:4, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 147) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: ביבין
On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, pp. 13. On the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. Ds: Joseph (30)’s father F: – S: ySheq 3:2, 47b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 147) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Samuel (15), who was contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: ביבי
On this form see vol. 4, Bebai (1) B/M, p. 63. Ds: Gozlon (1)’s son F: – S: yBM 2:5, 8c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 147) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S/H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), see Introduction 7.4.5.

5. O: ביבי
See above, n. 4. Ds: Ami (1)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 26:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 266) E: – D: 3rd C
He is Rabbi Ami (1)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: ביבא
All versions found in mss to Lev Rab 4:3, see Margulies, Wayyikra Rabbah, 84. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. and see above, n. 6./ביבי
So in most mss to Lev Rab 3:3, 4:3 and 29:9, and see previous note. Another mss to 29:9 has בבי, see Margulies, Wayyikra Rabbah, 682. For this form see above, n. 4./פפא/רבינא
Both versions are found in mss to Lev Rab 4:3, see Margulies, Wayyikra Rabbah, 84, and see above, n. 14. The forms רבינא and פפא are scribal “corrections,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. For the form רבינא see vol. 4, under Abbin (5) S-H/M, p. 322. For the form פפא see vol. 4, under PÁpÁ/PÁpai I/M, p. 322. Ds: Abba (49)’s son
Hyman, Toldoth, 264 and 266 differentiates this ביבי בר אבינא and ביבי בר אבא but the mss tradition in Lev Rab 3:3 makes it clear that they are the same, see Margulies, Wiyyikra Rabbah, 61. Perhaps also mentioned in yTaan 2:4, 65d, as ביבי אבא. F: – S: Lev Rab 29:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 264) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: 
On the  prefix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, p. 18. The form  is recorded in vol. 1, under Babi (1) B.M, p. 80. On the alternative suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.4, p. 24. Ds: Simon (48)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 943 E: Family?
Nahum (8) son of Simon (48) is described as  which could be translated as “of the Barbabis.” This may have been a family name, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 49. D: 3rd C

8. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, Babi (1) B/M, p. 80. Ds: Maximus
Perhaps to be identified with Bebai (1). (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Apollonia
Ancient site and fortress 15 kilometres north of Tel Aviv. S: Germer-Durand, RB 1 (1892) 247 E: Samaritan?
The inscription includes the formula  (the one God who lives). This formula is often associated with Samaritans in Palestine, but see Introduction 6.1.6. D: –
See above, n. 25.

9. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, Babi (1) B/M, p. 80. On the interchange of  with  as a scribal error, or as reflection of another dialect see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7, pp. 17-8. Ds: – F: Dedicatory inscription, theatre seat, Sichem-Nablus S: FitzGerald, PEFQS 61 (1929) 107 E: Samaritan?
On these seats see Introduction 6.1.5.2. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

10. O: באבה
On the additional א as representing a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3, pp. 13. On the interchange of the י and ה suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 11, and vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25. Ds: Esther (12)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 11 E: – D: 468
The inscription is dated to the year 398 to the Destruction of the Temple, see Introdution 7.5.2.1.

11. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, Babi (1) B/M, p. 80. For the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3, p. 27. Ds: Isaac (66)’s nephew
In Greek – . F: Epitaph, Jaffa S: Price, SCI 22 (2003) 218 E: – D: 3rd C?
The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, see Introduction 5.2.2.1, it is correct for this one as well.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 11:22. בניה is one of King David’s generals.

body.p:
1. O: בנייה
On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: – F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 152) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: בוני
For this form see vol. 1, under Benaiah (6) B/M, p. 81. Ds: Judah (24)’s father F: – S: yBM 7:1, 11b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 51) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1). See Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Priest?
Perhaps – הכ[הן]. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: Graffito, Golden Gate, Jerusalem S: Gera, Cathedra 61 (1992) 180 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

4. O: 
The reading is the editor’s. The interpretation is mine. For abbreviations of biblical names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12. Ds: Jacob (63)’s father F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 190 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on names mentioned in the inscription, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The location was not particularly inhabited by Jews, see Introduction 6.2.1.2. D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel.

body.p:
1. O: 
On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 82. Ds: Of Tiberias
Described in the text –  (in Tiberias). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Theophanes, PG 108, 676 E: Christian convert
First he is described as of the  (the Christians). Then we are informed that  (for he had been Jewish). D: 628
Served as host to the Emperor Heraclius when he came to Palestine in this year, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: بنيمين
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would be בנימין. Ds: Leader of the Jews
In Arabic – رايس اليهود. F: – S: Esbroeck, AB 104 (1986) 156 E: Fictitious
This is a pseudepigraphic letter. All mentioned in it are fictitious. D: 452
This fictitious letter (see previous note) is dated.

3. O: Iamein
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 30. In Greek this would be , implying the Hebrew ימין. On this sort of kern form see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Ds: High priest
In Coptic – paryhereus. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 29b II E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

4. O: – Ds: Japhet (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 6:1, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: בנימן
On this form see vol. 4, Benjamin (1) B/M, p. 65. Ds: Levi (9)’s son F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: בנימן
See above, n. 14. Ds: Abba (22)’s father F: – S: yShevi 6:3, 36d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 11) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: בנימן
See above, n. 14. Ds: Ashtor (2)’s son F: – S: yBik 1:4, 64a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

8. O: בנימן
So also in PT, e.g. yTer 9:1, 46c. For this form see above, n. 14. Ds: Gidol (2)’s son F: – S: 1. yYev 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153); 2. bHul 125a (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 324) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: בנימן
So also in PT, e.g. yPes 8:8, 36b. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see above, n. 14. /מיניימין
So also in PT, e.g. in ySot 6:4, 21a, see previous note. On this form see vol. 1, under Benjamin (4) B/M, p. 82. On the additional יs see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13./מניומי
So in BT, see above, n. 22. For this form see below, n. 27. Ds: Gidol (3)’s father
Not the same as the previous, see Hyman, Toldoth, 282, 303. F: – S: 1. yYev 15:6, 15b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153); 2. bPes 107a (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 324) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rav (in vol. 4, Abba [70] S-H/M, p. 311], who died in 247. On such dating see Introduction 7.4.5.

10. O: מניומי
In vol. 4 I identified this form as a separate name (see under S-H/M, pp. 376-7), but because it is found only in BT (including this one), and because in Palestinian sources מנימין is often found as an alternative form to בנימין (see vol. 1, Benjamin [4], p. 82; vol. 3, Benjamin [1], p. 80; vol. 4, Benjamin [3, 4, 5], p, 65) and because in BT it is once found as an alternative reading to the name Benjamin (see vol. 4, under Benjamin [5] B/M, p. 65), I here assume that it is actually a variant of the same name. Ds: Eleazar (26)’s father F: – S: bHul 19b
Although he appears only here in BT, his son is consistently designated by the title רבי, see vol. 4, Introduction 7.1, pp. 39-40, and transmits a tradition in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 212) E: – D: Pre-320
Naḥmani (1) B/M in vol. 4, p. 112 transmits in his son’s name. This is the date of his death.

11. O: – Ds: Abbin (26)’s father F: – S: Lev Rab 10:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, 93) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Aha (Ahi [1]), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Leah (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Caesarea, Sukenik S: CIJ 888 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

13. O: 
So is this name transliterated in Josephus, see Schalit, NB, 26. Ds: Joseph (74)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Vincent S: CIJ 908 E: – D: 3rd C

14. O: 
On this form see vol 1, Benjamin (1), p. 82. The double  is a standard Greek spelling variation, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.3, p. 11. Ds: Isaac (43)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 912 E: – D: 3rd C

15. O: 
This is probably a Greek transliteration of the Hebrew form מניומי, see above, n. 27. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Sukenik S: CIJ 942 E: – D: 3rd C

16. O: בינימין
On the additional י as representing a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. Ds: Joseph (80)’s son, administrator
In Aramaic – פרנסה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.1. F: Synagogue inscription, Na‘aran,
North of Jericho. Vincent & Carrière S: CIJ 1202 E: – D: –
See above, n. 32.

17. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1099 S: BS 2:80 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

18. O: 
See above, n. 34. Ds: Julius (6)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 19 S: BS 2:189 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 41.

19. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Leader, of Caesarea
In Greek – . On this title see vol. 3, under Yael (1) B/F, p. 179 and Introduction 3.1.3.4. On the geographical designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Italy, Miranda S: JIWE 1, 30 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, and provenance – Palestine – but see but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 4th-5th C

20. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Joseph (85)’s son
Rey-Coquais, Archéologie au Levant, 405, suggest identifying him with Benjamin (13) found in the cemetery at Jaffa (CIJ 908). This identification is likely but not definite. F: Synagogue inscription, Ían Íalde,
Located south of Beirut and north of Sidon. Rey-Coquais S: IJO 3, Syr23 E: –
The inscription is a dedicatory inscription to a building. It includes biblical names, but is late and thus could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Roth Gerson, “A Greek Inscription at Khan Khalde,” Zion 56 (1991) 193-200 (Hebrew) identified it as a synagogue inscription. Her arguments, however, are not decisive. However the form  of the name of his brother is uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.3. D: 605
The inscription is dated to the era of the city of Beirut, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

21. O: 
See above, n.2. Ds: – F: Bowl, synagogue, Gaza S: Ovadiah, IEJ 19 (1969) 196 E: – D: –
See above, n. 32.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 7:52. The name is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). It is also documented on Hebrew First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 110, 424). בסא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 77).

body.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol.1, under Besai (2) B/M, p. 84. Ds: Nonnus (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 909 E: – D: 3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 31:2.

body.p:
1. O: בוצלא
So in the Lerner edition. Either this is the name intended in which name בצלאל is a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18, or בוצלא is a scribal error. Ds: – F: – S: Rut Rab 1:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 283) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. ברוך was Jeremiah’s scribe.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Saul (3)’s father F: – S: yGit 9:7, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 156) E: Fictitious?
These names are given as examples for signatures on a document, and probably do not represent real people. D: 3rd C
His son is mentioned as giving his signature to a document mentioned by Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Phineas (16)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Jerash,
In Transjordan. Crowfoot S: CIJ 866 E: – D: 5th C

3. O: 
For the form  see vol. 1, under Baruch (1) B/M, p. 84. This form looks like a Greek transliteration of the form ברוכי. For such forms see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.2, p. 11. For this name see vol. 4, under Barachiah (2) B/M, pp. 66-7. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 953 E: – D: 3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Zach 1:1.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d, Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 158-9 E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

2. O: יברכיה
So in the Munich Ms and in the Vilna print to bSot 49a and in the Jerusalem – Yad Harav Herzog 1 Ms. to bSan 94b. On the additional י see under Hezekiah (6) B/M in vol. 1, pp. 95, and 96, n. 17. Ds: Eleazar (24)’s father F: – S: bTaan 10b
Although he appears only in BT (here and in bSot 49 and in bSan 94b), his son is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and transmits haggadic traditions, in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5-6. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 161) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Hanan (11)’s father, of Bostra
In Aramaic – בוצרייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. So only in Exod Rab 10:1. In Gen Rab without place designation. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1. F: – S: Gen Rab 66:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 470) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Elder
In Aramaic – סבא. On this title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33. F: – S: Lev Rab 1:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 299) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Abbin (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

5. O: – Ds: Priest, berrabbi
In Hebrew – הכהן ברבי. On the first title see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. On the second title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: – S: TanB lekh lekha 4:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 299) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: זכריה
So in the parallel Tanḥuma (Warsaw edition). On this name see below under Zachariah B/M. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Levi (23)’s father F: – S: TanB behukotai 7:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 858) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: – Ds: Asaf (1)’s father F: – S: Pines, PIASH 5 (1971-6) 258 E: Fictitious?
See Introduction 5.1.4.2. D: 6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

8. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Barachiah (1) B/M, p. 81. The fall of the  is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. Ds: Marcelina (1)’s son F: Amulet, Samaria S: Piccirillo, Historiam pictura, 468 E: Samaritan?
The amulet comes from the region of Samaria and displays no Christian signs, but see Introduction 6.1.5. D: 572
The amulet is dated according to the Byzantine indictions, see Introduction 7.5.4.2.

9. O: 
See above, n. 16. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: CIIP 2, 1461 E: Jew?
One person mentioned in this epitaph has a biblical name and the other a Semitic one, but in the period in which it was composed these could have been Christian names, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Judg 4:8. ברק was the Prophetess Deborah’s partner.

body.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Joshua (3)’s father, Eden (1)’s son F: – S: Tulida, 129 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He is his contemporary.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Dan 18:6. גבריאל is the name of an archangel.

body.p:
1. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 42. Ds: Amos (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 293 E: Christian?
Lehmann & Holum wrote about this inscription: “Because the names are biblical and he was able to restore a building dedication, Lifschitz assigned the donation ‘sans doute’ to a synagogue. But the names are found among Christians too.” I think that this study actually shows that they are found much more among Christians than among Jews. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:5. גדליה was the Judaean prefect nominated by the Babylonians after destruction of the First Temple.

body.p:
1. O: גוריא
So in the parallel Tanḥuma (Warsaw edition) bahar 1. On this name see under S-H/M. Ds: Samuel (34)’s father F: – S: TanB, bahar 2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1136) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source, but in association with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: – Ds: Jeremiah (16)’s father, Joseph (128)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Ben-Dov, Shadow of the Temple, 334 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 17:4. גלית was the name of the Philistine giant David overcame in battle.

body.p:
1. O: איגוד/גוליד/גולידו/גולייר/גולירי/גולית
All these versions appear in various mss, see Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 144. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4./אמי
So in the printed text, see previous note. This is obviously a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. For this name see under Ami S-H/M. Ds: Hananiah (38)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 16:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 479) E: Nickname
Even if this is the said biblical name, it is very unlikely that it was used as a proper name, and see vol. 1, under Goliath (1) B/M, p. 84. On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. D: 3rd-4th C
His son transmits in the name of Joshua (4), who was a student of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Num 1:10.

body.p:
1. O: Gamalielus
This is an exact transliteration into Latin from the Greek , see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.2, p. 14. On this form in Greek see vol 1, under Gamaliel (1) B/M, p. 85. Ds: The Patriarch
Linder, JRIL, no. 41 is the document which removes this family from the status it held as patriarchs for the Jewish people for many generations, but the office he holds is designated in this document praefecturam. Marcellus, De Medicamentis 23, 77 designates him patriarcha. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: Codex Theodosianus 16:8:22 S: 1. Marcellus, De Medicamentis 23, 77
According to M. Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen (Tübingen 1995) 331-2 this person could be identical with this or the next one. 2. Linder, JRIL, no. 41 E: – D: 415
This is the year the document was issued. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 400-25, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 206 and Introduction 7.4.6.

2. O: Gamaliel
This is an exact transliteration into Latin from the Greek , short from , see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.2, p. 14. It is the Greek spelling of this name in LXX, see H. & R. Suppl. 45./Gamalihel
This is a variant reading, see previous note. The additional h fits the transliteration of the name in the Vulgate in Num 1:10, which is also the product of Jerome. Which is the correction of which is hard to decide here. Ds: The Patriarch
In Latin - patriarcha. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: Jerome, PL 22, 570 E: – D: 395
This is the year to which this letter of Jerome is dated. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 365-85, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 206 and Introduction 7.4.6.

3. O: – Ds: Annianus (2)’s son F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 63) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Abba (8), who was a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

4. O: – Ds: The 3rd
Meaning after Rabban Gamaliel the 1st (of the New Testament, see vol. 1, under Gamaliel [1] B/M, p. 85) and Gamaliel the 2nd (of Yavneh, see vol. 1, under Gamaliel [4] B/M, p. 85). This one is Judah the Patriarch’s son, see vol. 1, under Judah (36) B/M, p. 113. On this family see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: yKil 2:8, 28b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 173) E: – D: 225-35
According to Graetz, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.

5. O: – Ds: Twin/partner?
In Aramaic – זוגא. F: – S: yTer 11:5, 48b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 172) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a late contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: גמלייל
For the form גמליל, see vol. 4, under Gamaliel (1) B/M, p. 67. For the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Of Qunteh
In Aramaic – דקונתיה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 558-9. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yNed 10:8, 42b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 172) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Simon (3), who was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Liani (1)’s son F: – S: yNid 3:5, 51a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 486) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Mana (2), who was Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

8. O: 
So in BS 2:174. 3:9 has גמליאל. For the form  see vol. 1, under Gamaliel (1) B/M, p. 85. On the fall of the Greek suffix see vol.3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.1, p. 11. Ds: Rabbi
In Hebrew – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 14 S: 1. BS 2:174; 2. 3:9 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

9. O: – Ds: Nehemiah (10)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:15 E: – D: Pre-352
See previous note.

10. O: – Ds: Eleazar (43)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:26 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 21.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:22. גרשום was one of Moses’ sons.

body.p:
1. O: גרשון
On the interchange of מ and נ see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.3, p. 29. Ds: Ada (10)’s father F: – S: yTer 10:10, 47b
On this chain of tradition see Introduction 5.1.3.1.1. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 56) E: –D: Pre-400
Appears in PT with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4, and previous note.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yNed 3:8, 38a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 178) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel.

body.p:
1. O: דויד
For this form see vol. 3, under David (2) B/M, p. 82. Ds: – F: – S: yQid 3:1, 63d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 182) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: 
The biblical form of this name in LXX is . On the Greek suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.6, p. 12. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Tabgha,
Located on the northern shore of the Sea of Galilee. Schneider S: Klein, Yeshuv, 39 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

3. O: דויד
See above, n. 2. Ds: Moses (8)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Sukenik, “Jewish Inscriptions,” 139 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:18.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: His son
In the text – בר דליה. F: S: yKil 1:6, 27a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 156) E: Nickname; family?
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. On such family names see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.1, p. 39. However, in this case a tradition is cited in his name in a way that may indicate that this is the name of a rabbinic school, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.1, p. 39. D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Dan 1:7. דניאל is the biblical figure who gave his name to the Book of Daniel.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Tailor
In Aramaic – חייטה. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: Gen Rab 64:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 334) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in Palestinian-amoraic source, but in association with no one, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Daniel (4) B/M, p. 83. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 933 E: – D: 3rd C

3. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Daniel (1) B/M, p. 83. Ds: Ada (22)’s son, of Tyre
In Greek – . On such designtions see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Beit She‘arim, Avigad S: IJO 3, Syr7 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

4. O: 
See above, n. 5. Ds: Antoninus (3), Marcus (4) and Nonna (4)’s sons, Theodorus (13) Joshua (31)’s brother F: Dedicatory inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 2 E: Jew?
The inscription is accompanied by a cross, obviously implying Christianity. However, Di Segni, ibid., suggests, because of his sons’ names, that the father may have been a Jew or Samaritan, who converted to keep his job, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 455
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gadara, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

5. O: – Ds: – F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Sukenik, BIES 12 (1946) 64 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 42:1.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Eleazar (12)’s father F: – S: yBer 5:2, 9b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 69) E: Fictitious?
This person is only mentioned once (here) in the form ר' אלעזר ב"ר הושעיה. Elsewhere in PT we find the formula ר' אלעזר בשם ר' הושעיה (Rabbi Eleazar in the name of Rabbi Hoshaiah). Also Hyman does not record him. Yet in all the mss (Leiden, Vatican, Paris, London) and in the Venice print here the first form is recorded. Only in the margins of the Leiden Ms is the text emended. I think this form is the lectio difficilior, but doubt lingers. D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: – Ds: Berabbi
So he is designated in BT, e.g. bEruv 53a. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: – S: yPea 8:8, 21b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 64-9) E: – D: 3rd C
Was of the earliest amoraim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Samuel (14)’s son F: – S: yKil 6:3, 30c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 69) E: – D: 4th C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: – Ds: Nathan (4)’s father F: – S: yTer 7:1, 44c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 70) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: אושעיה
For this form see vol. 4, under Hoshaiah (2) B/M, p. 68. Ds: Abba (35)’s son F: – S: yGit 4:2, 45c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 18) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Judah (10) the Patriarch, who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: אושעיא
So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Oxford Opp. Add. Fol. 23 and in the Munich 140 Mss. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see above, n. 8./הושעיא
So in the Goettingen 3, the Cambridge T-S F2 (2) 73 and the Munich 95 Mss, see previous note. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26./יהושעיא
So in the Vatican 487 Ms, see above, n. 10. On the replacement of the הsuffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. On the additional י see under Hezekiah (6) B/M in vol. 1, pp. 95, and 96, n. 17. Ds: Zebadiah (6)’s son F: – S: bTaan 26b
Although mentioned only here in BT, he reacts to the words of Palestinian sages (see Introduction 5.3.2.3) and in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 127) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: אושעיה
So in bSan 25a. For this form see vol. 4, under Hoshaiah (2) B/M, p. 68. Ds: Ḥama (10)’s father F: – S: 1. bSan 25a; 2. Gen Rab 7:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, 458) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 3.

8. O: – Ds: Translator
In Aramaic – תרגימניה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.3. F: – S: Gen Rab 51:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 119) E: – D: 3rd C
Tanḥum (3), who transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), also transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Samuel (32)’s son
Hyman, Toldoth, 118 identifies him with Samuel (14), but if that were so, the designation of his father, “of Caesarea,” would be superflouos. F: – S: Lev Rab 31:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 118) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 3.

10. O: הושיעה
This could be this name with a letter reversal (see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20). However, Naveh, OSM, 124 does not think this is a name, but part of a prayer, with the word “save us.” Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Susya,
Village in southern Mount Hebron. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 86 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

11. O: 
The reading is mine. The editors had other suggestions. For this form see vol. 1, under Joseph (16) B/M, p. 150. There it is the alternative reading of the name and obviously this is the name intended, Joseph being a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Joseph (103)’s father F: Lintel inscription, Khisfin
In the Golan. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 74 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

12. O: – Ds: Tanḥum (35)’s son, of Tiberias
In Aramaic – מן טיבריה. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh, Atiqot 49 (2005)113* E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13. In the case of Hillel, the relative popularity of the name in the latter documents found in this list may be the result of the popularity of Hillel the Elder and his activities in Palestine.

body.p:
1. O: 
On this form see vol. 3, under Hillel (2) B/M, p. 84. Ds: Patriarch
In this text he is described as being nominated  (to the patriarchate). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: Epiphanius, PG 41, 412 E: Christian convert?
Epiphanius informs us that on his deathbed he summoned the bishop and     (the patriarch was granted baptism and the holy mysteries). D: 272-337
Was a contemporary of the Emperor Constantine. These are his dates. According to Graetz, he should be dated to 320-65, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.

2. O: – Ds: Joseph (6)’s son-in-law F: – S: yBer 2:5, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 4th C
His father/in/law was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.
