3. O: – Ds: Pazatos (2)’s son F: – S: yDem 7:7, 26c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Of Kifra
In Aramaic – דכיפרא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 376-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yPes 8:8, 36b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Mana (2), who was Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

5. O: הילל
For this form see vol. 1, under Hillel (2) B/M, p. 88. Ds: Gamaliel (5)’s brother F: – S: yMQ 3:5, 82c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a late contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Hananiah (15)’s father F: – S: yTer 1:5, 41a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2) and Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

7. O: הילל
See above, n. 10. Ds: Samuel (3)’s son F: – S: yShevu 6:1, 36b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
On his father see Introduction 7.4.2.

8. O: – Ds: Joshua (24)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:16 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

9. O: הליל
See above, n. 10. The letter reversal is probably a scribal error, see vol 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20. Ds: Levi (32)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:28 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 15.

10. O: הילל
See above, n. 10. Ds: Samuel (63)’s father F: Inscription, Wadi Hajjaj
In Sinai. S: Negev, Qadmoniot 4 (1971) 24 E: –
Despite the fact that the inscription was found in Sinai, the name is biblical and the inscription is in Hebrew characters, indicating Jewishness see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, p. 33 and 6.6, pp. 60-1. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, Josh 7:1. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 85-6; and in Idumea, see AOFCI, 99.

body.p:
1. O: זבד
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On this sort of kern form see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Ds: Aaron (2)’s father F: – S: Tulida, 134 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.

2. O: – Ds: Jacob (7)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:2, 3b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208-9) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: זבדא
So in yBer 1:5, 3d. In yShebi 1:5, 33b זבדי. For the form זבדא see vol. 4, under Zebediah (8) B/M, p. 69. Ds: Abba (6)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 12-3) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a contemporary of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

4. O: זביד
Usual form זבדי but so in yBer 2:8, 5c. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it. This could be a letter-reversal scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20, but for this form see vol. 4, under Zebediah (1) B/M, p. 69./זבדא
So in yShab 7:1, 9a, see previous note. For this form see above, n. 6. Ds: Simon (5)’s father F: – S: yBer 2:8, 5c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 209) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

5. O: – Ds: Levi (10)’s son F: – S: yDem 7:1, 26a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: זבד
See above, n. 2. Ds: Ḥalifa (4)’s father F: – S: Lev Rab 16:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 451) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [29]), who was Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, 1 Chr 8:17. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews.

body.p:
1. O: זכריה
So in the Vatican, Paris and London Mss of yBer 1:5, 3b as well as the Vatican and London Mss to yBer 6:5, 6c. On this name see below. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Jacob (7)’s son F: – S: yBer 3:5, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 209) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: זבידא
For this form see vol. 4, under Zebediah (4) B/M, pp. 69. Ds: – F: – S: yMSh 1:3, 53a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 4th C
See above, n. 3.

3. O: זבידא
See above, n. 4. Ds: Judah (7)’s father F: – S: ySot 7:4, 21d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Samuel (3) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

4. O: זבדא
For this form see vol. 4, under Zebediah (8) B/M, p. 69. Ds: Ḥiyya (19)’s father F: – S: yNed 6:3, 39c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

5. O: זבידא
See above, n. 4. Ds: Bisna (5)’s father F: – S: bBer 55b
On this chain of tradition see Introduction 5.1.3.1.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 320) E: –D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

6. O: גוריא
So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400) Ms. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.2.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see under Gurya S-H/M./זבדא
So in the Vilna and Pesaro prints and in the Goettingen 3 Ms, see previous note. For this form see above, n. 8./זיגורא
So in the Vatican 487 and in the Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 Mss, see above, n. 13. For the name זיגור see vol. 4, under Zighru (1) I/M, p. 206./זיגורי
So in the Cambridge T-S F2 (2) 73 Ms, see above, n. 13. For the name זיגור see previous note./זיגרא
So in the Munich 140 Ms, see above, n. 13 and n. 8. /זידא
So in the Vatican 134 Ms, see above n. 13. The fall of the ב is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20./זירא
So in the Munich 95 Ms, see above, n 13. For this form see vol. 4, under Ze‘ira (3) S-H/M, p. 356. Ds: Hoshaiah (6)’s father F: – S: bTaan 26b
Although his son is mentioned only here in BT, he reacts to the words of Palestinian sages (see Introduction 5.3.2.3) and in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 127) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: זבדא
See above, n. 8. Ds: Yohanan (15)’s father F: – S: Pines, PIASH 5 (1971-6) 258 E: Fictitious?
See Introduction 5.1.4.2. D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

8. O: זבידה
See above, n. 4. On the interchange of the א and ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25. Ds: Yohanan (16)’s son, Ḥalifa (8)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Capernaum, Klein S: CIJ 982 E: – D: 3rd C

9. O: 
On the  prefix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, p. 18. On the variant spellings of this name in Greek and Latin see vol. 3, under Zebadiah (4) B/M, n. 6, p. 85 Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1121 S: BS 2:97 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

10. O: 
See above, n. 26. For an exact transliteration of this form into Latin see vol. 3, under Zebadiah (8), p. 85. Ds: Vahaban (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 117 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 418
The inscription is dated and according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

11. O: זבידה
See above, n. 25. Ds: Zaza (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Kafra
South of Tiberias. S: Ilan, Ancient Synagogues, 160 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, 1 Chr 2:33.

body.p:
1. O: זוזי
This form is recorded in Palmayra, see Stark, PNPI, 86. The vowel ordering is probably a reflaction of the dialect, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. Ds: Zebadiah (11)’s father F: Epitaph, Kafra
South of Tiberias. S: Ilan, Ancient Synagogues, 160 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to the biblical book.

body.p:
1. O: זכאי
For this form see vol. 1, under Zachariah (18) B/M, p. 91./זכיי
In the Bible the form זכי is recorded, see Ezra 2:9. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 3:5, 6d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 211) E: –
Hyman, 401 claims he was Babylonian, but his reference is incorrect, and in all other references he is associated with Palestinian rabbis, and is designated רבי, see vol. 4, Introduction 7.1, pp.39-40. D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Levi (6)’s son-in-law F: – S: yPea 8:8, 21b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 212) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Simon (12)’s father F: – S: yDem 2:1, 22d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 212) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yonah (2) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: זכיי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Cook
In Aramaic – טבחא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: yMeg 4:1, 74d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 211) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: זכיי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Of Kabul
In Aramaic – דכבול, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 325-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yMeg 4:5, 75b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 211) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Hananiah (2), who transmits in the name of Samuel (12) who was a student of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s contemporary, see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: – F: – S: ySan 1:1, 18b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 212) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Levi (22)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 15:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, 858) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source, but in association with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

8. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see under Zachariah (5) B/M, in vol. 1, p. 90. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Schick S: CIJ 915 E: – D: 3rd C

9. O: 
The form  is recorded in vol. 1, under Zachariah (29), p. 91. This is the same name with a strange declension. For declensions that are clearly scribal errors see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.5, p. 21. Ds: Esther (4)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Vincent S: CIJ 916 E: – D: 3rd C

10. O: 
The form  is recorded in vol. 3, under Zachariah (3), p. 86. The form  is recorded in vol. 1, under Zachariah (29), p. 91. This is obviously a combination of the two. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 923 E: – D: 3rd C

11. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Zachariah (1) B/M, p. 90. Ds: – F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 67 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested by Di Segni, based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 5th-6th C

12. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Zachariah (1) B/M, p. 90. This is probably the same form without the Greek suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. The fall of the  may be a “correction” resulting from the way the name was pronounced. Ds: Jacob (68)’s father F: Sarcophagus, Tallusa
North east of Sichem-Nablus. S: Lifschitz, RB 76 (1969) 92 E: Samaritan?
The inscription was found on a sarcophagus in a region that is predominantly Samaritan. On such sarcophagi see Introduction 6.1.5.1. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

13. O: –
In Greek, but the publication only provides the Hebrew transcription, and Introduction 2.4. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth Govrin
West of Hebron. S: Kloner, Qadmoniot 20 (1988) 101 E: –
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p 35. D: 4th-8th C

14. O: 
See above, n. 11. Ds: – F: Seal, Jerusalem S: Saller, LA 21 (1971) 178 E: Jew?
The seal is located in the Franciscan Museum in Jerusalem. There is no information about where it was found, or in which archaeological context. If late, it could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52, and it could also be a fake, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.2, p. 39. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Hagai 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Samuel of Cappadocia’s attendant
In Aramaic – שושביניה דר' שמו' קפודקיא . This is Samuel (1) B/M in vol. 3, p. 161, but since he was a Rabbi in Palestine, so was his attendant. On such titles see Introduction 3.1.3.5. F: – S: yBer 2:6, 5b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 237) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yonah (2) transmits in the name of his master, see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 3:5, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 234-7) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: חגיי
On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Eleazar (16)’s father F: – S: ySheq 7:2, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 127) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: – Ds: Jonathan (17)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 21:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 702) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son transmits in the name of Isaac (5), who was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see Introduction 7.4.5.

5. O: 
In LXX this name is transliterated as , see H. & R. Suppl. 5. This a variation on the form. Ds: Abdolmithabo (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 48 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 385
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 240-4) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Of Akko
In Aramaic – עכייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 488-92. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yShab 14:4, 14d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 244) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Jeremiah (10)’s son F: – S: yQid 1:7, 61a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 244) E: – D: Pre-400
See previous note.

4. O: – Ds: Of Huquq
In Hebrew – חוקוק, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 248-9. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: ySan 3:9, 21d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 244) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Phineas (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

5. O: – Ds: Parnakh (1)’s son F: – S: bBer 63a
Although he apears only in BT, and only in this tradition, his father is a well known Palestinian rabbi, mentioned often in PT, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 461) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Bouleutinus (1)’s son F: – S: bArakh 28b
Although he appears only in BT here, he is associated with well known Palestinian rabbis (Abbahu [1] and Simon [2] i.e Resh Laqish) and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 461) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Translator
In Aramaic – תרגמנא. Hyman, ibid., thinks this refers to Hezekiah King of Judah, but he is not completely convincing. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.3. F: – S: Gen Rab 65:11 (Hyman, Toldoth, 423) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 4.

8. O: – Ds: Judah (62)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Jerash,
In Transjordan. Crowfoot S: CIJ 866 E: – D: 5th C

9. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Hezekiah (1) B/M, p. 95. This is probably the same form without the Greek suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. For the replacement of  with  and  as part of the phenomenon of iotacism see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. Ds: Levi (25)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 911 E: – D: 3rd C

10. O: חזקין
For this form see vol. 1, under Ezekiah (25) B/M, p. 96. Ds: Halifa (9)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Ein-Gedi,
In the Judaean desert, west of the Dead Sea. Barag & Porat S: Naveh, OSM, no. 70 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

11. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Hezekiah (1) B/M, p. 95. This is probably this form without the Greek suffix, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 17-8. For the replacement of  with  as part of the phenomenon of iotacism see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 194 E: Jew?
Both persons mentioned in this epitaph have biblical names, but in the period in which it was composed these could have been Christian names, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 18.

12. O: – Ds: – F: Sarcophagus, Kfar Giladi
A kibbutz in Upper Galilee. S: Kaplan, EI 8 (1966) 109 E: – D: 3rd C

13. O: 
See above, n. 19. Ds: Isaac (66)’s nephew
In Greek – . F: Epitaph, Jaffa S: Price, SCI 22 (2003) 218 E: – D: 3rd C?
The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them, see Introduction 5.2.2.1. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, it is correct for this one as well.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. חכליה was Nehemiah’s father.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: Amulet, Hecht Museum, Haifa S: – E: – D: –
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 9:4, 14b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 260) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Simon (3), who was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Tobiah (4)’s son F: – S: yBB 3:3, 14a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 260) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Gidol (3), who transmits in the name of Joseph (28), who was of Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Num 34:23.

body.p:
1. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. This would be a straightforward transliteration of Haniel, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11. Ds: Aged 7
In Greek – (. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Khisfin
In the Golan. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 77 E: Jew?
Since the name is reconstructed and not quite clear, and since the area was populated by Jews, pagans and Christians, there is no way to specifically identify this epitaph as Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.3. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

2. O: ח[ניא]ל
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Hannah (10)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Misgav IMSA 5 (2006) no. 31 E: – D: 519
The inscription is dated to 449 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Abba (10)’s son F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247, see Introduction 7.4.5.

2. O: – Ds: Ḥalbo (1)’s father F: – S: yBer 7:1, 11a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 259) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rav, see previous note.

3. O: – Ds: Simon (8)’s father F: – S: yPea 1:5, 16c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: – Ds: – F: – S: ySheq 3:2, 47c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 263-4) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

5. O: חנין
For this form see vol. 1, under Hanan (9) B/M, p. 99. Ds: Levi (18)’s son F: – S: yBes 4:1, 62b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

6. O: – Ds: Judah (28)’s father F: – S: ySan 10:1, 27d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son transmits in the name of Barachiah (1), who transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

7. O: חנין
So in most mss and prints, see above, n. 6. Ds: Son-in-law of the Patriarch’s House
In Aramaic – חתניה דבי נשיאה. On this family see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: bMQ 25b
Although mentioned only in BT, he is associated with the Palestinian Patriarchal House, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 502) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

8. O: – Ds: Hanan (7)’s son F: – S: bMQ 25b
See above, n. 11. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 523) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 12.

9. O: – Ds: Of Sepphoris
In Aramaic – דציפורין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 537-43. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Gen Rab 10:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 471) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Samuel (3), see Introduction 4.7.2.

10. O: – Ds: Nahmani (9)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 40:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 941) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

11. O: – Ds: Barachiah (3)’s son, of Bostra
In Aramaic – בוצרייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. So only in Exod Rab 10:1. In Gen Rab without place designation. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1. F: – S: Gen Rab 66:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 470) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: חנ[ן]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Íalifa (6)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Horvat Kanaf,
In the Golan, north east of the Sea of Galilee. Dalman S: CIJ 854 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

13. O: 
For the form  see vol. 1, under Hanan (38) B/M, p. 100. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 19 E: Jew?
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 28:1.

body.p:
1. O: Baranina
On the  prefix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, p. 18. The name in Greek would look as . On this form see vol. 3, under Hananiah (7) B/M, p. 92. Ds: Jerome’s teacher
Jerome writes in this letter to Pammachius and Oceanus that he took lessons from this person late at night because Baranina was afraid of what the Jews would do to him if they knew he was imparting their knowledge to Christians. F: – S: Jerome, PL 22, 745 E: – D: 388-420
Was Jerome’s teacher during his years in Bethlehem. These are the dates of his sojourn there.

2. O: חנינא
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (24) B/M, p. 103. Ds: Andreas (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 135) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits a tradition in the name of Samuel (12) who was a student of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s contemporary, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Ada (2)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:4, 3b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 57) E: – D: 3rd C
Tanḥum (3), who transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), also transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Ḥama (1)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 261) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a student of the Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

5. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Pappus (2)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:1, 4b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Samuel (6)’s father F: – S: yBer 2:4, 4d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Ahi (5)’s father F: – S: yBer 2:4, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

8. O: – Ds: Abbahu (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:4, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 34-5) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Tanḥum (5)’s father F: – S: yBer 4:4, 8b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

10. O: חיננא
On this form see vol. 3, under Hananiah (2) B/M, p. 91. Ds: Ze‘ira (3)’s father F: – S: yBer 5:1, 8d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 232) E: – D: 3rd C
He is mentioned in yTer 8:4, 46b in association with Queen Zenobia who reigned between 267-74, see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: חנינה
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (68) B/M, p. 105. Ds: Joseph (13)’s father F: – S: yBer 5:3, 9c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: חיננא
See above, n. 18. Ds: Isaac (9)’s son F: – S: yBer 6:1, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275-6) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Samuel (9), who was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

13. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Yaqa (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 9:2, 14a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 98) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

14. O: – Ds: Of En-Tena
In Aramaic – ענתוניה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 483-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yPea 1:1, 16b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 274) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2) and Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

15. O: – Ds: Hillel (6)’s son F: – S: yKil 7:5, 31a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 4th C
See previous note.

16. O: – Ds: Of Sepphoris
In Aramaic – דציפורין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 437-43. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yKil 9:3, 32a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 274-5) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Mana (2), Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

17. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: Joseph (23)’s son F: – S: yTer 4:3, 42d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

18. O: – Ds: Associate of the rabbis
In Aramaic – חברהון דרבנן. On this title see vol. 4, Introduction 3.2, p. 20. F: – S: yTer 8:3, 45c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 274) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

19. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: Of Tira
In Aramaic – תירתא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen 624-5. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yTer 10:6, 47b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

20. O: – Ds: Akhbari (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 11:5, 48b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ḥiyya (6), who was a student of Ami (1), see Introudction 7.4.1.

21. O: – Ds: Samuel (16)’s son F: – S: yShab 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Appears to be a tanna here, but in yDem 2:1, 22d it is obvious that he is a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1).

22. O: – Ds: Hoshaiah (2)’s nephew F: – S: yShab 1:2, 3a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 70) E: – D: 3rd C
His uncle was of the was of the earliest amoraim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

23. O: – Ds: Eleazar (14)’s father
Could be identified with Hananiah (19) B/M, in vol. 1, p. 103, but since the combination is so rare, and the names so common, this is unlikely. F: – S: yShab 3:7, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 127) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 20.

24. O: – Ds: Phineas (5)’s father F: – S: yShab 4:1, 6d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Hagai (2), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

25. O: – Ds: Shlamiah (1)’s son F: – S: yEruv 1:1, 18d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276-7) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247, see introduction 7.4.5.

26. O: חיננא
See above, n. 18. Ds: Abba (28)’s father F: – S: yEruv 8:4, 25a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 14) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was an early contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

27. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Kahai (1)’s son F: – S: yPes 2:7, 29c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Mana (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

28. O: חיננא
See above, n. 18. Ds: Yinṭah (1)’s father F: – S: yPes 4:1, 30c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

29. O: חיננא
See above, n. 18. Ds: Ami (6)’s father F: – S: yMeg 1:9, 71c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: 3rd C
Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

30. O: – Ds: Pazatos (6)’s son F: – S: yMeg 4:3, 75a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

31. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: Mana (1)’s brother F: – S: yMQ 3:5, 82d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 274) E: – D: 3rd C
His brother was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

32. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: Agol (1)’s son F: – S: yYeb 6:6, 7c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Ḥiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

33. O: – Ds: Of Qartis
In Aramaic – קרתיסיה. I do not know where this place is. Reeg, Ortsnamen, does not mention it. F: – S: yKet 2:9, 26d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

34. O: חיננא
See above, n. 18. Ds: Joseph (28)’s son F: – S: yGit 1:1, 43b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

35. O: – Ds: Sheila (6)’s son F: – S: ySan 8:8, 26c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rav (Abba [70] B/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247, see Introduction 7.4.5.

36. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: The scribe
In Aramaic – כתובה. On this designation see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: – S: yHor 1:3, 47a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 274) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Aḥi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

37. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Qara
In Hebrew – קרא, perhaps refering to his proficiency in the Bible (מקרא), see Introduction 3.1.2.2. F: – S: bTaan 27b
Although he appears only in BT (and often: bBer 30b; bMeg 22a; bYev 40a; bKet 56a), he is always associated with Palestinian rabbis, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 514) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

38. O: חנינה
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (68) B/M, p. 105. Ds: Goliath (1)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 16:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 479) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Joshua (4), who was a student of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

39. O: חננא
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (52) B/M, p. 104. Ds: Sansan (1)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 19:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 493-4) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

40. O: – Ds: Ahi (19)’s son F: – S: Lev Rab 3:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 478) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [28]) who was Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

41. O: – Ds: Abba (50)’s son F: – S: S of S Rab 7:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 505) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 17.

42. O: – Ds: Shalaqa (1)’s son F: – S: TanB, ki tese 10:10 (Hyman, Toldoth, 497) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

43. O: חנינה
See above, n. 20. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Hammat Gader, Sukenik S: CIJ 856 E: – D: Pre-438?
On the date of this synagogue see Introduction 7.5.3.
44. O: – Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Klein S: CIJ 895 E: – D: 3rd C

45. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (1) B/M, p. 103. Ds: Paregorius (5)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Alt S: CIJ 944 E: – D: 3rd C

46. O: 
See previous note. Ds: Jacob (50)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Gaza, Leob S: CIJ 967 E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

47. O: 
So in Beth Alpha. On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (50) B/M, p. 104./
So in Beth She’an. On this form see vol. 3, under Hananiah (7) B/M, p. 92. Ds: Marinus (6)’s son, artist
In both synagogues where they worked their handywork is comemorated. In Beit She’an with the word  (the work of their hands) and in Beit Alpha with the words:      (The artists who executed this work). F: Synagogue inscriptions, Beth Alpha
In the Beth She’an Valley. -Beth She’an, Sukenik S: 1. CIJ 1166; 2. Roth-Gerson, GISEI, no. 5 E: – D: 6th C

48. O: 
See above, n. 81. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1066 S: BS 2:55 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

49. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (72) B/M, p. 105. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1086 S: BS 2:69 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 86.

50. O: [ח]יננה
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 5. On the interchange of א and ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Dabbûra,
In the Golan. Urman S: Naveh, OSM no. 9 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

51. O: חנינא
See above, n. 5. Ds: Eleazar (45)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Kfar Nevoraya,
In Upper Galilee. Renan S: Naveh, OSM, no. 13 E: – D: 564
The inscription is dated to the year 494 to the Destruction of the Temple, see Introdution 7.5.4.3.

52. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see vol. 3, under Hananiah (6) B/M, p. 92. Ds: Alud (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Kfar Nafah
See above, n. 90. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 107 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.2, p. 51. Note that the area were the inscription was found was not uniquely Jewish. D: –
See above, n. 91.

53. O: 
See above, n. 81. Ds: Aged 75
In Greek – . On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Quneitra
See above, n. 90. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 212 E: Jew?
See above, n. 97. D: –
See above, n. 91.

54. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Hananiah (50) B/M, p. 104. The interchange of  and  is another form of iotacism (see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21), not recorded elsewhere. Ds: Aged 1
In Greek – ().On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Bab el-Hawa
See above, n. 90. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 233 E: Jew?
See above, n. 97. D: –
See above, n. 91.

55. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form vol. 3, under Hananiah (5), p. 91. Ds: Shiphra (1)’s son, Hilarus (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 346 E: Jew?
See above, n. 97. D: –
See above, n. 91.

56. O: אנינה
On this form see vol. 3, under Hananiah (11) B/M, p. 92. This could be an example of a Greek transliteration, transliterated back into Jewish characters, see Introduction 2.2. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Sepphoris S: Weiss, Sepphoris Synagogue, no. 10 E: – D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.4.2.

57. O: 
See above, n. 81. Ds: – F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 70 E: Jew?
See above, n. 97. D: 5th-6th C

58. O: – Ds: Phineas (19)’s son, Priest
In Aramaic – [כה]נה. On this designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Migav & Stern, Tarbiz 74 (2005) no. 28 E: – D: 444
The inscription is dated to 374 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

59. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10.

body.p:
1. O: טובי
On this form see vol. 1, under Tobiah (9) B/M, p. 110. Ds: Nathan (3)’s father F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 287) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: טבי
On this form see vol. 1, under Tobiah (4) B/M, p. 110. Ds: – F: – S: yTer 2:1, 41b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 287) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Josiah (1), who was a contemporary Rabbi Eleazar (22), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: טובי
See above, n. 2. Ds: Abdimi (7)’s father F: – S: yMQ 3:5, 82d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 25) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu, who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: טובי
See above, n. 2. Ds: Helkiah (2)’s father F: – S: yBB 3:3, 14a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 260) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Gidol (3), who transmits in the name of Joseph (28), Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: טובי
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: – S: yNid 1:1, 48d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 287) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan, see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Isaac (34)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 40:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 523) E: Fictitious?
This figure could be a literary invention, since the text runs: ר' טוביה בר' יצחק אמר: שני אהלים רות המואביה ונעמה העמונית. דכוותה "קום קח את אשתך ואת שתי בנותיך הנמצאות" (בראשית יט טו). ר' טוביה אמר: שתי מציאות רות ונעמה. אמר ר' יצחק: "מצאתי דוד עבדי" (תהלים פט כא). איכו מצאתיו? בסדום. “Rabbi Tobiah son of Rabbi Isaac said: Two tents – Ruth the Moabite and Naama the Amonite. And likewise: “Arise and take your two daughters found here” (Gen 19:15). Rabbi Tobiah said: Two found – Ruth and Naama. Rabbi Isaac said: “I have found my slave David” (Ps 89:21). Where have I found him? In Sodom.” Since in the the introductory passage there are two names mentioned as father and son, and further down two rabbis by these same two names are mentioned, perhaps there really was no such sage with a combined name, and this is merely a literary combination. D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: 
In vol. 3, under Tobiah (1) B/M, p. 94 I explained the absence of a standard transliteration for this name. Ds: Gadrathi (1)’s husband?
The name of this woman appears at the end of the inscription, just after its initiator had praised marriage. The editor assumed this means she was his wife. F: Dedicatory inscription, Dama,
In Transjordan. Waddington S: CIJ 864 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested, based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

8. O: 
See above, n. 14. This form is reminiscent of the apocryphal . Ds: Samuel (62)’s son, aged 10
In Greek – []  .On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Mourdouk
See above, n. 16. S: Dunand, RB 41 (1932) 562 E: Jew?
See above, n. 17. D: –
See above, n. 18.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Num 32:41.

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: Joshua (11)’s father
This is the only tradition where this sage is mentioned and he transmits a tradition in the name of Phineas (9) son of Yair (3) in vol. 1, p. 206. Because the name is rare, perhaps this is the same Yair. F: – S: yTaan 3:4, 66c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 294) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The longer form – יאשיהו – is the name of a king of Judah (2 Kgs 21:26).

body.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 2:6, 5b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 294-5) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary Rabbi Eleazar (22), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Jonathan (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 2:1, 41b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 295) E: – D: 3rd C
Seems to have been a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Of Usha
In Armaic – דמן אושא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 35-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bGit 33b
Although mentioned only in BT, his provenance (Usha) indicates a Palestinian origin, see Inroduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 564-5) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

4. O: יושיה
The interchange of the א with a ו is probably an indication of the decline of the laryngeals, see vol. 1, Intoduction 2.5.1, p. 28. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Isfiya,
In the Carmel. Avi-Yonah S: CIJ 885 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:22.

body.p:
1. O: 
So in both epitaphs. The form  is recorded in vol. 1, under Yadua (1) B/M, p. 112. The form  is recorded in vol. 4, under Yadua (3) B/M, p. 81. On the suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.7, p. 12. Ds: – F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 8, CIJ 1141, 1158 S: 1. BS 2:114; 2. 124 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:35. יהודה was one of Jacob’s sons, and a tribe of Israel. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2. Further on this name see Introduction 6.2.2.

body.p:
1. O: Iudae
On this form see vol. 3, under Judah (22) B/M, p. 96. Ds: – F: Codex Justinianus 3:13:3 S: Linder, JRIL, nos. 5 E: –
Jewishness suggested based on name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. It has been suggested that the Judah, to whom this rescript was issued, was the patriarch, Judah III, but this is by no means certain. D: 293
This is a rescript of the Emperor Diocletian, issued in this year, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (1) B/M, p. 112. Ds: Hillel (1)’s son F: – S: Epiphanius, PG 41, 416 E: – D: 320-403
Was a contemporary of Epiphanius, who lived in these years, see Introduction 7.1.

3. O: بهوذا
In the Hebrew version – יהודה. So in Arabic, in PO iv/3, 270, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would be יהודא. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. /ܝܗܘܕܐ
So in Syriac, in Guidi, ROC1/9 (1904) 87, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would be יהודא and see previous note./Iuda
So in Latin, in Gregory of Tour, PL 71, 179. On this form see above, n. 2./iuodas
So in Coptic, in Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 30b II, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek it would read . On this form see above, n. 5. Ds: Quiriacus (1), Simon (1) and Hannah (1)’s son, discoverer of the cross, bishop of Jerusalem
This is a well known Christian legend, retold in many versions and many languages, relating how Queen Helena discovered the true cross in Jerusalem with the help of Judah the Jew. F: – S: 1. PO iv/3, 270; 2. Guidi, ROC 1/9 (1904) 87; 3. Gregory of Tour, PL 71, 179; 4. Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 30b 2; 5. Krauss, Leben Jesu, 142 E: Christian convert
The text describes him as ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (in Syriac – Jew) or Hebreo (in Latin – Hebrew). Then it describes his conversion, elevation to the bishophood and subsequent martyrdon at the hands of Julian the apostate.; fictitious
See above, n. 11. D: 326-8
These are the years of Helena’s visit to Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.1.

4. O: –
In Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Marfalinah (1)’s son F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 176 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. Note the use of the name Judah by Samaritans, and see Introduction 1.1.1.2.1. D: 4th C
Calculated according to key dates in the Samaritan chronicles, see Introduction 7.2.2.

5. O: – Ds: Pazatos (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b
In BT, e.g. bBer 9b, he is always designated יהודה בן שמעון בן פזי. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322-4) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (1)’s father, Samuel (2)’s grandfather F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 255) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: – Ds: Zebadiah (3)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Samuel (3) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

8. O: יודן
On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (48) B/M, p. 114. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 299-319) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

9. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Ayybu (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:4, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 84) E: – D: 3rd C
His father transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Patriarch
In Aramaic – נשיאה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: yBer 3:1, 6a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 319-20) E: – D: 235-60
According to Graetz, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.

11. O: יודה
So here. Elsewhere יהודה. On this form see vol. 4, under Judah (2) B/M, p. 82. Ds: Titus (2)’s son F: – S: yBer 3:4, 6c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 291) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Of Ein Tura
In Aramaic – ענתירדיה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 482-3. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 320) E: – D: 3rd C
Supports Rabbi Yohanan (1) in a debate, see Introduction 7.4.1.

13. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Ishmael (2)’s son
A. Marmorstein, “About the Inscription of Judah ben Ishmael,” PEFQS 59 (1927) 101-2 suggests identifying him with Judah (69). On such identifications, however, see vol. 1, Introduction 3.3, pp. 34-6. F: – S: yBer 4:2, 7d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 321) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

14. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Tanḥum (6)’s father F: – S: yBer 6:1, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 327) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son transmits in the name of Ḥiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

15. O: – Ds: Simon (3)’s son F: – S: yBer 8:5, 12b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Shalum (3)’s son F: – S: yBer 9:2, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 324-5) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

17. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Of Migdal
In Aramaic – מגדליא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 696-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 9:2, 14a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 319) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

18. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Playah (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 9:5, 14b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

19. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Dorotheus (1)’s son
Probably not identical with Judah (63) B/M of vol. 1 (p. 114) because he transmits a tradition in the name of Rabbi Simon bar Yohai (Simon [51] son of Yohanan [32] vol. 1, p. 220) who is later. In volume 1, I probably gave the wrong reference. It should have been bPes 70b. F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 184) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

20. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Mataniah (1)’s father F: – S: yDem 5:3, 24c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 320) E: – D: 4th C
For his son’s date see Introduction 7.4.1.

21. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Gurion (1)’s son F: – S: yShevi 2:3, 33d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary Ḥiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

22. O: – Ds: Ami (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 2:5, 41d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: 3rd C
His father is mentioned in yTer 8:4, 46b in association with Queen Zenobia, who reigned between 267-74, see Introduction 7.4.1.

23. O: יודני
So in yTer 8:5, 45c. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it. On this form see above, n. 22. For the additional י suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 11./יודנה
So in the parallel in yAZ 2:3, 41a, see previous note. For the additional ה suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 11. The examples there refer to an א suffix, but in Palestine א and ה suffixes are often interchangeable, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.3, p. 25. Ds: His son
In the text in Aramaic – בר יודני. F: – S: yTer 8:3, 45c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 325) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

24. O: – Ds: Benaiah (2)’s son F: – S: yTer 11:1, 47d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 51) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1). See Introduction 7.4.1.

25. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Joseph (13)’s nephew F: – S: yTer 11:5, 48a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 325) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a relative of Joseph (13), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

26. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Gadia (1)’s son F: – S: yMSh 4:1, 54d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 163) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Jacob (12), who transmits in the name of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

27. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Tryphon (2)’s son F: – S: yOrl 1:3, 61a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 292) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

28. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Hanan (6)’s son F: – S: yOrl 1:3, 61b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Barachiah (1), who Transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

29. O: – Ds: Levi (15)’s son F: – S: yShab 7:2, 10c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 321-2) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

30. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Samuel (17)’s father F: – S: yShab 12:1, 13c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 326-7) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

31. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Of Kfar Immi
In Aramaic – דכפר אימי, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 335-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yShab 16:7, 15d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

32. O: – Ds: Abba (27)’s father F: – S: yEruv 6:6, 23d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 14) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247. On such dating see Introduction 7.4.5.

33. O: יודה
See above, no. 29. Ds: Laqrah (1)’s son F: – S: ySuk 4:6, 54d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

34. O: – Ds: Nahmani (6)’s son F: – S: ySuk 5:1, 55a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a translator in Resh Laqish (Simon [2])’s academy, who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

35. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Pazatos (5)’s son, of Bardalia
In Aramaic – דברדלייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 149-50. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBes 2:8, 61d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 156) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits traditions in the name of tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

36. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Hama (9)’s son, of Kfar Tehumin
In Aramaic – דכפר תחומין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 374-5. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yTaan 1:7, 64d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 262) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

37. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Manaseh (2)’s son F: – S: yTaan 2:1, 65a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

38. O: יודן
On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (48) B/M, p. 114. Ds: Of Gezer
In Hebrew – גזורי, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 176-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yMeg 1:5, 71a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Aḥi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

39. O: – Ds: Tamuza (1)’s son F: – S: yMeg 4:5, 75b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2) and Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

40. O: – Ds: Simon (26)’s son F: – S: yHag 1:8, 76d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 325) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

41. O: – Ds: Safra (2)’s son F: – S: yHag 1:6, 76c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

42. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Shiqlai (1)’s son F: – S: yKet 9:10, 33c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 324) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

43. O: יודא
On this form see vol. 4, under Judah (12) B/M, p. 82. Ds: Ṣereda (1)’s son F: – S: yNed 7:1, 40b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 324) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

44. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Patriarch,
In Aramaic – נשיאה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. Judah (10)’s grandson F: – S: yNaz 7:1, 56a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 320) E: – D: 290-320
According to Graetz, see Jacobs, Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen, 205 and Introduction 7.4.6.

45. O: – Ds: Abbin (6)’s son F: – S: yQid 1:2, 59d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 42) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

46. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Simon’s
In vol. 1, Simon (52) B/M, p. 220. grandson F: – S: yQid 1:7, 61b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 184) E: – D: 3rd C
He is the son of a tanna, see Introduction 7.4.1.

47. O: – Ds: Yohanan (1)’s student
In the text ר' יהודה ור' שמעון תלמידיו של ר' יוחנן . F: – S: bBer 21b
Although mentioned only her in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and transmits tradition in the name of the Palestinian Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1685) E: Fictitious?
The text tells of Abdimi (1) (S-H/M - vol. 4, p. 318) coming to Babylonia and transmitting a tradition in his name and in the name of Simon (32). Usually ר' יהודה ור' שמעון are the famous Judah (30) B/M vol.1, p. 113 and Simon (51) B/M vol. 1, p. 220, but they cannot be students of Yohanan (1). Thus I assume these are otherwise unknown students, from Palestine of course, although it cannot be ruled out that they are a literary invention of an early sage. D: 3rd C
Was the student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

48. O: – Ds: Sheila (7)’s son F: – S: bShab 44a
Although mentioned only in BT, he makes his appearance clearly in Palestinian contexts, and see also Hyman, Toldoth, 570, and Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 667-8) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Asi (Joseph [28]), who was Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

49. O: – Ds: Āštād/t (1)’s son F: – S: bEruv 52a (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 660) E: –
Although mentioned only here in BT, and although he bears the title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36), he is found only in association with a Palestinian rabbi (Nathan [4], son of Hoshaiah [4]), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3.. D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Nathan (4) (see previous note), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

50. O: – Ds: Ada (18)’s son F: – S: 1. bRhSh 31a; 2. TanhB bereshit 21 (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 660) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

51. O: – Ds: Bisna (6)’s son F: – S: bNed 32a
This is the only tradition in which he is mentioned, but his son is designated with the Palestinian title רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2 and he is mentioned as a דרשן (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6). Also the tradition is in Hebrew, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 661) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

52. O: – Ds: Ma‘arava (2)’s son F: – S: bSot 41b
In the Vilna print of BT he is only mentioned in this tradition. In the mss he is also mentioned in bSuk 52a, but there is some confusion whether an independent person is intended or the tanna Rabbi Judah (vol. 1, Judah [30] B/M, p. 113) when he expounded in the west (במערבא). The two traditions together, and his exegetical role (in Hebrew), makes it likely that he was Palestinian, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 666) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 113.

53. O: – Ds: Masparta (1)’s son F: – S: 1. bSan 44a; 2. Gen Rab 53:10
See Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 565, in the critical apparatus. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 666) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

54. O: – Ds: Pedayah (2)’s son, Qapara’s
In vol. 1, Qapara (1) S-H/M, p. 409. nephew F: – S: Gen Rab 21:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 567-9) E: – D: 3rd C
Was associated with the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

55. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Joseph (56)’s son F: – S: Lev Rab 9:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, –) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, no. 20.

56. O: יהדה
Throughout Bekkum’s book his name appears in this orthography in the acrostic sequence of the third part of each poem. On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (160) B/M, p. 117. Ds: Poet
We know this poet from the achrostica of his poems in which his name appears. And see Introduction 3.1.3.7. F: – S: Bekkum, Poems of Yehudah E: – D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

57. O: – Ds: Physician,
Cited as an authority on a medical substance in the Book of Assaph the Physician, see Introduction 5.1.4.2. of Jericho
In Hebrew – הירחוני. F: – S: Muntner, Assaph, 167 E: – D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

58. O: Iud[ae]
The reading is according to the ammendation of JIWE 1, 15, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. CIJ had only a fragment of the inscription before it. On this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Marcus (2) Aurelius (4) Pylades (1)’s father, of Scythopolis
In Latin – Scythop. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Italy, Meiggs S: CIJ 534a E: –
Considered Jewish because of his provenance from Scythopolis, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.8, p. 54; and his name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.8, pp. 52-3. D: 3rd C

59. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Naveh,
In the Bashan (Transjordan south of the Golan). Braslawski S: CIJ 853 E: – D: 3rd-4th C

In Aramaic – חזאנה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.2. F: Synagogue inscription, Afeq,
In the Golan. Schumacher S: CIJ 855 E: – D: 3rd-4th C

61. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Architect from Emaus
In Aramaic – ארדה מן חימאוס. Naveh, OSM, 57 interprets ארדה as short for ארדיכל. On the geographical designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. On the profession see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Synagogue inscription, Hammat Gader, Sukenik S: CIJ 857 E: – D: Pre-438?
On the dating of this synagogue see Introduction 7.5.3.

62. O: ידן
On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (106) B/M, p. 116. Ds: Hezekiah (8)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Jerash,
In north-west Transjordan. Crowfoot S: CIJ 866 E: – D: 5th C

63. O: יודן
See above, no. 22. Ds: Tryphon (4)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 892 E: – D: 3rd C

64. O: 
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Greek. On this form see vol. 1, under Judah (82) B/M, p. 115./יודן
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Hebrew. On this form see above, n. 22. Ds: Jonathan (24)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 900 E: – D: 3rd C

65. O: 
See above, no. 141. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 923 E: – D: 3rd C

See above, no. 5. Ds: Jonathan (26)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Schick S: CIJ 924 E: – D: 3rd C

See above, no. 5. Ds: Paregorius (3)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 926 E: – D: 3rd C

See above, no. 22. Ds: Eleazar (38)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Bar‘am,
In Upper Galilee. Renan S: CIJ 975 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: See above, no. 22.
A. Marmorstein, “About the Inscription of Judah ben Ishmael,” PEFQS 59 (1927) 101-2 suggests identifying him with Judah (13). See above, no. 35.
North of the Sea of Galilee.
See above, no. 148.

105. O: 
The editor failed to read the inscription. If these letters are an ethnicon, then one of the persons mentioned in this inscription (? ?) is Jewish. If not, this person is Jewish, because of the name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.8, p, 52. The form is perhaps recorded in the vocative case. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Transjordan S: Séjourné, RB 7 (1898) 104 E: – D: –
See above, no. 148.
