In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

118. O: []
Reading reconstructed by us, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 5. Ds: Claudia (1)’s husband?
We assume that a man and a woman mentioned together on the same inscription in the Elijah’s Cave are man and wife, but in this case it is not even certain that the second person is a woman, since the end of the name is reconstructed, see under Claudia. F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 23 E: –
Jewishness indicated by the Hebrew form of the name, see Introduction 6.2.2. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Chr 17:18.

div.p:
1. O: יהזבד
The fall of the ו is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beit She‘arim S: CIJ 1132 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 17:9. יהושע was the name of the general, Moses’ successor, who gave his name to a biblical book. On the Jewishness of this name in a post-Chriatian era see Introduction 6.2.2.1.

div.p:
1. O: aboc’ihsou
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . In Hebrew this would perhaps read אבות ישוע, perhaps indicating a name such as the Arabic אבו ישוע, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 15. Ds: High priest
In Coptic – paryhereus. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 29b 2 E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: ihsou
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . On this form see vol. 1, under Joshua (48) B/M, p. 127. Ds: High priest
In Coptic – paryhereus. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 29b 2 E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

3. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Barak (1)’s son, leader
On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 129 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introduction 7.2.3.

4. O: – Ds: Of Sikhnin
In Aramaic – דסכנין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 458-60. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 335) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: – Ds: Of Darom
In Aramaic – דרומיא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 212-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 5:9, 9c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 187) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Rabbi Yonah (2) and Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

6. O: – Ds: Zeidal (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 8:3, 45c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 342) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: יושוע
For the form ישוע, see vol. 1, under Joshua (1) B/M, p. 126. On the additional ו as a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13. Ds: Gizorah (2)’s son F: – S: yShab 3:1, 5c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 16.

8. O: – Ds: Abbin (15)’s son F: – S: yYom 3:5, 40c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 42) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Annianus (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

9. O: – Ds: Nehemiah (2)’s son F: – S: ySheq 2:3, 46d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 42) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Judah (15), whose father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Nahmani (7)’s son F: – S: yTaan 1:6, 64c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 342) E: Fictitious?
The text is as follows: רבי יצחק בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי צומא רבא. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה: איסתניס אני. רבי יהושע בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי תעניתה. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה איסתניס אני (Rabbi Isaac bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of the Great Fast [i.e. Yom Kippur] He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive. Rabbi Joshua bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of fasting. He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive).. Perhaps the second is simply a literary parallel and not a historical figure. D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: – Ds: Yair (1)’s son F: – S: yTaan 3:4, 66c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 336) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

12. O: יישוע
For this form see vol. 1, under Joshua (1) B/M, p. 126. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Dorotheus (3)’s brother F: – S: yMQ 3:5, 82c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 184) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

13. O: יישוע
See above, n. 24. Ds: Ishmael (6) and Yohanan (9)’s father F: – S: yYeb 7:6, 8b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 184) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 23.

14. O: – Ds: Joseph (51)’s father F: – S: yNid 3:2, 50d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, –
In Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 430-1 one is informed that any Joseph son of Joshua refers to Joseph (34) son of Joshua ben Levi (vol. 1, Joshua [25], p. 126) but the text here does not imply this. Hyman, Toldoth, 728 identified him as a separate person, also mentioned in bHul 56b and bNid 24a, but because he is cited by Rabbi Yohanan (1), he thinks he was a tanna, i.e. too early for this volume. Yet he is only recorded in amoraic literature. ) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

15. O: – Ds: Abba (44)’s son F: – S: bShab 126a
Although he appears only in BT, he bears the title רבי, see vol. 4, Introduction 7.1, pp. 39-40, and Hyman, Toldoth, 620. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 868-7) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ulla (1), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: – Ds: Boethus (2)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 84:18 (Hyman, Toldoth, 621) E: – D: 3rd C
Cites late tannaim and early amoraim, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.

17. O: – Ds: Benjamin (5)’s son F: – S: S of S Rab 4:16 (Hyman, Toldoth, 621) E: – D: 3rd C
Rav Huna (1) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 347, who died in 297 transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.5.

18. O: – Ds: Timaius (1)’s son F: – S: Eccl Rab 9:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 635) E: – D: 3rd C
He is mentioned by Isaac (4), who transmitted traditions in the name of late tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

19. O: – Ds: Ephraim (2)’s son F: – S: Est Rab 5:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 620-1) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 23.

20. O: – Ds: Saraf (1)’s son, priest of Arbel
In Hebrew – כהן מארבל, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 56-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5-6, pp. 33-4. F: – S: SOZ 9:6 E: – D: Post-270
In this chronicle, just before he is mentioned, we are informed that 166 years after the destruction of the Temple there was a war between Rome and the Persians. He was therefore supposed to have lived shortly thereafter.

21. O: – Ds: Poet
In this composition Se‘adya Gaon explains the work of poets (אלשערא in Judeo-Arabic), and lists this one among them, see Introduction 3.1.3.6. F: – S: Saadia Gaon, Ha’egron 155 E: – D: 5th-7th C
Zulay, Eretz Israel, 165 dates him to the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.5.5.

22. O: יהושוע
On the additional ו as a dialect variant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, pp. 13. Ds: Eleazar (33)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 897 E: – D: 3rd C

23. O: יהושוע
See prvious note. Ds: Tanḥum (34)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Beer Sheba S: CIJ 1196 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

24. O: יהשוע
The letter replacement is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20. Ds: Hillel (8)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:16 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

25. O: יושוע
So in BS 3:23. For this form see above, n. 17./יהושוע
So in BS 3:24 and 3:25, see above, n. 40. Ds: Levi (31)’s son,
It has been suggested by the editors that he is identical with Joshua (25) B/M in vol. 1, p. 126. However on such identifications see vol. 1, Introduction 3.3, pp. 35-6. Megea (1)’s husband F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: 1. BS 3:23; 2. 3:24; 3. 3:25 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 44.

26. O: יש[וע]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see vol. 1, under Joshua (1) B/M, p. 126. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Kfar Canah,
East of Nazareth. Clermont-Gannau S: Naveh, OSM, no. 31 E: – D: –
See above, n. 42.

27. O: אישו
This is a form of the name Joshua recorded for Jesus on an incantation bowl, see Levene, JSQ 6 (1999) 287. Although the authors of this bowl may not have identified the two (see Introduction 2.2) it seems to have been a Semitic variant of this name. The name אישו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 75 and the form ’ŠW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 50). Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Ma‘on,
In the north-western Negev. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 57 E: – D: –
See above, n. 42.

28. O: יושוע
So in OSM 78. For this form see above, n. 55./ישוע
So in OSM 77. On this form see above, n. 49. Ds: The witness
In Hebrew – העד. F: Synagogue inscriptions, Susya,
In southern Mount Hebron. Guttman S: Naveh, OSM, nos. 77, 78 E: – D: –
See above, n. 42.

29. O: 
On the form see vol. 1, under Joshua (1) B/M, p. 126. The fall of the  as well as the unusual suffix are obviously a scribal errors, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20, and 2.8.5, p. 21. Ds: Joseph (101)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Gaza, Avi-Yonah S: Roth-Gerson, GISEI, no. 21 E: – D: 508
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gaza, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

30. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Joshua (1) B/M, p. 126. Ds: Sheila (9)’s son, aged 60
In Greek –   . On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Dabiyye
In the Golan. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 94 E: –
Even though the area were the inscription was found was not uniquely Jewish (see Introduction 6.2.1.3), this biblical name was not adopted by Christians, since they refrained from using the name of Jesus prophanely, see Introduction 6.2.2. D: –
See above, n. 42.

31. O: 
On the interchange of  with  in Greek orthography see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. On the unusual declension see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.5, p. 21. Ds: Theodorus (13), Marcus (4) and Nonna (4)’s son, Daniel (4) Antoninus (3)’s brother F: Dedicatory inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 2 E: Jew?
The inscription is accompanied by a cross, obviously signifying Christianity. Di Segni, ibid., suggests, based on his sons’ names, that their father may have been a Jew or Samaritan, who converted to keep his job, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 455
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gadara, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

32. O: יהושוע
See above, n. 40. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beer Sheba S: Jaussen et al., RB 14 (1905) 252 E: – D: –
See above, n. 42.

33. O: ישוע
See above, n. 49. Ds: Omer (1)’s husband F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Stern, Tarbiz 68 (1999) no. 13 E: – D: 375
The inscription is dated to 305 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

34. O: – Ds: Levi (35)’s son, rabbi
In Aramaic – רבי. Not identical with Joshua (25). Perhaps identical with Joshua (25) B/M, in vol. 1, p. 126, but see above, n. 47. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Aviam & Amitai, Cathedra 141 (2011) no. 13 E: – D: 2nd-4th C

35. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Joshua (48) B/M, p. 127. Ds: Jonathan (32)’s son F: Sarcophagus lid, private collection S: Cotton, personal communication E: –
Jewishness indicated by son’s name see Introduction 6.2.2. D: –
See above, n. 42.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:16. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2. Further on this name and its use by Jews see Introduction 6.2.2.2.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 345-84) E: – D: d. 280
See Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Of En Tena
In Aramaic – ענתנייתא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 483-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 5:1, 9a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 385) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Of Qasion
In Aramaic – דקרציין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 576-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 8:6, 12b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 385) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Nahum (2), whose father was a tanna, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Madaya (1)’s son F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 385) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Mana (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: – Ds: Of Sepphoris
In Aramaic – בולווטיה דציפורין הוה להון צומות והוה תמן חד מיתקרי יוחנן(the council of Sepphoris declared fasts and there was on there called Yohanan). F: – S: yPea 1:1, 16a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, –) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Sheila (3)’s son F: – S: yShab 4:1, 6d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 386) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 4.

7. O: יונתן
So in yMeg 3:8, 74b. This may be considered a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. It may however actually be the name of this person, in which case יוחנן is the scribal “correction.” Ds: Scribe of Gufta
In Aramaic – ספרה דגופתא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 171-2. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. On the title see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: – S: ySuk 2:5, 53a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 4.

8. O: – Ds: Safra (2)’s brother F: – S: yHag 1:6, 76c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 385) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

9. O: יחונן
The letter reversal in this version is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.5, p. 21. Ds: Joshua (13)’s son F: – S: yYeb 7:6, 8b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 386) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 4.

10. O: – Ds: Simon (30)’s father F: – S: yAZ 1:4, 39d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 386) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son witnessed an inscription of Diocletian in Tyr, see Introduction 7.4.2.

11. O: – Ds: Arza (1)’s son F: – S: bAZ 58a
Although he appears only here in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and is mentioned in a halakhic anecdote which is then commented upon by a Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 782) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: יוחי
On this form see vol. 1, under Yohanan (32) B/M, p. 135. Ds: Jacob (33)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 60:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, –) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Jonathan (9), a contemporary of Simon (3), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

13. O: חנא
So in BT. On this name see under Ḥana S-H/M. Ds: Shahina (1)’s son F: – S: 1. bAZ 75a; 2. Lev Rab 5:2 (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 499) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

14. O: – Ds: Joseph (57)’s father,of Tzitor
In Hebrew – איש ציתור, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 536-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Lev Rab 24:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 717) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 4.

15. O: – Ds: Zebadiah (7)’s son, physician,
In Hebrew – הרופא. On this Jewish medical literature see Introduction 5.1.4.2. of Jericho
In Hebrew – הירחוני, according to Muntner, Assaph, 163. F: – S: Pines, PIASH 5 (1971-6) 258 E: Fictitious?
On the question of his historicity see Pines, ibid. D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

16. O: – Ds: Zebadiah (8)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Capernaum,
On the northern shore of the Sea of Galilee. Klein S: CIJ 982 E: – D: 3rd C

17. O: – Ds: Joseph (83)’s father, Caleb (1)’s grandfather F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem De Saulcy S: CIJ 1403 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

18. O: – Ds: Simon (57)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 12 S: BS 3:2 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

19. O: – Ds: Joseph (98)’s son, priest
In Hebrew – הכהן. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, pp. 33-4. F: Synagogue inscription, Susya,
In southern Mount Hebron. Guttman S: Naveh, OSM, no. 75 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

20. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Yohanan (88) B/M, p. 137. For the interchange of  and  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 15. Ds: Ismenus (1)’s father, of Tiberias
In Greek – On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Dedicatory inscription, Rome S: Schwabe, Yohanan Levi, no. 16 E: Jew?
Although he bears a Jewish name, this person resides in Rome, where the name Johannes became very popular with Christians, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52, and the inscription was found on the base of a human female statue, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.8.1. D: 3rd C

21. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see vol. 1, under Yohanan (88) B/M, p. 137. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 298 E: Jew?
Caesarea was a mixed city and this could be a Christian name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 36.

22. O: 
On this form see vol. 3, under Yohanan (17) B/M, p. 106. Ds: Innkeeper
In Greek –  (of the innkeepers). On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Inscription, Antioch
In Syria. S: Jalabert & Mouterde, IGLS 770 E: Jew?
This is an inn inscription. It bears Hebrew names and a biblical quotation (1 Sam 16:4). Yet its tentative date (and the popularity of this name among Christians, see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.1.2, p. 4-5) puts its Jewish character into question, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. IJO 3, App19 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription. D: 6th C

23. O: 
This is all that could be read from the publication. Perhaps another name is intended and maybe other names were found on this inscription. If this is the name intended the following observations can be made: On the interchange of  and , see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the form , see vol. 3, under Yohanan (23) B/M, p. 106. The additional  is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.1, p. 20. The declension is probably in the vocative. Ds: – F: Inscription on column base, Sheikh Meyser
In Samaria. S: Zertal, Har Menashe 3 (2000) 266 E: Samaritan
Suggested based on location, see Introduction 6.1.5, but this could be a Christian name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52, or the reading could be wrong. D: –
See above, n. 36.

24. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Yohanan (67) B/M, p. 136. Ds: Isidorus (3)’s son, aged 10 months
In Greek – []. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1b, no. 59 E: Jew?
The inscription mentions  (one God who rules all) but this is no indication of Jewishness, especially not in Zoar, see Introduction 6.1.6. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 4th-6th C
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.

25. O: 
See above, n. 43. Ds: Gadia (4)’s son F: Epitaph, Beer Sheba S: Jaussen et al., RB 14 (1905) 253 E: Jew?
The inscription was found in a location where Jews also resided, but the name may be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 36.

26. O: 
The form  is recorded in vol. 1, under Yohanan (129) B/M, p. 138. On the interchange of  and , see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the hellenized suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1.1.1, p. 11. Ds: Macarius
Macarius could also be considered this Yohanan’s son, but the way the inscription is transcribed () suggests that it should be translated for Cyrus, [son of] Megalus, son of Macarius Yohanan. The editor translated  as “the blessed” (המאושר), but such an interpretation is unnecessary. (1), Megalus (3)’s father F: Epitaph, Khirbet Ḥebra
South of Tel Aviv. S: Kaplan, BIES 11/3-4 (1945) 23 E: –
Jewishness indicated by the form of the name, which was not used by Christians, see Introduction 6.2.2.2. D: –
See above, n. 36.

27. O: יואנס
The inscription is in Greek but this is the Hebrew transcription given in the publication, see Introduction 2.4. Ds: – F: Dedicatory inscription, Ha-Bonim
On the seashore, south of Haifa. S: Prausnitz, AN 15 (1965) 17 E: Jew?
This could be a Christian name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 36.

28. O: –
The Inscription is in Greek, but the report is in Hebrew, see Introduction 2.4. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Tel Eitun
West of Hebron. S: Tzafaris, AN 27 (1968) 8 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 36.

29. O: יואנס
See above, n. 63. Ds: – F: Synagogue chancel screen, Beth She’an S: Bahat & Druks, AN 36 (1970) 7 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: –
See above, n. 36.

30. O: יוחנ[ן]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Samuel (73)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

31. O: 
See above, n. 40. Ds: – F: Seal (Jerusalem) S: Manns, LA 26 (1976) no. 34 E: Jew?
The seal is located in Jerusalem but its provenance is unknown, and it could be a fake, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.10.2, p. 39. This could also be a Christian name, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The seal is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3.

32. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 43. Ds: Simon (85)’s father F: Oil lamp, Jerusalem S: Loffreda, LA 44 (1994) 595 E: Jew?
The editor suggested that the persons mentioned on this lamp were Jewish because of their names, and because this type of lamp was idenitifed as being in use by Jews, but at this time, both are not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 36.

33. O: 
For the form  see vol. 1, under Yohanan (129) B/M, p. 138. On the Greek suffix see vol. 3, 2.2.1.1.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 8 E: –
Jewishness indicated by the Hebrew form of the name, see Introduction 6.2.2.2. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, 2 Kgs 14:25. יונה was the prophet after whom a biblical book is called.

div.p:
1. O: ܝܘܢܐ
In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read יונא. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. Ds: Leader of the Jews
The text speaks of the forced conversion of Jews (ܝܗܘܵܕܝܐ). He is described as ܚܕ ܡܢܗܘܢ ܡܢ ܪܝܵܫܐ ܕܒܗܘܢ (one of them, one of their leaders) and is their spokesman. F: – S: Chabot, Chronicon Pseudo-Dionysianum 2, 149 E: Forced convert to Christianity
See previous note, and Introduction 5.1.1. D: 616
This is the date at which time this information is inserted in the chronicle (928 of the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1).

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:2, 3b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 387-95) E: – D: 4th C
Is associated with the general Ursicinus, who was active in Palestine in the year 351-2 (yBer 5:1, 9a), see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: – Ds: Of Bostra
It may be assumed that יונה בן צרויה mentioned in yShab 5:1, 7b is the same, and see his name יונה בצרויה in Lev Rab 8:1, and see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1. F: – S: yKil 8:3, 31c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 395) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

4. O: – Ds: Tanḥum (26)’s father, of Bostra?
In Hebrew – ממצוצרא. This designation may refer to the City of Bostra, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 77-8. If it is Bostra, perhaps he is the same as the previous. F: – S: PesR tisa 8 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1244) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 9.

5. O: 
For the form  see vol. 1, under Yonah (3) B/M, p. 143. On the  suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.2, p. 11. Ds: Aconius (1), of Sepphoris
In Greek – On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Rome, Schneider Graziosi S: CIJ 362 E: –
The person is Jewish because the inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.5.3, pp. 46-7. D: 3rd- 4th C

6. O: 
This form is unknown from elsewhere, although its correctness is confirmed by its double appearance in the catacomb. I assume it is an abbreviated, kern form of this name, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Ds: – F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1012, 1018, 1021 S: 1. BS 2:1; 2. 2:7; 3. 2:9 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

7. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Jonah (3) B/M, p. 108. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She‘arim S: BS 2:215 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 15.

8. O: 
This is an alternative reading suggested by the editors. The main text has . On the form  see vol. 1, under Yonah (3) B/M, p. 143. On the interchange of with  as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. Ds: Aged 75
In Greek: () . On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, El-Al
In the Golan. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 50 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.2, p. 51. Note that the area were the inscription was found was not uniquely Jewish. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

9. O: 
See above, n. 8. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 48 E: – D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 13:2. Jonathan was King Saul’s son. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 9:1, 12d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 328-30) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: ינאי
For this form see vol. 1, under Jonathan (14) B/M, p. 144. Ds: Ishmael (3)’s son F: – S: yBer 9:2, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 439) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Isaac (12)’s son F: – S: yPea 5:1, 18d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His father was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.1, pp. 40-1 and Introduction 7.4.5.

4. O: – Ds: Joseph (20)’s son F: – S: yKil 2:6, 28a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

5. O: – Ds: Akhmai (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 11:5, 48b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: – Ds: Qaifa (1) F: – S: yMaas 5:3, 52a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

7. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: The minor
In Aramaic – זעירא. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.4, p. 33. F: – S: yShab 6:5, 8b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 439) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

8. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Ami (1)’s father-in-law F: – S: yEruv 10:10, 26c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: 3rd C
His son-in-law is mentioned in yTer 8:4, 46b in association with Queen Zenobia who reigned between 267-74, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Of Beth Govrin
In Aramaic – דבית-גוברין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 95-6. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yYom 7:3, 42b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 162) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Simon (3), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Joseph (43)’s father F: – S: yGit 9:7, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 396) E: Fictitious?
These names are given as examples for signitures on a document, and probably do not represent real people. D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: – Ds: Ḥali (1)’s son F: –– S: ySan 6:5, 23c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 259) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 36.

12. O: – Ds: Isaac (26)’s father F: – S: yNid 2:7, 50b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rav Huna (1) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 347, who died in 297, see Introduction 7.4.5.

13. O: רבנאי
This is the form ר' ינאי, see vol. 4, under Jonathan (1) B/M, p. 87 Ds: Ḥiyya (4)’s brother F: – S: bBer 21b
Although mentioned only in BT and only here, he is mentioned as a relative of a Palestinian rabbi, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1526) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
On his brother’s date see Introduction 7.4.2.

14. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Elder/Great
In Aramaic – סבא, as in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Oxford Opp. Add. fol 32 and the Vatican 134 Mss or רבא as in the Goettingen 3, the Munich 95 and the New York – Columbia X 893 T 141 Mss, and on this tradition see also Introduction 3.1.3.1.1. F: – S: bMeg 32a
He appears only in BT, here and in bNed 22a. In this tradition it is not clear whether he should not be identified with Jonathan (21) of vol. 1 (B/M, p. 145), here designated ינאי רבא (Yannai the Great), but in bNed 22a they are clearly differentiated, though both appear in the same Palestinian context, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 887) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

15. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Jonathan (14)’s grandson
On the identification of this person see above, n. 26. F: – S: bMeg 32a
Appears only here in BT, but in a Palestinian context, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 887) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 27.

16. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Ami (1)’s son F: – S: bHul 111a
Although only mentioned here in BT, he is described in this tradition as residing in Palestine (התם - there) and is the son of a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 887) E: – D: 3rd C
On his father’s dating see Introduction 7.4.1.

17. O: – Ds: Hagai (4)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 21:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 702) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Isaac (5), who was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see Introduction 7.4.5.

18. O: – Ds: Eleazar (29)’s son, governor of the castle
In Hebrew – שר הבירה. On a possible interpretation of this name see Introduction 3.1.3.3.1. F: – S: Gen Rab 95:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 701) E: – D: 3rd C
Samuel (3) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

19. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Ḥiyya (28)’s father F: – S: Est Rab 7:10 (Hyman, Toldoth, 446) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

20. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Simon (19)’s son F: – S: Eccl Rab 2:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, 766) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Abba (8), who was a contemporary of Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

21. O: ינאי
So in Pes Rab. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it. For this form see above, n. 3./זכאי
So in the parallel: Pes Rab 21, see previous note. For this form see vol. 1, under Zachariah (18) B/M, p. 91. This is probably a scribal error, or “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: Of Shab
In Aramaic – דשאב, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 596-7. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Pes Rab 14 (Hyman, Toldoth, 766) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

22. O: ינאי
See above, n. 3. Ds: Poet
In this composition Se‘adya Gaon explains the work of poets (אלשערא in Judeo-Arabic), and lists this one among them. And see also Introduction 3.1.3.6. F: – S: Saadia Gaon, Ha’egron 155 E: – D: 5th-7th C
Zulay, Eretz Israel, 165 dates him to the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.5.5.

23. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Jonathan (4) B/M, p. 109. On the interchange of the initial  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. Ds: Aurelius (2) Malkiah (4)’s father, of Eleutheropolis
In Greek – . This is Beit Govrin, situated west of Hebron. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Papyrus, Egypt S: P. Oxy. 3574 E: –
Jewishness indicated by name, and provenance, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1 and 6.8, p. 54. D: 314-18
The papyrus is internally dated according to the local governer, see Introduction 7.1.

24. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Jonathan (20) B/M, p. 109. Ds: Judah (64)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 900 E: – D: 3rd C

25. O: 
This name is completely corrupted. The use of  to transliterate the Hebrew יו is nowhere else recorded and the Greek suffix  for this name is also otherwise undocumented, but this is obviouslz the name intended.Ds: Ḥalafta (4)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 904 E: – D: 3rd C

26. O: 
Although no parallel exists, this is a reasonable Greek transliteration of the Hebrew ינאי. For this form see above. n. 3.Ds: Judah (66)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Schick S: CIJ 924 E: – D: 3rd C

27. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Jonathan (22) B/M, p. 110. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 11 S: BS 2:132 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

28. O: – Ds: Mariam (7)’s father, rabbi
In Hebrew – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:21 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 57.

29. O: 
See above, n. 53. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She’an, Tzori S: Roth-Gerson, GISEI, no. 7 E: – D: 6th C

30. O: יהונתן
For this form see vol. 1, under Jonathan (14) B/M, p. 144. Ds: Cantor
In Aramaic – חזנה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.2. F: Synagogue inscription, Ein-Gedi
In the Judaean Desert, west of the Dead Sea. S: Barag, AN 41-2 (1972) 36 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

31. O: – Ds: Elisheba (1)’s son F: Amulet, Nazareth?
The owner of the amulet reports that he found it in a field near Nazerath. S: Hamilton, JSS 41 (1996) 221 E: – D: 6th C

32. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Jonathan (14) B/M, p. 144. Ds: Joshua (34)’s father F: Sarcophagus lid, private collection S: Cotton, personal communication E: –
Jewishness indicated by son’s name see Introduction 6.2.2. D: –
See above, n. 64.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:24. יוסף was a son of Jacob. On the suggestion that it was also a name of a Hasmonean brother, see vol. 1, under Joseph B/M, p. 158, n. 20.

div.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Joseph (5) B/M, p. 150. Ds: Count
In Greek –  On this title see Introdution 3.1.3.4. F: – S: Epiphanius, PG 41, 409 E: Christian convert
He is described in this text as saying that he has become a Christian (    ). D: 306-37
Was active in during the reign of Constantine. There are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: ShutlaÎ (1)’s son, leader
On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 132 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

3. O: –
See above, n. 6. Ds: Saninah, priest
In the text – צנינה. Described in Hebrew as officiating as priest – כהן, see Introduction 3.3.2. F: – S: Tulida, 133 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 8. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 9.

4. O: يوسف
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. For this form see vol. 4, under Joseph (36) B/M, p. 89. Ds: Messenger to the Persian king
See below, n. 17. F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 132 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 8. D: 3rd C
Described in the text as visiting Ardashir King of Persia 545 years after Alexander. This would be sometime in the third century, and see Intoduction 3.2.2.

5. O: يوسي
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read יוסי. This may be a scribal “correction,” see the next two forms of the name and vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18./יצובו
So in Adler & Séligsohn, REJ 45 (1902) 90. I have no idea what this name is./יצובי
So according to Cohen, Chronicle, 15, see previous note. Ds: Sage
In Arabic – الحكيم. On this title see Introduction 3.3.3. F: – S: Abu’l-Fath, 141 E: Samaritan

51. O: יוסי
See above, n. 24. Ds: Joshua (14)’s son F: – S: yNid 3:2, 50d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, –
In Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 430-1 one is informed that any Joseph son of Joshua refers to Joseph (34) son of Joshua ben Levi (vol. 1, Joshua [25], p. 126) but the text here does not imply this. Hyman, Toldoth, 728 identified him as a separate person, also mentioned in bHul 56b and bNid 24a, but because he is cited by Rabbu Yohanan (1), he thought he was a tanna, i.e. too early for this volume. Yet he is only recorded in amoraic literature. ) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 67.

Transmits a tradition in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

He is probably also mentioned in the Vatican 487 Ms to bShab 116a. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 875) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

73. O: 
The initial editor suggested that this is the biblical name ישי, King David’s father, but there is no indication that the name was transcribed so in LXX or other Greek renditions of the Bible. Roth-Gerson, GISEI, p. 92, suggested that it is a Greek rendition of the variant איסי (see above, Joseph [23]). This is quite a straightforward transliteration, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11. On the interchange of with  as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. Ds: Abbin (28)’s son, of Tasele
In Greek – . I have no idea where this is. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 901 E: – D: 3rd C

80. O: יוסה
See above, n. 68. Ds: Benjamin (16)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Na‘aran,
North of Jericho. Vincent & Carrière S: CIJ 1202 E: – D: –

81. O: פסיו
The name is written in reverse order here. For this phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.6, p. 31. Ds: Aaron (3)’s son F: Epitaph, Jerusalem, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 1389 E: Late?
The inscription (on a marble plaque) is not typical of Second Temple Jerusalem, and at later times it is hardly likely to find Jewish tombs in Jerusalem. The inscription bears the marks of a late-antique Jewish epitaph similar to those found for example in Jaffa. How it made its way to Jerusallem’s rubbish heaps is unclear. Thus, some scholars assume it is medieval (as in CIIP 1/2, no. 881**). D: –
See previous note.

82. O: – Ds: Jacob (51)’s father F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem, Mayer, 1930 S: CIJ 1398 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

83. O: – Ds: Caleb (1)’s grandfather F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem, De Saulcy S: CIJ 1403 E: Late?
See above, n. 205. D: Pre-650?
See above, n. 205.

84. O: 
See above, n. 186. Ds: Tailor
In Greek – . On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Stamp, Sidon, Huezey S: IJO 3, Syr14 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name but a late date may indicate Christianity, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 183.

85. O: 
See above, n. 188. Ds: Abbomari (4)’s son
Rey-Coquais, Archéologie au Levant, 405, suggests identifying him with Joseph (74) found in the cemetery at Jaffa (CIJ 908). This idenitifaction is likely but not definite. F: Synagogue inscription, Ḥan Ḥalde,
South of Beirut and north of Sidon. Rey-Coquais S: IJO 3, Syr23 E: –
The inscription is a dedicatory inscription to a building. It includes biblical names, but is late and thus could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. L. Roth Gerson, “A Greek Inscription at Khan Khalde,” Zion 56 (1991) 193-200 (Hebrew) identified it as a synagogue inscription. Her arguments, however, are not decisive. In this case Jewishness is indicated by the form of the name, see Introduction 6.2.2.3. D: 605
The inscription is dated according to the era of the City of Beirut, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

86. O: 
In BS 1:40 the form יוסף is recorded. So in BS 2:19. For this form see above, n. 188./
So in BS 2:22. For this form see vol. 1, under Joseph (113) B/M, p. 153. Perhaps it is the vocative./
So in BS 2:23, 26, 32 and 33. For this form see above, n. 186. Ds: Isaac (47)’s father F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 996, 997, 998, 999, 1043, 1044 S: 1. BS 1:40; 2. 2:19; 3. 2:22; 4. 2:23; 5. 2:26; 6. 2:32; 7. 2:33 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

108. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Joseph (28) B/M, p. 151. On the interchange of the initial  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. On the interchange of  with  suffix in Greek orthography see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. Perhaps this is the vocative. Ds: Samuel (61)’s father F: List of citizens of Agraema inscription, Hauran
In Transjordan. S: Ewing, PEFQS 27 (1895) 139 E: Jew?
This list mentions many citizens. Although both father and son here seem to have Jewish names, this is not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52, and the Hauran was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
See above, n. 183.

109. O: – Ds: – F: Graffito, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 19 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is not possible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
See previous note.

110. O: יסא
See above, n. 27. Ds: Rabbi
In Armaic – רב[י]. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Sukenik, BIES 12 (1946) 63 E: – D: –
See above, n. 183.

See above, n. 191. S: Kedar, AN 11 (1964) 9 E: – D: –

See above, n. 183.

In Western Galilee. S: Lifschitz, RB 76 (1969) 94 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
See above, n. 183.

In Samaria. S: Tzori, EI 10 (1971) 240 E: Samaritan?
The location of the find suggests this, but see Introduction 6.1.5. D: –
See above, n. 183.

See above, n. 183.

In Greek – . The place is attested in Josephus and Ptolemaius, see Damati, ibid. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Damati, Atiqot 38 (1999) 91* E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on names mentioned in the inscription but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. Even though Tiberias was predominantly Jewish, it was also populated by many non-Jews, see Introduction 6.2.15. D: –
See above, n. 183.

124. O: יוסה
See above, n. 68. Ds: Awfi (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 24 E: Arabia?
In the inscription his death is described as follows: דגז בטפר מדינתה בארעהון דחמיראי ונפק לארעה דישראל ואקבר (who died in the City of Tafar in the Land of the Hamyarites and went forth to the Land of Israel and was buried). From this it is not clear whether he was a native of Palestine who was away and died abroad, or whether he was a Native of Himyar (Yemen) and was then buried in what was for him the Holy Land. D: 470
The inscription is dated to 400 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

See above, n. 68. Ds: Samuel (68), Jacob (76) and Menahem (19)’s father, rabbi, scribe

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. I do not understand why he chose to emend according to this complex version of the name and not a simpler one. Nevertheless, for this form see above, n. 117. Ds: Archon
In Hebrew characters – [אר]כון. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.1.2.2.5.3, p. 40. F: Seal, Lebanon?

Hagai (2), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:26. יעקב is the third Patriarch. On this name see Introduction 1.1.1.1.

div.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Jacob (7) B/M, p. 171. Ds: Jewish functionary
In Greek –  (a certain Jewish man, a functionary). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.4. F: – S: Epiphanius, PG 41, 25 E: – D: 315-403
Was a contemporary of Epiphanius of Salamis. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: ܝܥܩܘܒ
In Syriac script, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read יעקוב. For this form see vol. 1, under Jacob (42) B/M, p. 172. Ds: Christian dignitary?
In Syriac – ܒܗܢܐ ܙܒܢܐ ܡܬܝܕܥ (at the time [he] became known). These words are followed by a list of Christian officials such as Athanasius the patriarch of Antioch. But this Jacob has no such title, and instead he is designated ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (=Jew). Editors thought this is probably a mistake and refers to Jacob of Edessa, see Chronicon Anonymum Pseudo-Dionysianum (translation into French – Robert Hespel; Corpus Scriptorum Christianorum Orientalium 507; Scriptores Syrie 213), Louvan 1989, 111, n. 1 and Chabot, ibid. F: – S: Chabot, Chronicon Pseudo-Dionysianum 2, 149 E: Jew?
Described in the text as ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (=Jew), but see previous note. Perhaps in some Christian writings this is a derogatory description, see Introduction 6.2.3. D: 616
This is the date in which this information is inserted in the chronicle (928 of the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1).

3. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Jacob (1) B/M, p. 170. Ds: Newly baptized
In the title of the composition about his conversion –  (teachings of Jacob the newly baptized). F: – S: Doctrina Jacobi 1:12 E: Christian convert
This is the topic of this composition, see previous note. D: 7th C
On the dates see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).

In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Of Ischar
In Aramaic – דמן יסכר, perhaps identical with עין סוכר, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 480-1. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. leader
On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 127 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

Was a student of Joseph (28), who was Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

In Hebrew – איש כפר נבוריא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 352. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yBer 9:1, 12d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 441) E: Christian?

29. O: – Ds: Gurion (3)’s son F: – S: bEruv 62a
Although his son appears only in BT, and often (bEruv 62a; bTaan 29b; bMQ 18a; bKet 46a; bHul 101b) and in some mss bears the title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36) he is always described as sending his traditions (שלח – obviously from Palestine to Babylonia) in the name of the Palestinian Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 915) E: – D: 3rd C
Is the father of Isaac (29), who transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

30. O: – Ds: Simon (33)’s father, of Tyre
In Aramaic – דמן צור, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 531-33. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bBer 33a
Although mentioned only here and in bKet 7a in BT, his provenance is Syria (Tyre), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 956) E: –
Jewishness based on source in which he is mentioned, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.7, pp. 53-4. D: 3rd C
His son is a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

31. O: – Ds: The heretic
In Aramaic – מינאה. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.8, p. 34. F: – S: bAZ 28a
Mentioned three times in BT – bMeg 23a; bAZ 28a and bHul 84a – once in a Palestinian context (bAZ 28a) and twice conversing with Babylonian rabbis – Rav Judah (5), in vol. 4 B/M, p. 88 (bMeg 23a) and Rava (Abba [17] in vol. 4 B/M. p. 390) (bHul 84a). I consider it more likely that he was Palestinian, because (Christian) heretics were more common in Palestine, and because he may be confused with Jacob (16) in vol. 1, B/M, p. 171. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 895) E: Christian
See previous note. D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

The location of the find suggests this, but see Introduction 6.1.5. D: –
See above, n. 75.

69. O: 
See above, n. 102. Ds: Alexander (12)’s father F: Sarcophagus, Gilboa S: Lifschitz, RB 76 (1969) 92 E: Jew?
See above, n. 125. D: –
See above, n. 75.

70. O: 
For possibly this form see vol. 3, under Jacob (41) B/M, p. 122. Ds: Julianus (12)’s son F: Inscription, Caesarea S: Applebaum, Isaac & Landau, SCI 4 (1978) 136 E: Jew?
See above, n. 125. D: 3rd C

71. O: – Ds: Samuel (66)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 7 E: – D: 393
The inscription is dated to 323 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

72. O: – Ds: Saul (9)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 9 E: – D: 408
The inscription is dated to 338 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

73. O: – Ds: Avid (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Stern, Tarbiz 68 (1999) no. 16 E: – D: 476
The inscription is dated to 406 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

74. O: – Ds: Simon (77)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 20 E: – D: 416
The inscription is dated to 346 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

75. O: 
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Greek. The Hebrew has יעקב. On this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Hesychius (5)’s son F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh & Ustinova, Atiqot 49 (2005)113*, 117* E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

76. O: – Ds: Joseph (125)’s son, scribe
In Aramaic – ספרה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh, Atiqot 49 (2005) 114* E: – D: 3rd-4th C

77. O: יע[קב]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jerusalem S: Shukron & Reich, HA 117 (2005) E: Late?
The excavator thought the inscription should be dated to the early Arabic period D: 7th C

78. O: – Ds: Nehorai (4)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

79. O: – Ds: Nehorai (4)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
See above, n. 160. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
I See above, n. 161. E: – D: 4th-7th C

80. O: – Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 11 E: Late?
There is no way to date the Hebrew inscriptions from Elijah’s Cave, see Appendix 3.1. D: Pre-8th C?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:32. יפת was one of Noah’s three sons.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Benjamin (4)’s father F: – S: yBer 6:1, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153) E: Nickname?
Despite the fact that this is biblical name, it is so unusual, that it may, in this case, be considered a nickname. On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:19. יצחק is the second Patriarch, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.

div.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Isaac (3) B/M, p. 174. Ds: Of Akko
In Greek – . On such designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Doctrina Jacobi 4:5 E: –
Described as  (godfearing Jew). D: 7th C
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).

2. O: eisak
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . On this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (54) B/M. p. 129. Ds: – F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril, ECASS, no. 168 E: Samaritan
In Coptic – mpeisamariths, see Introduction 6.1.1.; convert to Christianity
The entire composition is devoted to his conversion, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.6.3, p. 32. D: 313-86
Was a contemporary of Cyril of Jerusalem. These are his dates.

3. O: – Ds: Nahmani (2)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Eleazar (10)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 131-2) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 2:3, 4c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 443-5) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see Introduction 7.4.5.

6. O: – Ds: Seḥora (2) F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 445) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Isaac (27), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Ahi (6)’s father F: – S: yBer 4:3, 8a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: – Ds: Abdimi (11)’s son; the Great
In Aramaic – רובא. On such designation see Introduction 3.1.3.1. Because he is so designated only in PT, while in BT he is designated רב יצחק בר אבדימי, I mistakenly assumed in vol. 4 that he is a separate sage, and listed him under Isaac (12) B/M, p. 96. F: – S: yBer 5:2, 9b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 445) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 10.

9. O: – Ds: Hananiah (12)’s father F: – S: yBer 6:5, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 275-6) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Samuel (9), who was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Abba (17)’s son F: – S: yBer 6:6, 10d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a student of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), see Introduction 7.4.5.

11. O: – Ds: Elyashib (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 7:1, 11a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 110) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

12. O: – Ds: Ḥaqula (1)’s son
BT identifies him with Isaac (5), see Hyman Toldoth, 787-8, but the PT and the Palestinian sources do not. F: – S: yPea 1:1, 16b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 285) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 10.

13. O: – Ds: Of Attushiya
In Aramaic – עטושיא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 471. On such designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yPea 8:4, 20d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 254) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Simon (1), who was the companion of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

14. O: – Ds: Ṭavla (1)’s son F: – S: yDem 2:1, 22d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 288) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (10) see Introduction 7.4.1.

15. O: – Ds: Redifa (2)’s son F: – S: yShevi 9:4, 39a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: –
He is mentioned in four traditions. In three of them, two of them Palestinian and one Babylonian (yShevi 9:4, 39a; ySheq 4:2, 48a; bKet 106a) he is designated with the Palestinian title רבי and is found in association with Palestinian rabbis. In another Babylonian tradition (bShab 23b) he bears the Babylonian title רב and transmits a tradition in the name of a Babylonian rabbi (רב הונא – Huna [1] S-H/M in vol. 4, p. 347). However, the earlier Palestinian traditions seem more reliable, and contra Hyman, Toldoth, 798. D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: – Ds: Gufti (1)’s son F: – S: yMaas 1:4, 49b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 164) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Mana (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s contemporary, see Introduction 7.4.1.

17. O: – Ds: Bisna (1)’s son F: – S: yMaas 1:5, 49b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 148) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 26.

18. O: – Ds: Marion (2)’s son F: – S: yShab 2:6, 5b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 445) E: – D: 4th C
Transmits a tradition in the name of Simon (2) ben Laqish (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

19. O: – Ds: Orion (1)’s son F: – S: yShab 10:6, 12d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 64) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporay of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

20. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (13)’s son F: – S: yPes 1:8, 28b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

21. O: – Ds: Qaṣaṣtah (1)’s son F: – S: yRhSh 1:1, 56b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

22. O: – Ds: Istiaius (1)’s son F: – S: yYev 1:1, 2c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97-8) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits a tradition in the name of Simon (2) ben Laqish (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion. See Introduction 7.4.1.

23. O: – Ds: Abba (33)’s father F: – S: yYev 12:1, 12c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 14) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

24. O: – Ds: Eleazar (22)’s son F: – S: yBB 8:1, 16a
So only in the Escorial Ms (ר' אלעזר אבוי דר' יצחק, ר' יצחק בר נחמן). In the Leiden Ms the two Eleazars are combined. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 40) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 10.

25. O: – Ds: Mataniah (2)’s son F: – S: yAZ 3:13, 43b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 24.

26. O: – Ds: Jonathan (12)’s son F: – S: yNid 2:7, 50b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Rav Huna (1) S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 347, who died in 297, see Introduction 745.

27. O: – Ds: Blacksmith
In Aramaic – נפחא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: bBer 41a
Though he appears only in BT, there is no doubt that this rabbi (designated always רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2), was Palestinian, see Hyman, Toldoth, 800-2. Hyman wanted to identify him with יצחק בר טבלאי – Isaac (14), but he has no solid proof for this. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 909-11) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Resh Laqish (Simon[2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

28. O: – Ds: Ze‘ira (11)’s son F: – S: 1. bShab 20b; 2. Gen Rab 63:12 (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 909) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 34.

29. O: – Ds: Jacob (29)’s son F: – S: bEruv 62a
Although he appears only in BT, and often (bEruv 62a; bTaan 29b; bMQ 18a; bKet 46a; bHul 101b) and in some mss bears the title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 37) he is always described as sending his traditions (שלח – obviously from Palestine to Babylonia) in the name of the Palestinian Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 915) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

30. O: – Ds: Phineas (10)’s son F: – S: bPes 114a
Appears only in BT, here and in bHul 27b (and also in bQid 71a, but not in the Vilna print, where his name has been skipped), but I assume he is Palestinian because he is always designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, because in bPes 114a he is designated דאגדתא (he who transmits aggadah, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6) and in bQid 71 he is described within the context of the Palestinian study house. Hyman, Toldoth, 782-4 argues that he is the person designated simply Isaac (5) in PT, but he has no proof for this, and Isaac (5) is probably Ahi (7)’s son. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 919) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

31. O: – Ds: Of Magdala
In Aramaic – מגדלאה. see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 396-7. On such designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: 1. bYom 81b; 2. Gen Rab 5:9 (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 909) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

32. O: – Ds: Of Kfar Akko
In Hebrew – איש כפר עכו, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 488-92, under עכו. On such designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bAZ 7b
Although mentioned only in BT, his Palestinian origin is indicated by provenance, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 909) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 44.

33. O: – Ds: Ḥalbo (2)’s son F: – S: bHul 99b
Although this is the only tradition in which he is mentioned, he bears the distinct Palestinian title רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2), and is mentioned in association with other Palestinian rabbis, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 915) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

34. O: – Ds: Tobiah (6)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 40:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 523) E: Fictitious
This figure could be a literary invention, since the text runs: ר' טוביה בר' יצחק אמר: שני אהלים רות המואביה ונעמה העמונית. דכוותה "קום קח את אשתך ואת שתי בנותיך הנמצאות" (בראשית יט טו). ר' טוביה אמר: שתי מציאות רות ונעמה. אמר ר' יצחק: "מצאתי דוד עבדי" (תהלים פט כא). איכו מצאתיו? בסדום. “Rabbi Tobiah son of Rabbi Isaac said: Two tents – Ruth the Moabite and Naama the Amonite. And likewise: “Arise and take your two daughters found here” (Gen 19:15). Rabbi Tobiah said: Two found – Ruth and Naama. Rabbi Isaac said: “I have found my slave David” (Ps 89:21). Where have I found him? In Sodom.” Since in the the introductory passage there are two names mentioned as father and son, and further down two rabbis by these same two names are mentioned, perhaps there really was no such sage with a combined name, and this is merely a literary combination. D: 3rd C
See above, n. 48.

35. O: – Ds: Simon (39)’s son F: – S: Lam Rab 1:30 (Hyman, Toldoth, 797) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 48.

36. O: – Ds: Of Piskat
In Aramaic – פסאקא . In the Buber edition – פסיקא. In Gen Rab 85:4 this place is identified with גזיב, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 174-6. On such designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Lam Rab 1:36 (Hyman, Toldoth, 802) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 31.

37. O: – Ds: Huna (7)’s father F: – S: PesR 40 (Hyman, Toldoth, 353) E: – D: 3rd C
Joshua (9), who transmits in his son’s name, was a contemporary of Judah (15), whose father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

38. O: – Ds: Menahem (13)’s son F: – S: Midrash Tehilim 34:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 796) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 34.

39. O: – Ds: Physician
Is cited as an authority on a medical substance in the Book of Assaph the Physician, see Introduction 5.1.4.2. F: – S: Muntner, Assaph, 157 E: Proselyte
In Hebrew – גר צדק. D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

40. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (9) B/M, p. 128. On the replacement of  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. Ds: Elder
In Greek – <> (of the most pious of elders) On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3, p. 41. F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea/Syria, Mayence S: CIJ 803 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: 391
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

41. O: 
See above, n. 64. Ds: Hilasius (2)’s father F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea/Syria, Mayence S: CIJ 804 E: –
See above, n. 66. D: 391
See above, n. 67.

42. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (8) B/M, p. 128. Ds: Goldsmith
In Greek – (). On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Donation inscription, Ain-Mousa,
In the Hauran in Transjordan. Waddington S: CIJ 865 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but the date makes it equally likely that it is Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. IJO 3, App12 did not include it in its corpus. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

43. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (24) B/M, p. 128. On the interchange of the initial  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. On the Greek suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11. Ds: Benjamin (14)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 912 E: – D: 3rd C

44. O: 
See above, n. 6. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 927 E: – D: 3rd C

45. O: 
See above, n. 64. Ds: Simon (49)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 955 E: – D: 3rd C

46. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Isaac (1) B/M, p. 174. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Gaza, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 968 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
See above, n. 75.

47. O: 
In BS 1:40 – יצחק. So in BS 2:23. For this form see above, n. 64. /
So in BS 2:36. For this form see vol. 1, under Isaac (11) B/M, p. 174. Ds: Joseph (86)’s son, barabbi
In Aramaic – ביריבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 998, 1042, 1047 S: 1. BS 1:40; 2. 2:23; 3. 2:36 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

48. O: – Ds: Joseph (89)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1052 S: BS 1:50 E: – D: Pre-352
See previous note.

49. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Isaac (1) B/M, p. 174. On the interchange of the initial  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. Ds: Caridius (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1031 S: BS 2:16 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

50. O: 
See above, n. 83. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1060 S: BS 2:47 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

51. O: 
See above, n. 83. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1089 S: BS 2:71 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

52. O: 
See above, n. 83. Ds: Tuta (1)’s son F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1096, 1097 S: BS 2:76, 77 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

53. O: 
See above, n. 83. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1099 S: BS 2:80 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

54. O: 
See above, n. 6. Ds: Lollianus (7)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 2, CIJ 1101 S: BS 2:82 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

55. O: 
See above, n. 6. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 3, CIJ 1106 S: BS 2:84 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

56. O: 
See above, n. 79. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1122 S: BS 2:98 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

57. O: 
On the form  see vol. 1, under Isaac (3) B/M, p. 175. On the Greek suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.1, p. 11. Ds: Anastasius (2)’s son, Samuel (49)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1123 S: BS 2:99 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

58. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Samuel (50)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1128 S: BS 2:105 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

59. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (24) B/M, p. 128. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She‘arim S: BS 2:209 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

60. O: 
For this form see above, n. 107. On the interchange of the initial  with  see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.4, p. 11. Ds: Ze‘ira (13)’s son F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 25 S: BS 2:220 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 85.

61. O: יצח[ק]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov,
South of Beth She’an. Vitto S: Naveh, OSM, no. 48 E: – D: –
See above, n. 75.

62. O: – Ds: Judah (101)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Sepphoris S: Weiss, Sepphoris Synagogue, no. 3 E: – D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

63. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (9) B/M, p. 128. On the interchange of with  as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. Ds: – F: Memorial inscription, Hammat Gader S: Di Segni, Hammat Gader, no. 8 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 5th-6th C

64. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Isaac (5) B/M, p. 127-8. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Hebron?
The inscription comes from the antiquities market. The man who produced this inscription claimed that it comes from a place associated with Abraham. Mordtmann understood this to refer to Hebron. S: Mordtmann, ZDPV 12 (1889) 132 E: Jew?
This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but it could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 75.

65. O: – Ds: Shemayah (3)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 25 E: – D: 505
The inscription is dated to 435 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

66. O: 
See above, n. 6. Ds: Qozon (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa S: Price, SCI 22 (2003) 218 E: – D: 3rd C?
The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them, see Introduction 5.2.2.1. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, it is correct for this one as well.

67. O: סחק
For the form אסחק see vol. 4, under Isaac (36) B/M, p. 97. This seems to be a late-antique linguistic development see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.1, pp. 12. On the fall of the initial א as a Palestinian-Aramaic linguistic phenomenon see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29. Ds: Nahum (16)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Katzrin
In the Golan. S: Yardeni, personal communication E: – D: –
See above, n. 75.

68. O: 
See above, n. 71. Ds: – F: Bread stamp, Hecht Museum, Haifa S: –
The stamp is decorated with a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35. E: – D: –
See above, n. 75.

69. O: – Ds: Komah (1)’s son F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 37 E: Late?
There is no way to date the Hebrew inscriptions from Elijah’s Cave, see Appendix 3.1. D: Pre-8th C?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 8:19.

div.p:
1. O: אליקים
So in BT, see Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1686. For this name see under Elyakim B/M. Ds: Simon (10)’s father F: – S: yPea 7:1, 20a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 449-50) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: יקום
On the interchange of the letters י and ו see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.1, p. 18. Ds: Ashyan (4)’s father F: – S: yYeb 11:7, 12a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 142) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: – Ds: – F: – S: Exod Rab 42:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 803) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 27:1. ירמיה was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Abba (4)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 14-5) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yonah (2) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 3b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 455-64) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Scribe
In Aramaic – ספרא. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Jeremiah (2), see above, n. 3.

4. O: – Ds: Tanḥum (7)’s father F: – S: yBer 7:3, 11c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

5. O: – Ds: Kahana (5)’s father F: – S: yOrl 3:3, 63a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Samuel (1) B/M, in vol. 4, p. 125, who died in 253, see Introduction 7.4.5.

6. O: – Ds: Ze‘ira (4)’s son
This is a long story. At the beginning רבי זעירא (Ze‘ira [4]) and a certain ר' ירמיה are seated together. This could be Jeremiah (2). In the end of the episode we read אמר רבי זעירה ... ירמיה בני (Said Rabbi Ze‘ira: … Jeremiah my son …). This could be interpreted as a condescending epithet, but it could imply a real family relationship, in which case this is another Jeremiah. F: – S: yMaas 3:10, 51a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 5.

7. O: – Ds: Simon (18)’s son F: – S: yShab 4:3, 7a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

8. O: – Ds: Eleazar (15)’s son F: – S: yShab 6:9, 8d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 132) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

9. O: – Ds: Meyasha (3)’s father F: – S: yNaz 9:3, 57d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

10. O: – Ds: Hezekiah (3)’s father F: – S: yQid 1:7, 61a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

11. O: – Ds: Taḥlifa (6)’s son F: – S: bYom 78a
Although mentioned only in BT, he is always mentioned in association with Palestinian rabbis, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3, and bears the title רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 935-6) E: – D: Pre-400
He is mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

12. O: – Ds: Shemayah (1)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 93:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 815) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

13. O: – Ds: Phineas (11)’s father F: – S: Lev Rab 10:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, –) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

14. O: – Ds: Joseph (58)’s father F: – S: S of S Rab 1:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 732) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 6.

15. O:
This is a form of this name in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 81. Ds: Joseph (120)’s son, Kolokasius
In Greek – . This is probably a nickname and a reference to a plant common in Palestine and known as לוף in rabbinic literature or “arum” in English. F: Epitaph S: Schwartz, JQR 80 (1989) 91 E: –
Jewishness indicated by the form of his father’s name, see Introduction 6.2.2. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

16. O: – Ds: Gedaliah (2)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount S: Ben-Dov, Shadow of the Temple, 334 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:11. ישמעאל was Abraham’s first-born, rejected son see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1, pp. 5-6.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Of Luza, leader
In Hebrew – מלוזה. On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 126 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: – Ds: Judah (13)’s father
A. Marmorstein, “About the Inscription of Judah ben Ishmael,” PEFQS 59 (1927) 101-2 suggests identifying him with Ishmael (11). On such identifications, however, see vol. 1, Introduction 3.3, pp. 34-6. F: – S: yBer 4:2, 7d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 321) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Jonathan (2)’s father F: – S: yBer 9:2, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 439) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Ulla (2)’s father F: – S: yDem 1:1, 21c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 470) E: – D: 3rd C
See previous note.

5. O: – Ds: Berrabbi
In Aramaic – בי רבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: – S: yBes 1:7, 60c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 469) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 7.

6. O: – Ds: Joshua (13)’s son F: – S: yYeb 7:6, 8b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 469) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 7.

7. O: – Ds: Eleazar (20)’s father F: – S: yNaz 6:2, 55a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 109) E: Fictitious?
Hyman, Toldoth, 185, claims there is no such person, because in his appearance in yTer 11:2, 47d, the text which runs: לעזר ביה ר' ישמעאל should be read לעזר בשם ר' ישמעאל. However, he does not refer to the text here, which runs רבי ליעזר בן ישמעאל. Nevertheless, because both texts refer beforehand to the tanna Rabbi Yishmael (Ishmael [4] B/M. in vol. 1, p. 177), he may be correct, and no such person exists. D: Pre-400
See above, n. 7.

8. O: שמואל
So in the printed editions. In the mss ישמעאל. For this name see under Samuel B/M.This could be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. Ds: The Elder,
In Aramaic – סבא. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33. Hananiah’s
In vol. 4, under Hananiah (2) B/M, p. 75. son-in-law F: – S: bBer 62b
Although he appears only here in BT, he is related to a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1629) E: – D: 3rd C
His father-in-law was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Of Kfar Yamma/Yoma/Ma/Yadma/Dima
In Hebrew – איש כפר ימא/יומא/מה/דימא/ידמ', see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 338, 347-8. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bKet 57b
Although mentioned only here in BT, his provenance indicates his Palestinian origin, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 937) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Ami (12)’s son F: – S: Lev Rab 1:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 829) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 7.

11. O: ישמעל
For this form see vol. 1, under Ishmael (11) B/M, p. 177. Ds: Judah (69)’s father
See above, n. 6. F: Synagogue inscription, Chorazin, Ory S: CIJ 981 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
