note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezr 8:7. ישעיהו was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book.

div.p:
1. O: Iaisati
In the Vulgate this prophet is sometimes (but not always) designates Isaias. The editor must have understood this as the same name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.3, p. 51. Ds: Nonnus (4)’s father, the Syrian
In Latin – SuroOn such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Dedicatory inscription, Italy, Diehl S: CIJ 92* E: Christian?
The name and provenance (Syria) made editors consider it Jewish, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.8, p. 54, but both are inconclusive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 32:29. ישראל is the second name given by God to Jacob.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Makhir (1)’s son, leader
On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 131 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: [י]שראל
The reconstruction is ours, but it seem certain. Ds: Reuben (6)’s son F: Graffito, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 10 E: Late?
There is no way to date the Hebrew inscriptions from Elijah’s Cave, see Appendix 3.1. D: Pre-8th C?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:18. יששכר was a son of Jacob, and one of the tribes of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Of Kfar Mandi
In Aramaic – דכפר מנדי, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 350-1. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yRhSh 1:3, 57a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 471) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Hananiah (5), who was a student of the Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 4:18. יתרו was the name of Moses’ father-in-law.

div.p:
1. O: 
The editor identified this as this biblical name. However, this is not how it is transliterated in LXX, or in other Greek translations, and it was not a common name Jews used, so it is hard to decide whether the editor’s suggestion is correct. Ds: Tino (2)’s son, guardian of the orphans
In Greek – . On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.4. F: Epitaph, Lod
East of Tel Aviv. S: Schwabe, Tarbiz 12 (1941) 230 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. The editor suggested that the title too was Jewish, but there is no evidence that this title was reserved to jews rather than Christians or Samaritans. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Num 13:6. כלב was one of the spies Moses sent to inspect Canaan.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Joseph (84)’s son, Yohanan (17)’s grandson, deceased
In Hebrew – ננ (short for נוח נפש – may his soul rest). This very common acronym is not known from antiquity, and see next note. F: Inscription, Temple Mount, De Saulcy S: CIJ 1403 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See Introdution 7.5.6 and previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Levi (7) B/M, p. 182. Ds: Of the Phiale quarter (in Akko)
In Greek – . The identification of this place is suggested by the editor. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Doctrina Jacobi 5:6 E: – D: 7th C
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).

2. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Zayt (2)’s father F: – S: Tulida, 136 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introduction 7.2.3.

3. O: –
See above, n. 5. Ds: Sage, priest
In Arabic – الحكيم ... كاهن. On these titles see Introduction 3.3.2 and 3.3.3. F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 141 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 6. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 7.

4. O: –
See above, n. 5. Ds: Bebai (1)’s nephew F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 151 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 6. Christain convert; fictitious
In this text we are informed how this Samaritan pretended to convert to Christianity and then fooled the Byzantine church. Abu’l Fath says he read this story in a Jewish chronicle. It is obviously a completely legendary episode. But of course Baba Rabba may have had a nephew named Levi. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 7.

5. O: –
See above, n. 5. Ds: Bebai (1)’s son F: S: Abu’l Fath, 158 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 6. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his son.

6. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 483-5) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Sosias (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 485-6) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits traditions in the name of Rabbi Judah the Patriarch (Judah [36] B/M, in vol. 1, p. 113), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: – Ds: Nazira (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:1, 4b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 485) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

9. O: ליואי
So in yAZ 2:9, 42a. For this form see vol. 4, under Levi (2) B/M, p. 102. Ds: Benjamin (5)’s father F: – S: yPea 1:1, 15a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 153) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Zebadi (5) and Shalman (1)’s father F: – S: yDem 7:1, 26a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 3rd C
His sons transmit in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: – Ds: Of Ṣenaberi
In Aramaic – צנבריא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 547-8. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yShevi 6:2, 36d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 485) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: – Ds: Ḥana (3)’s son F: – S: yTer 4:3, 42d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 257) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

13. O: – Ds: Pelatyah (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 10:10, 47b
On this chain of tradition see Introduction 5.1.3.1.1. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 486) E: –D: 3rd C
Judah (15), whose father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

14. O: – Ds: Ḥayuta (1)’s son F: – S: yShab 6:9, 8d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 256) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

15. O: – Ds: Judah (29)’s father F: – S: yShab 7:2, 10c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 321-2) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: – Ds: Of Sokho
In Aramaic – סוכיא, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 450-1. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yEruv 10:2, 26a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 485) E: – D: 3rd C
Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

17. O: – Ds: Innkeeper
In the text פונדקא דלוי (Levi’s hostel). On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: ySheq 7:2, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 485) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

18. O: – Ds: Hanan (5)’s father F: – S: yBes 4:1, 62b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

19. O: – Ds: Paṭi (1)’s son F: – S: yMeg 3:7, 74b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 486) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

20. O: – Ds: Birai (1)’s son F: – S: yBB 5:1, 15a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 149) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

21. O: – Ds: LaÎma (1)’s son F: – S: bSuk 47a
Even though he is only mentioned here in BT, he is designated in all texts by the Palestinian title רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 980) E: – D: 3rd C
Is associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

22. O: – Ds: Zachariah (7)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 15 (Hyman, Toldoth, 858) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

23. O: – Ds: Barachiah (6)’s son
In the parallel Tanhuma (Warsaw edition) behuqotai 5 the transmitter is ר' זכריה. Perhaps this refers to Zachariah (6). F: – S: TanB, behuqotai 7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 858) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

24. O: – Ds: Ḥ̣alafta (3)’s son, the priest
In Hebrew – הכהן. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. F: – S: TanB, va-yira 25 (Hyman, Toldoth, 859) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 21.

25. O: 
This the way this name is spelt in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 101. Ds: Hezekiah (9)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 911 E: – D: 3rd C

26. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Levi (7) B/M, p. 182. Ds: Zoilus (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 917 E: – D: 3rd C

27. O: – Ds: Joseph (77)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Bar‘am-Alma,
In Upper Galilee. Renan S: CIJ 974 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

28. O: – Ds: Shalum (4)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Meron
See above, n. 48. (Samuel Bar Simson 1210) S: CIJ 978 E: – D: –
See above, n. 49.

29. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Levi (7) B/M, p. 182. Ds: of Esia
In Greek – . Biblical Ezion-Geber, according to the editors. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim catacomb 8, CIJ 1151, 1152 S: BS 2:119 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

30. O: לווי
So in BS 3:6. In BS 3:5 – לוי. On the double ו as a consonant, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Judah (87)’s father F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 13 S: 1. BS 3:5; 2. 3:6 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 54.

31. O: לווי
See above, n. 57. Ds: Joshua (25)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:24 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 54.

32. O: לווי
See above, n. 57. Ds: Hillel (9)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:28 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 54.

33. O: – Ds: Asher (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Naveh
In the Bashan (Transjordan south of the Golan). (Samuel Bar Simson 1210) S: Naveh, OSM, no. 36 E: – D: –
See above, n. 49.

34. O: 
This form is strange and not recorded elsewhere. It may actually be the Latin Livius, see WGE 808, under . This here could be the form Livus, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.4, p. 19. Ds: Euelpis (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 290 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, see Introduction 6.2.2. If however, this is not the name intended, (see previous note), there is no reason to view the inscription as Jewish. D: –
See above, n. 49.

35. O: – Ds: Joshua (34)’s father
Not identical with Levi (31). Perhaps identical with Levi (15) B/M, in vol. 1, p. 183, and see above, n. 49. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Aviam & Amitai, Cathedra 141 (2011) no. 13 E: – D: 2nd-4th C

36. O: הלוי
On names with the definite article ה prefix see vol. 1, Appendix, pp. 445-8. In this case it could be a title rather than a name, but the absence of a name next to the title makes this unlikely. On Arabic names with the definite article prefix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.5.1, p. 15. Ds: Pelatyah (3)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, Jer 32:12.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Abba (17)’s father F: – S: yBer 6:6, 10d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22) E: – D: 3rd C
His grandson (Isaac [10]) was a student of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247, see Introduction 7.4.5.

2. O: מחסיא
So in some of the mss e.g. Munich 95; New York – JTS Rab. 1623\2 (EMC 271); Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 etc. but not in all. On this form see vol. 4, under Mahsiah (2) B/M, p. 103. Ds: Ada (17)’s son F: – S: bYom 2a
Although he appears only in BT and only here and in bYom 3a, his Palestinian provenance is indicated by his designation (רבי), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and he transmits a tradition in the name of the Palestinian sage, Rabbi Yohanan (1), and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1015) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits a tradition in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, 1 Chr 8:9.

div.p:
1. O: מיישא
On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 519) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: מיישא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Simon (23)’s father F: – S: yMeg 1:12, 72d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 519) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Eleazar (8), who was associated with the general Ursicinus, see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: מיישא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Jeremiah (9)’s son F: – S: yNaz 9:3, 57d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: מיישא
See above, n. 2. Ds: Joshua’s
This is Joshua (25) B/M in vol. 1, p. 126. grandson F: – S: yBer 2:3, 4c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 342) E: – D: 3rd C
His grandfather is of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: מיאשה
On the additional א as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3, pp. 13. Ds: Judah (89)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:22 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 50:23.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Israel (1)’s father F: – S: Tulida, 131 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Ṣavo (1)’s father F: – S: Tulida, 135 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 3. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 9:12. In vol. 1, (מלכה) S-H/M, pp. 390-1 and in vol. 3 (מלכא) S-H/M, pp. 674-7, I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In this volume, as in vol. 4, it shows up once, so I recorded the name under biblical names.

div.p:
1. O: מלך
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On such kern forms see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. Ds: Priest, of the clan of Ithamar
On these see Introduction 3.3.2.2. F: S: Tulida 124 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: – Ds: Kahana (3)’s father F: S: yBer 6:1, 10b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 474) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rav (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in 247, see Introduction 7.4.5.

3. O: מלוך
On such kern forms see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. The additional ו is probably an indication of a pronounciation based on dialect, see vol. 4, Introoduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13. Ds: – F: – S: ySuk 3:1, 53c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 519) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: 
See above, n. 9. Ds: Aurelius (2), Jonathan (23)’s son, of Beth Govrin
In Greek – . On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Papyrus, Egypt S: P. Oxy. 3574 E: –
Jewishness indicated by name, and provenance, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1 and 6.8, p. 54. D: 314-18
The papyrus is internally dated according to the local governer.

5. O: 
On this form see vol. 1, under Malka (2) S-H/M, p. 390. Ds: Merchant
In Greek – . On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Epitaph, Tyre,
In Lebanon. Fröhner S: CIJ 881 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

6. O: 
The consonants in this name are the same, but the vowels are completely different from those in other forms of the name here. With these vowels the name would be pronounced like the name of the despised biblical idol Molech (e.g. Jer 32:35). If this is indeed the name intended here, this makes the likelyhood that he is Jewish smaller. Ds: Gelasius (3)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 76 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1, but see previous note. D: 395
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

7. O: 
On this form see vol. 3, under Malka (6) S-H/M, p. 674. Ds: Sheila (10)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 275 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 4th-6th C
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.

8. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Demetrius (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1b, no. 4 E: Jew?
See above, n. 22. D: 356
See above, n. 20.

9. O: 
See above, n. 9. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 38 E: Jew?
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

10. O: מלך
See above, n. 2. Ds: Guzu (1)’s son F: Amulet, Private Collection S: MSF no. 21 E: – D: –
See above, n. 17.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. מנחם was the one before last king of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Eleazar (7)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 128) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yPea 6:4, 19c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 530) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Hagai (2), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: – Ds: Judah (29)’s son F: – S: yDem 5:8, 24d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 530) E: – D: 4th C
His father was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: – Ds: Mavsima (1)’s son, Jonathan (6)’s brother F: – S: yMaas 5:3, 52a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 330) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

5. O: מנחמה
On the ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26. Ds: – F: – S: yShab 14:3, 14c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 530) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S/H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in this year, see Introduction 7.4.5.

6. O: – Ds: Of Yotapata
In Aramaic – יותפייה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen 293-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: ySuk 4:6, 54c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 434) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Gurion (2)’s brother F: – S: yBM 9:8, 12a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

8. O: – Ds: The cake-baker
In Aramaic – טלמא. See Jastrow, DTTBYML, 524. F: – S: ySan 2:6, 20c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 292) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: מנחמא
On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26. Ds: Ze‘ira (12)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 34:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 893) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

10. O: – Ds: Eleazar (9)’s son-in-law F: – S: Lev Rab 35:1(Hyman, Toldoth, 892) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Judah (8), who was a student of Samuel (3), transmits in his father-in-law’s name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

11. O: מנחמן
On the ן suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. Ds: – F: – S: S of S Rab 2:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 893) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

12. O: – Ds: Jacob (34)’s son F: – S: PesR tisa 69 (Hyman, Toldoth, 891) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

13. O: – Ds: Isaac (38)’s father F: – S: Midrash Tehilim 34:2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 796) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

14. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Menahem (1) B/M, p. 185. Ds: Amos (2)’s father F: Epitaph, Haifa, Heuzey S: CIJ 883 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

15. O: 
On the form  see vol. 1, under Menahem (1) B/M, p. 185. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. The fall of the  may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. Ds: Matrona (2)’s husband F: Column inscription, Ashkelon, Sukenik S: CIJ 965 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. Also, this could have been another name. D: –
See above, n. 22.

16. O: – Ds: Su‘am (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Nazareth, Dalman S: CIJ 988 E: – D: –
See above, n. 22.

17. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Other names may also be considered. On this sort of abbreviation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.3, pp. 19-20. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1048 S: BS 2:37 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

18. O: 
On the form  see vol. 1, under Menahem (1) B/M, p. 185. The replacement of the  with the  may be interpreted as a scribal error (see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20), or a pronounciation variant (see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3). Ds: Joseph (101)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Gaza, Avi-Yonah S: Roth-Gerson, GISEI, no. 21 E: – D: 508
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gaza, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.
19. O: – Ds: Joseph (125)’s son F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh, Atiqot 49 (2005)114* E: – D: 3rd-4th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה is Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: מנישא
On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, pp. 11. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. Ds: Joseph (31)’s father F: – S: ySuk 3:1, 53c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 431) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S/H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in this year, see Introduction 7.4.5.

2. O: – Ds: Judah (37)’s father F: – S: yTaan 2:1, 65a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son is a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

3. O: 
The name of the King מנשה is spelt in the Aquilla translation as , see H & R Suppl. 112. On the interchange of  with  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. The interchange of  and  represents a dialect variant, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3.Ds: Abba (53)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Vincent S: CIJ 941 E: – D: 3rd C

4. O: מניסס
This is the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2. Ds: Rabbi
In Jewish characters – רב. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Sukenik, BIES 12 (1946) 64 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

5. O: 
In this form this is also a Greek name, see WGE, 934. Ds: Candida (1)’s husband?
Although he is not designated her husband, they appear together in one inscription in the Elijah’s Cave, where often family members are listed together. F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 15 E: Jew?
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 12:5.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: His son
In the text – רבי בן מעדיה. F: – S: yDem 2:1, 22c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 431) E: Nickname?
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:1. מרדכי was Queen Esther’s uncle.

div.p:
1. O: [מ]רדכי
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Negev, RB 78 (1971) 248 E: Name?
According to the editors of CIIP 2, 1610, the inscription reads דרבי (of the rabbi) and is thus no name at all. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:10. משה was the great leader of the Exodus.

div.p:
1. O: מוסיא
So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Munich 6, the Munich 95, the New York JTS Rab 1623\2 (EMC 271) and the St Petersburg RNL Yevr. II A 293/1 Mss, as well as the printed editions. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. This is perhaps the Greek form of this name, translated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2./מנסיא
So in the New York JTS Rab. 218 (EMC 270) and the Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 Mss, see previous note. For this form see vol. 1, Menasiah S-H/M, p. 391./מסיא
So in the Vatican 134 Ms, see above, n. 2. Ds: The Great
In Aramaic – רבה. On such designations and this tradition see Introduction 3.1.3.1.1. F: – S: bYom 4b
Although mentioned only here in BT, he is designated רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2) and he transmits in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1015) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: מוסיא
See above, n. 2./מנסיא
So in the New York JTS Rab. 218 (EMC 270) Ms, see above, n. 3./מיסיא
So in the Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 Ms, see above, n. 3./מסיא
So in the Vatican 134 Ms and the Venice print, see above, n. 4. Ds: Moses (1)’s grandson
On this tradition see above, n. 5. F: – S: bYom 4b
See above, n. 6. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1015) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 7.

3. O: 
One of the forms of this name in LXX is . This is a variation on it. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the double consonant see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.4, p. 22. On the alternative Greek suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1, p. 11. Ds: Aziz (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Hauran
In Transjordan. S: Ewing, PEFQS 27 (1895) 347 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

4. O: – Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 19 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is impossible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
See previous note.

5. O: – Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
See above, n. 19. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 20 E: Late?
See above, n.20. D: –
See above, n. 20.

6. O: 
The inscription is bilingual. So in Greek. For the form  see vol. 3, Moses (5) B/M, p. 136. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21. /מוסיס
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Hebrew. This is the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2. Ds: Marsah (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Cotton & Price, ZPE 134 (2001) 278-9 E: – D: 360
The inscription is dated to 290 years after the destruction of the Temple, and according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.1-2.

7. O: מוסי
This is the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2. Ds: Moses (8)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Sukenik, “Jewish Inscriptions,” 139 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

8. O: מוסי
See above, n. 27. Ds: Moses (7), David (3), Amram (6) and Qayuma (2)’s father F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Sukenik, “Jewish Inscriptions,” 139 E: Late?
See above, n. 28. D: Pre-650?
See above, n. 28.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.

div.p:
1. O: 
There are many forms for this name in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 114. The nearest to this one is . This is probably another variation on it. Ds: Epiphanius (2)’s son, aged 25
In Greek –. On these see details vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 251 E: Jew?
The inscription mentions  (one God who rules all) but this is no indication of Jewishness, especially not in Zoar, see Introduction 6.1.6. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 498
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:17.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 2:4, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 541-2) E: – D: 4th C
Was associated with the general Ursicinus, who was active in Palestine in the year 351-2 (yBes 1:7, 60c), see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: מתנה
For this form see vol. 1, under Mataniah (1) B/M, p. 191. Ds: Isaac (25)’s father F: – S: yAZ 3:13, 43b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented In post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

div.p:
1. O: מתיה
For this form see vol. 1, under Mattathias (24) B/M, p. 192. Ds: Of Betarta
In Aramaic – מן דבתרתא, perhaps ברתותא, see Reeg Ortsnamen, 153-4. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yOrl 1:1, 60d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 541) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O:מתיא
For this form see vol. 1, under Mattathias (19) B/M, pp. 191-2. Ds: Joseph (62)’s father F: – S: Yalqut Phineas 776 (Hyman, Toldoth, 240) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: מתיה
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Yesud Hamaala,
Kibbutz in the Upper Jordan Valley. Goldhar S: CIJ 971 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

4. O: 
This is obviously the name intended, even though it is not recorded as such elsewhere, Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1061 S: BS 2:48 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

5. O: 
This is obviously the name intended, even though it is not recorded as such elsewhere, Ds: Hannah (9)’s father, of Beit She‘arim
In Greek – . On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Ben Shemen
West of Tel Aviv. S: Avi-Yonah, BIES 9 (1942) 31 E: –
Jewishness suggested based on both names. Usually this would not be enough, but  in this form, rather than Mathias, would be typical Jewish and the provenance of these people (Beit She‘arim) also suggests Jewishness, see Introduction 5.2.2.2. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

6. O: מתי
For this form see vol. 1, under Mattathias (32) B/M, p. 192. Ds: Saba (3)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Stern, Tarbiz 68 (1999) no. 14 E: – D: 468
The inscription is dated to 398 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

7. O: מתי
See above, n. 17. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. נדב was the name of a King of Israel, see 1 Kgs 14:20.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Samuel (28)’s father F: – S: bArakh 16b
Although he appears only here in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and his son is described as a relative of a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1635) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book. According to Noth, IPRGN, 38,

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 4:3, 8a
I identify him with רבי נחום, mentioned in bHul 98a. Also mentioned in bHul 98a, bBer 55b and in bBQ 82a. On this chain of tradition see Introduction 5.1.3.1.1. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 546) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rav (Abba [70] S/H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311), who died in this year, see Introduction 7.4.5.

2. O: מנחם
So in BT, e.g. bPes 104a. In PT always נחום. Ds: Simon’s
In vol. 1, under Simon (70) B/M, p. 220. son F: – S: yBer 5:2, 9b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 546) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: ניחומי
On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. On the י suffix see see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.1, pp. 23-4. Ds: Ḥiyya (4)’s son F: – S: yDem 1:2, 21d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
For his father’s dating see Introduction 7.4.2.

4. O: – Ds: Aiala (1)’s brother F: – S: yBes 5:2, 63b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 91) E: – D: 3rd C
His brother transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: – Ds: Of the Holy of Holies
In Hebrew – איש קודש הקודשים. This is an unusual title, since it refers to the holiest part in the Temple, and this person lived long after the latter’s destruction. F: – S: yMeg 3:2, 74a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 546) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

6. O: תנחום
So in the Escorial G-I-3 Ms. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. On this name see under Tanḥum S-H/M. Ds: Samuel (26)’s father, Ahi (5)’s relative F: – S: bBQ 55a
Although he appears only here, in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and is related to a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1635) E: – D: 4th C
His relative (Ahi [5]) was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

7. O: תנחום
So in the Vatican 111 Ms. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18. On this form see above, n. 12. Ds: Abbahu (1)’s attendant
In Aramaic – שמעיה. On these titles see Introduction 3.1.3.5. F: – S: bYeb 42b
Although he is mentioned only here in BT, he is described as an attendant of a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, –) E: – D: 3rd C
His master was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Nahum (1) B/M, p. 140. Ds: Simon (48)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 943 E: – D: 3rd C

9. O: – Ds: Joseph (78)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Gush-Halav,
In Upper Galilee. Renan S: CIJ 976 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

10. O: [נ]חום
My reading. The editor suggested [תנ]חום but this is unnecessary. Ds: Judah (70)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Sepphoris, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 989 E: – D: –
See above, n. 21.

11. O: 
The inscription is bilingual. So in the Greek. The Hebrew has נחום. For this form see above, n. 19. Ds: Hesychius (5)’s son F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh & Ustinova, Atiqot 49 (2005)113*, 117* E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

12. O: – Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 18 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is impossible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
See previous note.

13. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 19. For the Greek suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Wine press inscription, Har Bezeq
In Samaria. S: Tzori, EI 10 (1971) 240 E: Samaritan?
The location of the find suggests this, but see Introduction 6.1.5. D: –
See above, n. 21.

14. O: 
See above, n. 28. Ds: Plotinus (1)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Mount Gerizim S: Gerizim II, p. 247 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan synagogue, see Introduction 6.1.4. D: 4th-5th C

15. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Dalton
See above, n. 20. S: Navah, OSM, no. 107*
A photograph of the inscription is presented in OSM but Naveh could not read it. This reading is according to Ada Yardeni, who was kind enough to share it with me. E: – D: –
See above, n. 21.

16. O: נחמו
This form is either a scribal error, characterized by a letter reversal, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20; or a different dialect, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. On the ו suffix as typical Nabatean see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1, p. 28. Ds: Isaac (67)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Katzrin
In the Golan. S: Yardeni, personal communication E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. נחמיה was the Jewish leader who gave his name to a historical biblical book.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Aqub (6)’s son F: – S: yPea 1:5, 16c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: – Ds: Joshua (9)’s father F: – S: ySheq 2:3, 46d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 342) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Judah (15), whose father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: His son
In the text – דבר נחמיה. F: – S: yMQ 3:5, 83a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Simon (34) who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: In-law of the patriarchal house
In Aramaic – חתניה דבי נשיאה. On this family see Introduction 3.1.3.5.1. F: – S: bYom 78a
Although mentioned only here in BT, he is a relative of the Palestinian patriarchal house, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1074) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (27)’s father F: – S: Lev Rab 18:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 447) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 3.

6. O: – Ds: Migas (1)’s son F: – S: SOZ 10:8 E: – D: Post-522
This is the year in which Mar Zutra (Zutra [11] S-H/M, vol. 4, p. 354) ascended to the Land of Israel according to SOZ 10:1, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.5, p. 41. All his descendants in Palestine date to after this time.

7. O: 
See above, n. 11. Ds: Archisynagogus
In Greek – <> (of the most pious of archisynagogoi). On this title see vol. 3 Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1, p. 40. F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea, Mayence S: CIJ 803 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: 391
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

8. O: 
So is this name recorded in 2 Macc 1:36, see H & R Suppl. 120. Ds: Cantor
In Greek – . On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.2. F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea, Mayence S: CIJ 805 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: 391
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

9. O: ניחמיה
So in BS 1:91 in Hebrew. On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. /
So in BS 2:65 in Greek. Although this form is otherwise unattested, the Hebrew identifies it as this name. /
So in BS 2:66 (and also reconstructed – [] – in 2:68) in Greek. Although this form is otherwise unattested, the Hebrew identifies it as this name. Ds: Sarah (8)’s father F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1007, 1081, 1085 S: 1. BS 1:91, 2. 2:65, 3. 2:66, 4. 2:68 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

10. O: – Ds: Gamaliel (9)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 20 S: BS 3:15 E: – D: Pre-352
See previous note.

11. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For a form very similar to this one see above, n. 15. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 193 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

12. O: – Ds: Elisheba (1)’s son F: Amulet, Nazareth?
The owner of the amulet reports that he found it in a field near Nazerath. S: Hamilton, JSS 41 (1996) 221 E: – D: 6th C

note.p: Biblical, Neh 7:7.

div.p:
1. O: נחמן
So in most sources, but occasionally also נחמני, e.g. yBer 1:1, 2d. For this form see vol. 4, under Nahmani (1) B/M, p. 112 Ds: Samuel (3)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548-50) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
In yTer 8:4, 46bc his son is associated with the Emperor Diocletian, who ruled between 285-305, see Introduction 7.4.2.

2. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Isaac (3)’s father?
In yShab 19:2, 17a he is designated נחמן בר יצחק. F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 446) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Ada (4)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:4, 4d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 59) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yonah (2) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: The elder
In Aramaic – סבא. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33. F: – S: yBer 2:4, 4d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

5. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Samuel (3)’s father F: – S: yShab 1:4, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 550) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
On his son’s chronology see Introoduction 7.4.2.

6. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Judah (34)’s father F: – S: ySuk 5:1, 55a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a translator in Resh Laqish (Simon [2])’s academy, who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Joshua (10)’s father F: – S: yTaan 1:6, 64c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 342) E: Fictitious?
The text is as follows: רבי יצחק בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי צומא רבא. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה: איסתניס אני. רבי יהושע בר נחמן סלק גבי רבי יהושע בן לוי בלילי תעניתה. נפק לגביה לביש סולייסיה. אמר ליה: מהו הכין? אמר ליה איסתניס אני (Rabbi Isaac bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of the Great Fast [i.e. Yom Kippur] He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive. Rabbi Joshua bar Nahman went to visit Rabbi Joshua ben Levi on the night of fasting. He came to him dressed in a suleysa [whatever that is]. [Joshua] asked him: What is this? He answered: I am sensitive). Perhaps the second is simply a literary parallel and not a historical figure. D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Kahana (9)’s son F: – S: bKet 105b
Although he is mentioned only in BT and always bears the Babylonian title רב (see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36), he is always mentioned in a Palestinian context and always in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. In bKet 105b a tradition by him is transmitted in Babylonia by a נחותי (i.e. a sage who transmits Palestinian traditions in Babylonia, and see Hyman, Toldoth, 945) , and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.4. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1115) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Joseph (28), who was Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Hanan (10)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 40:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 941) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

10. O: נחמן
See above, n. 2. Ds: Of Jaffa
In Aramaic – דמן יפו, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 308-9. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Gen Rab 53:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 945) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 23.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. נחשון was the nasi of the tribe of Judah.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: Yalqut Psalms 752 (Hyman, Toldoth, 945) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:8. נפתלי was one of Jacob’s twelve sons and a tribe of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yTaan 4:1, 67b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 554) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Mana (2), who was Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. נריה was the name of Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe’s father.

div.p:
1. O: 
This may be the name intended, even though it is not recorded as such elsewhere, because the other two names in this inscription are biblical, and because this form, as non-biblical, is not recorded elsewhere either. Ds: Joseph (114)’s father F: Wine press inscription, Har Bezeq
In Samaria. S: Tzori, EI 10 (1971) 240 E: Samaritan?
The location of the find suggests this, but see Introduction 6.1.5. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Samuel (5)’s father F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 556) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His son was a contemporary of Hama (1), who was a student of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

2. O: – Ds: Of Darom
In Aramaic – דרומה. Perhaps not from the Rome but from Darom, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 212-3. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yEruv 6:4, 23c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 556) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Jonathan (1), who was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: – Ds: Tobiah (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 4:1, 7b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 287) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Hoshaiah (4)’s son F: – S: yTer 7:1, 44c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 70) E: – D: 3rd C
See previous note.

5. O: – Ds: Abba (32)’s son F: – S: yMQ 3:1, 82a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Eleazar (8), see Introduction 7.4.3.

6. O: – Ds: Ami (1)’s father F: – S: bGit 44a (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 260) E: – D: 3rd C
For the chronology of his father see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Barachiah (1)’s son F: – S: Lev Rab 22:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 955) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His father transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

8. O: – Ds: The associate
In Hebrew – החבר. On such designations see vol. 4, Introduction 3.2, p. 20. F: – S: TanB, toldot 22 (Hyman, Toldoth, 957) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Mevaser (1)’s son, Eli (1)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Allepo/Syria S: Sobernheim, “Aleppo,” 277 E: Late
There is disagreement about the dating of this inscription. Because in many respects it resembles inscriptions from the Muslim period, some argue that it should be dated to 833. On this argument see Roth-Gerson, JSRGI, 259-60. D: 342?
This is one way of calculating the date of this inscription, according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1, but see also previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Num 1:8.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Priest (XXIII)
On this list see Introduction 3.3.2.1. F: – S: Tulida, 121 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd C
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

2. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest
In Hebrew – כהן. F: – S: Tulida, 127 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.3.2.

3. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXV)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 140 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 4th C
See above, n. 5.

4. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXXII)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 147 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 484
Contemporary of the Samaritan revolt against Zeno. This is its date, see Introduction 7.1.

5. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Marfalinah (1)’s son F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 176 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 5th C
See above, n. 5.

6. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: Eleazar (5)’s son F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 177 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 5th C
See above, n. 5.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 6:29.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Priest, of the clan of Ithamar
On these see Introduction 3.3.2.2. F: S: Tulida 124 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: עו[בדיה]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this biblical variation of the name see Obad 1:1. Ds: Simon (62)’s father F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Schwabe, Yohanan Levi, no. 3 E: – D: 4th C

note.p: Biblical e.g. Ruth 4:17.

div.p:
1. O: עובר
So in most mss. But in the Florence II-I-9 and Jerusalem Yad Harav Hezog 1 Mss – עובד. On the interchange of ר and ד as a scribal error, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.4, p. 30. Ds: Galilean
In Aramaic – גלילאה. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bSan 70a
Although mentioned only in BT, Palestinian provenance is indicated by his designation, see previous note, and Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1782) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned without a chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: 
In LXX this name is transliterated as  (see H & R Suppl. 161), but this could also be a transliteration of the name. For the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. On the double consonant see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.4, p. 22. On the Greek suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 22-3. Ds: Orion (3)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1b, no. 22 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 423
The inscription is dated, according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

note.p: In the Bible the name is documented as עזיאל, e.g. Exod 6:22.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Ḥoni (1)’s son F: – S: yMSh 5:1, 55d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 238) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his father’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: The Great
In Aramaic – רבא. On this designation and this tradition see Introduction 3.1.3.1.1. F: – S: bMQ 5a
Although he is mentioned only here in BT, he is always designated רבי, see Introduction, 5.1.3.2.2, and transmits a tradition in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1137) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Uziel (2)’s grandson
For this tradition see above, n. 3. F: – S: bMQ 5a
See above, n. 4. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1137) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 5.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:4.

div.p:
1. O: [ע]וזי
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On the additional ו as a vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.1, p. 13. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Katzrin,
In the Golan Urman S: Naveh, OSM, no. 110 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

2. O: – Ds: Blacksmith?
In Aramaic – (ב)נפחא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C
3. O: עזי/ Ds: Joseph (*)’s father F: Lintel inscription, Par‘am (Eastern Galilee) S: Shivtiel & Stepansky, Jerusalem & Eretz Israel 8-9 (2013) 242-3 E: – D: 2nd-7th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 3:19.

div.p:
1. O: –
So in Hebrew. The inscription is bilingual, but the Greek is not given in the Hebrew publication, see Introduction 2.4. Ds: Joseph (111)’s father F: Epitaph, Bar‘am
Village located north west of Safed. S: Kedar, AN 11 (1964) 9 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:1. עזרא is the scribe who gave his name to a biblical book.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Eutolmus (1)’s grandson F: – S: bMen 53a
Although he appears only in BT, he bears the title רבי, see Introduction see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and is described as descending from a Palestinian rabbi, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1152) E: – D: 5th C
The calculation is completely fictional. His grandfather is described as a tenth generation after Eleazar ben Azariah (See vol. 1, Eleazar (43), p. 66 son of Azariah (3), vol. 1, p. 202). If we calculate four generations as a century he is of the 5th century.

2. O: 
Reading this as a name is my suggestion. The editors did not notice this possibility. This may be the name intended, even though it is not recorded as such elsewhere. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 316 E: Name?
See previous note. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:21. עזריה was a king of Judah.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 213) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Mana (2), who was Rabbi Yonah (1)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: – Ds: Of Kfar Hittaya
In Aramaic – דכפר חטייא, see Reeg Ortsnamen, 340-1. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Lev Rab 7:4 (Hyman, Toldoth, 981) E: – D: 4th C
Abba (8), who was a contemporary of Yonah (2), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

3. O: עזריא
On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. Ds: Abbayye (7)’s son F: – S: SOZ 10:10 E: – D: Post-522
This is the year in which Mar Zutra (Zutra [11] S-H/M, vol. 4, p. 354) ascended to the Land of Israel according to SOZ 10:1, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.5, p. 41. All his descendants in Palestine date to after this time.

4. O: עזרון
On the ון suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. Ds: Íalifa (8)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Ein-Gedi,
In the Judaean Desert, west of the Dead Sea. Barag & Porat S: Naveh, OSM, no. 70 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:3. עלי was the priest who brought up Samuel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Nathan (9)’s son, Mevaser (1)’s grandson F: Synagogue inscription, Allepo/Syria S: Sobernheim, “Aleppo,” 277 E: Late
There is disagreement about the dating of this inscription. Because in many respects it resembles inscriptions from the Muslim period, some argue that it should be dated to 833. On this argument see Roth-Gerson, JSRGI, 259-60. D: 342?
This is one way of calculating the date of this inscription, according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1, but see previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Amos 1:1. עמוס is the name of the prophet who gave the book the name.

div.p:
1. O: 
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 16. Ds: Gabriel (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Caesarea, Schwabe S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 293 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

2. O: {}{}
The reading is suggested by the editor, see above, n. 2. Ds: Menahem (14)’s son, comes and elder
In Greek – <> (most illustrious count and elder). On the first title see Introduction 3.1.3.4, On the second see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Haifa, Heuzy S: Schwabe, Tarbiz 15 (1944) 115-6 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
See above, n. 3.

3. O: 
In LXX, the name is recorded as see H & R Suppl. 16. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Tamra
A village in Galilee. S: Gal, IAS (1998), Ein Dor 72 E: Jew?
See above, n. 7. D: –
See above, n. 3.

4. O: 
In LXX, the name is recorded as see H & R Suppl. 16. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. On the double consonant see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.4, p. 22. Ds: Rabbi
In Greek – . Probably Hebrew – חבר, see vol. 4, Introduction 3.2, p. 20. F: Epitaph, Samakiya
A village in Transjordan, near Karak. S: Milik, LA 9 (1958-9) 345, 358 E: Jew?
See above, n. 7. D: –
See above, n. 3.

5. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jatt
By Caesarea. S: Masarwa, ESI 116 (2004) 25* E: Jew?
See above, n. 7. D: –
See above, n. 3.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Sarad (1)’s son, Titus (1), Marcus (1)’s father, priest
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such designations see Introduction 3.3.2. F: – S: Tulida, 129 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: –
See above, n. 2. Ds: The blind,
In Arabic – ﺿﺮﯿﺮ ﻋﻣﺮﻢ (Amram ̣the blind) and the text maintains that there are those who identify him with the father of Marcus (1). Thus, he is perhaps identical with Amram (1). On such designation see Introduction 3.1.3.7.3. sage
In Aramaic – בדואה דחכמתה (inventor of wisdom). F: – S: 1. Tulida, 129 ; 2. Abu’l Fath, 141 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 3rd-4th C
See above, n. 5.

3. O: – Ds: Judah (108)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 12 E: – D: 416
The inscription is dated to 346 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

4. O: עמרן
On the ן suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. Ds: Judah (111)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh Tarbiz 68 (1999) no. 17 E: – D: 503
The inscription is dated to 433 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

5. O: עוירם
So in CIJ 1401, but this form makes no sense. CIIP reads עמרם Ds: Hadbiah (1)’s father F: Inscription, Al-Aqsa mosque, Jerusalem, Chwolson S: CIIP 1/2, no. 981 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

6. O: עמרן
See above, n. 12. Ds: Moses (8)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Sukenik, “Jewish Inscriptions,” 139 E: Late?
See above, n. 13. D: Pre-650?
See bove, n. 15.

note.p: Biblical, Neh 10:27.

div.p:
1. O: ענני
For this form see vol. 4, under Anan (5) B/M, p. 117. Ds: Sason (2)’s son F: – S: bMQ 24b
Although only mentioned here in BT, he is described as clashing with the Palestinian House of the Patriarch, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1160) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She’an S: Naveh, OSM, p. 76 E: Samaritan
The inscription is in Greek, in the Samaritan script, see Introduction 6.1.3. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45.

div.p:
1. O: עקבון
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On the ון suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. Ds: Priest (XXII)
On this list see Introduction 3.3.2.1. F: – S: Tulida, 120 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd C
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

2. O: עקבון
See above, n. 2. Ds: Bebai (1)’s brother, priest (XXIV)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 139 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

3. O: עקבון
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXVI)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 141 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 4th C
See above, n. 5.

4. O: עקבון
See above, n. 2. Ds: Priest (XXVIII)
See above, n. 3. F: – S: Tulida, 143 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 4th C
See above, n. 5.

5. O: עקבון
See above, n. 2. Ds: The great, priest (XXX)
In Hebrew – הגדול, see Introduction 3.1.3.1. On this list see above, n. 3 F: – S: Tulida, 145 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 4. D: 4th C
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

6. O: עוקבן
On the ון suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.1, p. 27. The displacement of the ו is probably a dialect variant, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. Ds: Nehemiah (1)’s father F: – S: yPea 1:5, 16c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: עוקבא
For this form see vol. 4, under Aqub (1) B/M, p. 118. Ds: Ḥama (3)’s father F: – S: yKil 7:1, 30d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 261) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of Joseph (13), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: עקביה
For this form see vol. 1, under Aqub (3) B/M, p. 203. Ds: – F: – S: ySot 4:3, 19c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 575) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Resh Laqish (Simon [2]), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: עוקבה
The displacement of the ו is probably a dialect variant, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3.On the ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.9, p. 26. Ds: Ami (8)’s father F: – S: yKet 7:7, 31c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Joseph (13), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: עוקבה
See above, n. 28. Ds: Ḥiyya (20)’s father F: – S: yGit 3:7, 45a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 254) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Joseph (13), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: עוקבה
See above, n. 28. Ds: Samuel (24)’s father F: – S: bBer 10a
Although mentioned only here in BT (and in some mss his son is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2), he is described in the presence of a Palestinian rabbi, dealing with אגדתא (aggadah), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1551) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary Simon (34), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: עקיבה
For this form see vol. 1, under Aqub (3) B/M, p. 203. Ds: Of Antioch,
In Hebrew – האנטוכי (in Syria). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. Muhammad’s colleague
In Judeo-Arabic – אלטאיר פי אלגנה. F: – S: Leveen, JQR 16 (1925-6) 402 E: Muslim convert
On this text, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.1.3.1, p. 31. This man’s daughter (Muhammad’s wife) is known from Muslim sources. D: Pre-632
Was a contemporary of MuÎammad, who died in this year, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.3.2, p. 42.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:36.

div.p:
1. O: פדייה
So in PT. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12./פדא
So in BT. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13. Ds: His son
In the text – בר פדייה. F: – S: yNaz 6:9, 55c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 585) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: Judah (54)’s father
According to Hyman, identical with the previous. F: – S: Gen Rab 21:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 567-9) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was associated with the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:23.

div.p:
1. O: פלטא
So in the Leiden Ms of PT. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. On this sort of variation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.5, pp. 25-6./פלטה
So in Vatican Ms. of PT, see previous note. On this sort of variation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.5, pp. 25-6./פרטא
So in Gen Rab 50:19, in bHul 98a and in Ms. Moscow and London of PT, see above, n. 2. Perhaps this is the original version, in which case this is probably a nickname rather than a name, see Introduction vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46. For this name see vol. 1, under Parteh P/M, p. 353. Ds: Levi (13)’s father F: – S: yTer 10:10, 47b
On this chain of tradition see Introduction 5.1.3.1.1. (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 486) E: – D: 3rd C
Judah (15), whose father was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: פלטיא
For this form see vol. 1, under Pelatyah (1) B/M, p. 205. Ds: Of Naveh
In Aramaic – דנוה, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 433-5. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Eccl Rab 1:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1011) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: פילטא
On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. On this sort of variation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.6, p. 26. Ds: Levi (36) and Dositheus (14)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, 1 Chr 3:24.

div.p:
1. O: פילה
On this sort of variation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.6, pp. 26. Ds: Judah (18)’s father F: – S: yBer 9:5, 14b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 322) E: – D: 4th C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

2. O: פילא
For this form see vol. 1, under Playah (1) B/M, p. 205. Ds: – F: – S: Exod Rab 24 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1010) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Simon (2), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.

div.p:
1. O: Phineas
The original is in Armenian, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.5, p. 19. So in the translation of Conybeare. Ds: Of Tiberias, philosopher
The persons described in this text (in Armenian) are said to be philosophers, and this person is said to originate in Tiberias. F: – S: Conybeare, BZ 6 (1897) 579 E: –
Described in the text (in Armenian) as a Jew. D: Post-565
The Pesah calculations in which he was involved are post-Justinian. This is the date of his death.

2. O: פינחס
In Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. For this form see vol. 1, under Phineas (13) B/M, p. 206. Ds: Bebai (1)’s brother F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 135 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]), see Introduction 7.2.3. He was his contemporary.

3. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: The Great
In Arabic – الجبار. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.1. F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 176 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 7. D: 4th C
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

4. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 587-8) E: – D: 4th C
Was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

5. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Hananiah (24)’s son F: – S: yShab 4:1, 6d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Hagai (2), who was a student of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

6. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Of Jaffa
In Aramaic – דיפו, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 308-9. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yPes 1:1, 27c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 442) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Íama (6)’s son F: – S: yYom 3:7, 40d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 262) E: – D: 4th C
Was a companion of Judah (16), who was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

8. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Zachariah (1)’s son F: – S: yMQ 2:1, 81a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 212) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Abbin (18)’s son F: – S: ySot 9:2, 23c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 50) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 19.

10. O: – Ds: Isaac (30)’s father F: – S: bPes 114a
Appears only in BT, here and in bHul 27b (and also in bQid 71a, but not in the Vilna print, where his name has been skipped), but I assume he is Palestinian because his son is always designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, because in bPes 114a he is designated דאגדתא (he who transmits aggadah, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6) and in bQid 71 he is described within the context of the Palestinian study house. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 919) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

11. O: – Ds: Jeremiah (13)’s son F: – S: Lev Rab 10:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, –) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 19.

12. O: – Ds: The associate
In Hebrew – החבר. On this title see vol. 4, Introduction 3.2, p. 20. F: – S: Exod Rab 1:14 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1018) E: – D: 4th C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yonah (2), see Introduction 7.4.3.

13. O: – Ds: Poet
In this composition Se‘adya Gaon explains the work of poets (אלשערא in Judeo-Arabic), and lists this one among them. And see Introduction 3.1.3.6. F: – S: Sa’adia Gaon, Ha’egron 1 (3b) E: – D: 4th-7th C
Zulay, Eretz Israel, 165 dates him to the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.5.5.

14. O: – Ds: Abbayye (7)’s son F: – S: SOZ 10:10 E: – D: Post-522
This is the year in which Mar Zutra (Zutra [11] S-H/M, vol. 4, p. 354) ascended to the Land of Israel according to SOZ 10:1, see vol. 4, Introduction 8.2.5, p. 41. All his descendants in Palestine date to after this time.

15. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Phineas (2) B/M, p. 206. Ds: Archisynagogus
In Greek – <> (of the most pious of archisynagogoi). On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1, p. 40. F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea/Syria, Mayence S: CIJ 803 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: 391
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

16. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Baruch (2)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Jerash
Located in Transjordan., Crowfoot S: CIJ 866 E: – D: 5th C

17. O: פינחס
See above, n. 6. Ds: Justus (16)’s son, priest,
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.5, pp. 33-4. Rebekah (3)’s husband F: Synagogue inscriptions, Na‘aran,
North of Jericho. Vincent & Carrière S: CIJ 1197, 1198 E: – D: –
The inscriptions are not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

18. O: – Ds: The Elder
In Hebrew – [הז]קן. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33. F: Inscription, Shevet-Tzedeq, Jerusalem, Ben-Zvi S: CIJ 1409 E: – D: –
See above, n. 42.

19. O: פינחיס
See above, n. 6. On the additional י s as dialect variants see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. Ds: Hananiah (58)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Migav & Stern, Tarbiz 74 (2005) no. 28 E: – D: 444
The inscription is dated to 374 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

20. O: 
Although no parallel exists, this is a reasonable Greek transliteration of the Hebrew. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 34 E: Jew?
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7. D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, Num 34:25. This is most likely a Persian name ( – Pharnak, see, Justi, INB, 92-3).

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yPes 5:7, 32c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 591) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:23.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Annianus (12)’s father, rabbi
In Aramaic – רב. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh, Atiqot 49 (2005) 114* E: – D: 3rd-4th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:24. צדוק was King David’s priest.

div.p:
1. O: ܙܕܘܩ
In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read צדוק. Ds: Of Tiberias
In Syriac – ܡܢ ܛܝܒܝܪܝܐ. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Brock, AB 91 (1973) 302 E: – D: 580
Mentioned in association with the birth of Maximus Confessor. This is the date of this event, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: ﻕﺪﺼﺗ
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read תצדק. It is not clear where the initial letter came from or where the vowel has disappeared, but this is clearly the name intended. Ds: F: Sectarian
This text describes a number of Samaritan sects, see Introduction 3.3.3. S: Abu’l Fath, 175 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 4th-7th C
In his Samaritan heresiology Abu’l Fath is very vague about chronology. I assume all the sects he speaks about date to the meaningful Samaritan revival in the Byzantine period, see Introduction 7.2.2

3. O: ﻕﻭﺪﺻ
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read צדוק. Ds: Sectarian
See above, n. 6. F: – S: Abu’l Fath, 175 E: Samaritan
See above, n. 7. D: 4th-7th C
See above, n. 8.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:32. ראובן was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: روبيل
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read רוביל. On this form of the name see vol. 1, under Reuben B/M, n. 2, p. 210. This could be an example of a Greek transliteration, transliterated back into Semitic characters, see Introduction 2.2. Ds: Benjamin (2)’s son F: – S: Esbroeck, AB 104 (1986) 156 E: Fictitious
This is a pseudepigraphic letter. All mentioned in it are fictitious. D: 452
This fictitious letter (see previous note) is dated.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yKet 11:7, 34c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 612) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Mana (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Reuben (4) B/M, p. 147. Ds: Tanḥum (31)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 912 E: – D: 3rd C

4. O: [ר]אובן
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: The levite
In Hebrew – הליוי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 42. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Weiss, Sepphoris Synagogue, no. 6 E: – D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

5. O: 
On the form  see vol. 1, under Reuben (1) B/M, n. 2, p. 209. The suffix is standard Greek. Ds: – F: Bowl, synagogue, Gaza S: Ovadiah, IEJ 19 (1969) 196 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

6. O: – Ds: Israel (2)’s father F: Graffito, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 10 E: Late?
There is no way to date the Hebrew inscriptions from Elijah’s Cave, see Appendix 3.1. D: Pre-8th C?
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:2. שאול was the first king of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Joseph (14)’s father F: – S: yBer 7:2, 11b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 432) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: – Ds: – F: – S: yMaas 3:2, 50d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 641) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Baruch (1)’s son, witness
Described in the text as putting his signature to a bill of divorce. F: – S: yGit 9:7, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 156) E: Fictitious?
These names are given as examples for signatures on a document, and probably do not represent real people. D: 3rd C
Mentioned as giving his signature to a document mentioned by Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Yeymar (1), physician
Cited as an aurthority on a medical substance in the Book of Assaph the Physician, see Introduction 5.1.4.2. F: – S: Muntner, Assaph, 169 E: – D: Pre-6th C
So according to Muntner, Assaph, 33-7.

5. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Saul (1) B/M, p. 211. Ds: Elder
In Greek – <> (of the most pious of elders). On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3, p. 41. F: Synagogue mosaic, Apamea/Syria, Mayence S: CIJ 803 E: –
This is a synagogue inscription, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1, p. 36. D: 391
The mosaic is dated to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

6. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Saul (5) B/M, p. 148. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 953 E: – D: 3rd C

7. O: – Ds: Sheila (8)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar, Cowley S: CIJ 1208 (no. 1) E: – D: 434
The inscription is dated to 364 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

8. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 13. The fall of the  is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20.Ds: Gaianus (1) Domnus (2)’s son, aged 15
In Greek – (). On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Kafr Nafakh
In the Golan. S: Gregg & Urman, no. 108 E: Jew?
