Since the name is not quite clear, and since the area was populated by Jews, pagans and Christians, there is no way to specifically identify this epitaph as Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.3. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

9. O: [ש]אול
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Jacob (72)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 9 E: – D: 398
The inscription is dated to 328 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

10. O: 
See above, n. 9. Ds: – F: Amulet, Caesarea S: Lifshitz, RB 71 (1964) 387 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name, but he may also be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 19.

11. O: – Ds: – F: Ossuary, Horvat Kishor
South-west of Hebron. S: Zissu, Atiqot 46 (2004) 34 E: – D: 3rd-4th C

12. O: שא[ול]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Qonai (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:3. שבא was one of Abraham’s descendants from Qetura.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Abbin (23)’s father F: – S: bHul 86a
This is the only tradition in which he is mentioned, and although it is Babylonian the rabbi expounds a verse connected with the Diaspora, he has a Palestinian title (רבי), and the tradition is in Hebrew, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 69) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 20:1.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Priest, of the clan of Ithamar
On these see Introduction 3.3.2.2. F: S: Tulida 124 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 7.5.5. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introduction 7.2.3.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15.

div.p:
1. O: שובתי
So e.g. in ySot 3:4, 19a. On the additional ו as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 8:2, 12a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 642-3) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Joseph (28), who was Rabbi Ami (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: שובתי
See above, n. 2. Ds: Of Zaduka
In Aramaic – דצדוקי, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 526. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: yShevi 2:5, 34a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 593) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 3.

3. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (17)’s father F: – S: yYev 2:12, 4b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 255) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

4. O: – Ds: Joseph (42)’s father F: – S: yGit 9:7, 50c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 432) E: – D: Pre-400
See previous note.

5. O: שבתאי
On the additional א as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3, p. 13. Ds: Grain storer
In Aramaic – אצר פירי. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: bYom 83a
Although he appears only here in BT, he is mentioned within a story that takes place in the Palestinian academy, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1544) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

6. O: שבתאי
See above, n. 9. Ds: Marinus (5)’s son F: – S: bBes 32b
This is his only appearance in rabbinic literature and he is described as having come to Babylonia (אקלע לבבל) indicating that he is originally from Palestine, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1543) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in an amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

7. O: סמבטו
On the form סמבטי see vol. 3, under Shabtai (113) G/M, p. 152. On the interchange of the י and ו suffix as a scribal or reading error, see see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7, pp. 17-8. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Byblos
On the northern Lebanese coast. S: Renan, Mission de Phénicie I, 193E: –
Jewishness indicated by the fact that the inscription is in Jewish characters, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4 D: –
No date given. Based on vicinity to Greek and Latin, late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60..

8. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Shabtai (55) B/M, p. 150. Ds: – F: Sarcophagus, Ischar
In Samaria. S: Magen, Flavia Neapolis, 280 E: Samaritan?
The location of the find and its nature suggests this, see Introduction 6.15.1. D: 2nd-3rd C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:13. שלום was the name of a king of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Priest
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such designations see Introduction 3.3.2. F: – S: Tulida, 131 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: sulwm
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . The unusual vowel is probably an error in transmission of the name. Ds: High priest
In Coptic – paryhereus. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 29b II E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

3. O: – Ds: Judah (16)’s father?
In this period, this name, written thus in Jewish charaters is feminine, see vol. 1, under Salome B/F, n. 1, p. 251. This sage could also be designated after his mother. And see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 261-75. F: – S: yBer 9:2, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 324-5) E: Male?
See previous note. D: 4th C
His son was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

4. O: – Ds: Levi (28)’s son?
This inscription was not seen in modern times. It is reported by a medieval traveler. It may have he read שלום בן לוי, but it may have read בת or ברת. F: Synagogue inscription, Meron
In Upper Galilee. (Samuel Bar Simson 1210) S: CIJ 978 E: Male?
See above, n. 12. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

5. O: – Ds: Ada (21)’s father F: Epitaph, Beit She ‘arim S: CIJ 1131 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

6. O: 
In LXX, the name is recorded as see H & R Suppl. 16. On the single consonant see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.4, p. 22. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. For the Greek suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1, pp. 17-8.Ds: Shamirabo (1)’s son, aged 37
In Greek – []. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1a, no. 15 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 356
The inscription is dated to according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

7. O: – Ds: Son/daughter
The inscription reads – שלום ב[..]. It could be read as either בן or בת. F: Epitaph, Caesraea S: Negev, RB 78 (1971) 248 E: Male?
See previous note. D: –
See above, n. 15.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 12:24. שלמה was the son of David, King of Israel.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: – F: Graffiti, Parod
South-west of Safed. S: Ben-Zvi, BIES 1 (1933) 19 E: Late?
Ben Zvi maintained that it is impossible, according to the shape of the letters, to date the inscriptions but he connected them with reports of medieval pilgrims about their visit to the cave of Rabbi Tanḥum of Parod, and thus concluded that the inscriptions too are medieval. On this sort of problem see Introduction 6.4. D: –
See previous note.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Jer 37:3.

div.p:
1. O: שילמיא
So in yBer 4:1, 7c. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. Ds: Scribe
In Aramaic – ספרא. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: – S: yMeg 3:5, 74b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 647) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Mana (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Hos. 10:4.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Levi (10)’s son F: – S: yKil 1:4, 27a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 647) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. The form of this name in LXX is , see H & R Suppl. 133. On the Greek suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 18-9. Ds: Gadia (2)’s son F: Inscription, Sela
In Transjordan. S: Waddington, IGLS no. 2262 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. Di Segni, SCI 13 (1994) 110 notes that the inscription mentions the formula  with no Christian symbols, which may suggest it was set up by Jews or Samaritans. However both arguments are inconclusive. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

3. O: סלימן
This is the Greek form of this name, translated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2. If this interpretation is correct, this may also be the name שלמה, transliterated into Greek in LXX as  (see H & R Suppl. 146). Ds: Moses (8)’s son F: Inscription, Temple Mount, Jerusalem S: Sukenik, “Jewish Inscriptions,” 139 E: Late?
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1. Second name D: Pre-650?
See previous note.

4. O: 
The form of this name in LXX is , see H & R Suppl. 133. On the Greek suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1, pp. 18-9. On the interchange of  and  as probably a dialect difference see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 12-3. Ds: Claudius (1)’s son, aged 40
In Greek – .On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: IPT 1b, no. 18 E: Jew?
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1. D: 412
The inscription is dated, according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books.

div.p:
1. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (3) B/M, p. 215. Ds: Justus (2)’s and Abraham (2)’s father F: – S: Doctrina Jacobi 3:2 E: – D: 7th C
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971).

2. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (1)’s son, Judah (6)’s grandson F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 255) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

3. O: – Ds: Nahmani (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 548-50) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
In yTer 8:4, 46b-c he is associated with the Emperor Diocletian, see Introduction 7.4.2.

4. O: – Ds: Barachiah (1)’s brother F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 159) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
His brother transmits in the name of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

5. O: – Ds: Nathan (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:5, 3d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 556) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Hama (1), who was a student of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

6. O: – Ds: Hananiah (6)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:4, 4d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 281) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

7. O: – Ds: Abba (7)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:7, 5b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 22-3) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

8. O: – Ds: Ḥalafta (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 3:5, 6d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 260) E: – D: 3rd C
Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

9. O: – Ds: Ami (3)’s son F: – S: yBer 6:1, 10a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 97) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Sheila (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 7:2, 11b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 645) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 8.

11. O: – Ds: Joseph (6)’s son F: – S: yDem 4:1, 24a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 50) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: – Ds: Sostratus (1)’s son F: – S: yKil 3:1, 28c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 63) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s contemporary, see Introduction 7.4.1.

13. O: – Ds: Abbin (7)’s son F: – S: yKil 3:2, 28d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 50) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in PT with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

14. O: שמי
For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (15) B/M, p. 216. Ds: Hoshaiah (3)’s father F: – S: yKil 6:3, 30c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 69) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

15. O: שמי
See above, n. 16. Ds: – F: – S: yTer 1:1, 40b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 652-3) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

16. O: – Ds: Hananiah
He appears to be a tanna here, but in yDem 2:1, 22d it is obvious that he is a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1). (21)’s father F: – S: yShab 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276) E: – D: 3rd C
See previous note, and Introduction 7.4.1.

17. O: – Ds: Judah (30)’s son F: – S: yShab 12:1, 13c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 326-7) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

18. O: – Ds: Abdimi (5)’s son F: – S: yYom 4:1, 41c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 25) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Mana (1), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

19. O: – Ds: Hoshaiah (2)’s brother F: – S: yHag 2:7, 78c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 70) E: – D: 3rd C
His brother was of the earliest amoraim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

20. O: – Ds: Annianus (4)’s son F: – S: yYeb 4:11, 6b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 63) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

21. O: – Ds: Joseph (38)’s son F: – S: yKet 1:10, 25d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 434) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

22. O: – Ds: Jacob (27)’s son F: – S: yNed 3:2, 37d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 442) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

23. O: שמעון
So in the parallel in yBer 3:2, 6b. Where he is designated שמעון דתוספתא, in the Leiden, Paris and London Mss. In the Vatican Ms. שמוא' דתוספתה. It is hard to decide which is the correct reading. Ds: Of Sufafta
In Aramaic – דסופפתא. I do not know where this place is. Reeg, Ortsnamen, does not mention it. If the correct reading is תוספתה (see previous note) than he is not from Palestine at all, but rather from Ctesiphon in Mesopotamia, see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica , 206-7. But סופפתא is the lectio difficilior, and he is mentioned only in PT. F: – S: ySan 2:2, 20a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 663) E: Babylonian?
See previous note and Introduction 6.5. D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

24. O: שימי
For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (16) B/M, p. 216. Ds: Aqub (11)’s son F: – S: bBer 10a
Although mentioned only here in BT (and in some mss his son is designated רב, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2), he is described in the presence of a Palestinian rabbi, dealing with אגדתא (aggadah), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.6. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1551) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary Simon (34), who was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

25. O: – Ds: The elder
In Hebrew – הזקן. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.3, p. 33. F: – S: bBer 62b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 663) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 25.

26. O: – Ds: Nahum (6)’s son, Ahi (5)’s relative F: – S: bBQ 55a
Although he appears only here, in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2 and is related to a prominent Palestinian rabbi, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1635) E: – D: 4th C
His relative (Ahi [5]) was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

27. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (24)’s son F: – S: bBM 72b
Appears in only two traditions. In one he is designated רבי (=Palestinian bBM 72b, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2) and in one רב (=Babylonian bHul 56b, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 36). However, in both cases he is transmitting traditions in the name of Palestinian rabbis, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1631) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

28. O: – Ds: Nadab (1)’s son F: – S: bArakh 16b
See above, n. 37. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1635) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

29. O: – Ds: Phineas (7)’s brother F: – S: Gen Rab 6:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1132) E: – D: 4th C
His brother was a companion of Judah (16), who was a student of Joseph (7), see Introduction 7.4.3.

30. O: – Ds: Tanḥum (21)’s son F: – S: Gen Rab 8:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1147) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Hanan (11), who transmits in the name of Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

31. O: – Ds: F: Hananiah (18)’s son-in-law S: – S: Gen Rab 14:10 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1149) E: – D: 3rd C
His father-in-law was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

32. O: שימי
See above, n. 32. Ds: Hoshaiah (9)’s father, of Caesarea
In Aramaic – דקיסרין, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 563-8. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. Hyman, Toldoth, 118 identifies him with Samuel (14), but if that were so, the designation “of Caesarea” would be superfluous. F: – S: Lev Rab 31:9 (Hyman, Toldoth, 118) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

33. O: – Ds: Kahana (10)’s son F: – S: S of S Rab 7:1 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1140) E: – D: 3rd C
Jeremiah (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

34. O: – Ds: Gedaliah (1)’s son F: – S: TanB, bahar 2 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1136) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 15.

35. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (3) B/M, p. 215. On the interchange of  with  in Greek orthography see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. Ds: Esther (1)’s son F: Inscription, Admedera,
Slightly north-east of Damascus. Vidua S: CIJ 848 E: –
The suggestion that this is a Jewish inscription is based, 1. On the formula  (God is one), but see Introduction 6.1.6; 2. The biblical name Samuel (35) is found in the inscription, but he could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52; 3. However, the name of his brother, Tanḥum, was clearly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.4. D: 5th C

36. O: 
See above, n. 51. The interchange of  with  is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, introduction 2.8.4, p. 20. Ds: Clemes (1)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Tafas,
In Transjordan. Fossey S: CIJ 861 E: – D: 4th C

37. O: – Ds: Joseph (69)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Jerash
See previous note., Crowfoot S: CIJ 866 E: – D: 5th C

38. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Samuel (39)’s son F: Epitaph, Beirut, Renan S: CIJ 873 E: –
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35. D: 6th C

39. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Samuel (38)’s father F: Epitaph, Beirut, Renan S: CIJ 873 E: –
See above, n. 58. D: 6th C

40. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 903 E: – D: 3rd C

41. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (7) B/M, p. 215. Ds: Gallus (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 951 E: – D: 3rd C

42. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Samuel (40) B/M, p. 163. Ds: Symmachus (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 952 E: – D: 3rd C

43. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 2. The fall of the  is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. Ds: Matrona (2)’s son F: Column inscription, Ashkelon, Sukenik S: CIJ 965 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

44. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Antoninus (1) and Cyrus (6)’s father F: Epitaph, Maioumas (Shuni),
South of the Carmel. Burkitt S: CIJ 970 E: –
The inscription is accompanied by the Hebrew word שלום, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 66.

45. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Na‘aran,
North of Jericho. Vincent & Carrière S: CIJ 1201 E: – D: –
See above, n. 66.

46. O: – Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim S: CIJ 1146 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

47. O: 
There was obviously no fixed form for the abbreviated שמאי as this and other names in this list indicate. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1053 S: BS 2:42 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

48. O: 
So in BS 2:94. For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (5) B/M, p. 215./ [][]
So in BS 2:96. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Jacob (56)’s son F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1117, 1119 S: 1. BS 2:94, 2. 2:96 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

49. O: 
So in BS 2:99. For this form see vol. 1, under Samuel (7) B/M, p. 215.On the interchange of  with  in Greek orthography see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22./[]
So in BS 2:105. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 62. Ds: Isaac (57)’s son, Isaac (58)’s father F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 4, CIJ 1123, 1128 S: BS 2:99; 2:105 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

50. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Joseph (91)’s father, teacher
In Greek – []. On this title see vol. 3, under Eusebis (4) G/M, p. 275. F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 8, CIJ 1142, 1143, 1158 S: 1. BS 2:115, 2. 2:124 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

51. O: 
See above, n. 2. Ds: Jacob (57)’s father F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 8, CIJ 1161 S: BS 2:126 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

52. O: 
See above, n. 74. Ds: Siricius (4) F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 19 S: BS 2:191 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

53. O: 
The form intended is probably . The vowel replacements in this form are obviously scribal errors, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20. Ds: Gravedigger
In Greek – (). On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She‘arim S: BS 2:202 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

54. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Germanus (2)’s son, the poor
In Greek – [][]. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.7.3. F: Synagogue inscription, Beth She‘arim S: BS 2:206 E: – D: Pre-352
See above, n. 73.

55. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 74. Ds: Annianus (10)’s brother F: Synagogue inscription, El-Khirbe
West of Nablus (Sichem). S: Di Segni, Early Christianity, no. 7 E: Samaritan
On Samaritan synagogues, see Introduction 6.1.4. D: 4th-5th C

56. O: [][]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 62. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 171 E: –
See above, n. 58. D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

57. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 2. For the interchange of  with  as part of the iotacism phenomenon, see vol. 3, introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 15. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 194 E: Jew?
Jewishness may be suggested based on names mentioned in the inscription, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2. D: –
See above, n. 66.

58. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 2. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 309 E: Jew?
See above, n. 102. D: –
See above, n. 66.

59. O: []
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form see above, n. 2. Ds: Leontine (1)’s father, of Antioch
In Greek – [] (in Syria). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Schwabe, Yohanan Levi, no. 7 E: Jew?
The inscription was found in Tiberias, a mainly Jewish city. It may be assumed that Antiocheans with biblical names, who migrated from Syria to Tiberias in Palestine were Jews, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1. However, IJO 3, App18 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription. D: 3rd C

60. O: –
It is not clear in which alphabet the name appears. Negev reports about it in this early popular publication but not in his final report (see next note). It may have been in Greek or in Nabatean. I present it here in Hebrew because Negev’s publication is in this language, see Introduction 2.4. Ds: Artist
In this popular book in Hebrew, Negev writes: “Samuel, the artist who produced this fresco, signed his name under one of his paintings” (translation and paraphrase mine). Nowhere (not even in his book Greek Inscriptions from the Negev (Jerusalem 1981), where he published all other inscriptions from Mampsis, and mentioned the exact fresco he claims this Samuel has painted, has he published this inscription. F: Graffiti on a fresco, Mampsis
In the Negev. S: Negev, Masters of the Desert, 189 E: –
According to J. Goodman, “The Frescoes in Building XII,” in A. Negev (ed.), The Architecture of Mampsis, Final Report. Vol I: The Middle and Late Nabatean Period (Qedem 26; Jerusalem 1988) 147, the frescoes are no older than 222 and thus are unlikely to be Christian. The name is, therefore, Jewish and so must the artist have been. D: Pre-222
See previous note.

61. O: 
See above, n. 74. Ds: Joseph (108)’s son F: Inscription, list of citizens, Hauran
See above, n. 55. S: Ewing, PEFQS 27 (1895) 139 E: Jew?
This list includes many citizens, most of whom are clearly not Jewish, but both father and son here seem to have Jewish names, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6, pp. 50-1.D: –
See above, n. 66.

. O: 
See above, n. 74. Ds: Tobiah (8)’s father F: Epitaph, Mourdouk
See above, n. 55. S: Dunand, RB 41 (1932) 562 E: Jew?
See above, n. 102. D: –
See above, n. 66.

63. O: – Ds: Hillel (10)’s son F: Inscription, Wadi Hajjaj
In Sinai. S: Negev, Qadmoniot 4 (1971) 24 E: –
The name is biblical and the inscription is in Hebrew characters, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4. D: –
See above, n. 66.

64. O: 
On the  prefix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, p. 18. And see also above, n. 74. Ds: Simon (70)’s father F: Sarcophgus, Tiberias S: Ovadiah, IEJ 22 (1972) 231 E: Jew?
The editor gave his article the title, “A Jewish Sarcophagus at Tiberias” but he nowhere explains this claim, and the names are not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 3rd C

65. O: 
See above, n. 62. Ds: Mara (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Lifschitz, Euphrosyne 6 (1974) 24 E: Jew?
See above, n. 102. D: –
See above, n. 66.

66. O: – Ds: Jacob (71)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 64 (1995) no. 7 E: – D: 393
The inscription is dated to 323 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

67. O: 
See above, n. 74. Ds: Kholbidia (1)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa S: Price, SCI 22 (2003) 226 E: – D: 3rd C?
The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them, see Introduction 5.2.2.1. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, it is correct for this one as well.

68. O: – Ds: Joseph (125)’s son, scribe
In Aramaic – ספרה. On this title see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris, Druks S: Naveh, Atiqot 49 (2005) 114* E: – D: 3rd-4th C

69. O: – Ds: Maḥirshah (2)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Misgav & Stern, Tarbiz 74 (2005) no. 26 E: – D: 361
The inscription is dated to 291 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

70. O: שמ[ואל]
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Scribe
See above, n. 134. F: Synagogue Inscription, Khirbet Wadi Hamam
West of the Sea of Galilee. S: Leibner, Qadmoniot 43 (2010) 36 E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

71. O: 
See above, n. 79. Ds: – F: Ring, Israel S: Schwabe, Tarbiz 7 (1936) 345 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on name and provenance, but he could be also Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 66.

72. O: 
For this form see vol. 3, under Samuel (29) B/M, p. 162. Ds: – F: Seal, Gaza S: Saller, LA 21 (1971) 173 E: Jew?
See above, n. 140. D: –
See above, n. 66.

73. O: – Ds: Yohanan (30)’s son F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

74. O: []
Reading reconstructed by us, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. This form is not recorded elsewhere. For the form  see vol. 3, under Samuel (4) B/M, p. 162. This is a variation of this name and the form , see vol. 1, under Samuel (5) B/M, p. 215. Ds: – F: Inscription, Elijah’s Cave S: Appendix, no. 5 E: – D: Pre-8th C
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in the Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. Note also, that this is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

div.p:
1. O: شمعون
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read שמעון./sumewn
In Coptic, see vol. Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read . For this form see vol. 1, under Simon (17) B/M, p. 219. Ds: Judah (3)’s father F: – S: 1. PO iv/3, 270; 2. Pseudo-Cyril of Jerusalem, The Cross, 30b II E: – D: 312-37
In the days of Constantine. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.

2. O: – Ds: Laqish (1)’s son F: – S: yBer 1:1, 2d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 487-501) E: – D: 3rd C
Was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

3. O: סימון
For the form סמון see vol. 1, under Simon (237) B/M, p. 226. On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. This is probably the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, although see Introduction 2.2.1. Ds: – F: – S: yBer 1:5, 2c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 561-3) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of the last tannaim, see Introduction 7.4.1.

4. O: – Ds: Ada (13)’s father F: – S: yBer 2:3, 4d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 56) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

5. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Zebadi (4)’s son F: – S: yBer 2:8, 5c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 209) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Samuel (3), see Introduction 7.4.2.

6. O: – Ds: The pious
In Aramaic – חסידא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.7.1. He is probably not to be identified with Simon (3), of vol. 4, p. 131 or with Simon (85) of vol. 1, p. 221. F: – S: yBer 4:6, 8c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 284) E: – D: 4th C
Rabbi Yonah (2) transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.3.

7. O: – Ds: Cloths superintendant
In Greek, in Jewish characters – קמטריא. From the Greek –  (see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1385). This is the word used in the Targum for אֲשֶׁר עַל הַמֶּלְתָּחָה in 2 Kgs 10:22. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: yBer 9:2, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 606) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Hiyya (4), see Introduction 7.4.2.

8. O: – Ds: Hanan (3)’s son F: – S: yPea 1:5, 16c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 264) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Rabbi Yosi (Joseph [7]), see Introduction 7.4.3.

9. O: – Ds: Judge
In Aramaic – דיינא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.5. F: – S: yPea 6:1, 19b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 184) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Ze‘ira (4), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

10. O: – Ds: Yaqim (1)’s son F: – S: yPea 7:1, 20a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 449-50) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

11. O: – Ds: Abba (21)’s son F: – S: yDem 1:1, 21c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 23-4) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporay of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

12. O: – Ds: Zachariah (3)’s son F: – S: yDem 2:1, 22c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 212) E: – D: 4th C
See above, n. 12.

13. O: – Ds: Narashiya (1)’s son
Designated in this text שמעון בר נרשיה. In yKil 3:1, 28d he is designated simply נרשייה (of Naresh). A place called נרש is documented in Babylonia (see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica, 258-66. Perhaps this is what this name means. F: – S: yKil 3:1, 28c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 554) E: Babylonia?
See previous note and Introduction 6.5, D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Simon (2), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

14. O: – Ds: Karsana (1)’s son F: – S: yTer 2:1, 41c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 479-80) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Ahi (1), who was associated with Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

15. O: – Ds: Ḥiyya (11)’s son F: – S: yTer 10:5, 47b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 255) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a student of Rav (Abba [70] in vol. 4, p. 311), see Introduction 7.4.5.

16. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Joseph (17)’s father F: – S: yBer 9:5, 14c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 432) E: – D: Pre-400
Appears in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

17. O: – Ds: Nazira (2)’s son F: – S: yShab 2:3, 5a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 545) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Transmits in the name of Isaac (5), who was a contemporary of Rav Hisda (in vol. 4, Hesediah [1] B/M, p. 79) who died in 309, see Introduction 7.4.5.

18. O: – Ds: Jeremiah (7)’s father F: – S: yShab 4:3, 7a (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 464) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

19. O: – Ds: Jonathan’s
In vol. 1, under Jonathan (21) B/M, p. 145. son F: – S: yShab 13:7, 14b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 439) E: – D: 3rd C
Was the son of a late tanna, see Introduction 7.4.1.

20. O: – Ds: Council member
In Greek, in Hebrew letter – בולווטה (). On such titles see Introduction 3.1.3.4. F: – S: yPes 4:1, 30c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 146) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Hananiah (2), in vol. 4, p. 75, see Introduction 7.4.5.

21. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Justus (4)’s father F: – S: ySheq 2:1, 46c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 395) E: – D: Pre-400
See above, n. 27.

22. O: – Ds: Ahi (13)’s father F: – S: yMeg 1:9, 71c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 76) E: – D: 3rd C
His son transmits a tradition in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

23. O: – Ds: Meyasha (2)’s son F: – S: yMeg 1:12, 72d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 519) E: – D: 4th C
Was a contemporary of Eleazar (8), who was associated with the general Ursicinus, see Introduction 7.4.3.

24. O: – Ds: Scribe of Tarkhenet
In Aramaic – ספרא דטרכנת, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 278-9. On the title “scribe” see Introduction 3.1.2.4. F: – S: yMeg 4:5, 75b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 292) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Hananiah (2), in vol. 4, p. 75, see Introduction 7.4.5.

25. O: – Ds: Joseph (37)’s son F: – S: yMeg 4:5, 75b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 396) E: – D: 3rd C
Was a contemporary of Aila (1), who transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

26. O: – Ds: Judah (40)’s father F: – S: yHag 1:8, 76d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 325) E: – D: 3rd C
His son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

27. O: סימי
For this form see vol. 1, under Simon (168) B/M, p. 224. This is probably the Greek form of this name, translated back into Hebrew, although see Introduction 2.2.1. Ds: Father
In Aramaic – אבא, see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.1, p. 33. F: – S: yYeb 16:5, 15d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 2) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) reacts to his story, see Introduction 7.4.1.

28. O: – Ds: Hillel (3)’s son F: – S: ySan 7:5, 24c (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 204) E: – D: 3rd C
His father was a contemporary of Rabbi Ami (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

29. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Judah (7)’s brother F: – S: yBB 3:1, 13d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 208) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Samuel (3) transmits in his brother’s name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

30. O: – Ds: Yohanan (10)’s son F: – S: yAZ 1:4, 39d (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 386) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Witnessed an inscription of Diocletian in Tyr, see Introduction 7.4.2.

31. O: – Ds: Abshalom (2)’s son F: – S: bBer 7b
Although mentioned only in BT, he is designated רבי in all the traditions in which he appears (bBer 7a; bMeg 14a and bBB 68a), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2 and transmits traditions in Hebrew, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.5. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1686) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

32. O: – Ds: Yohanan (1)’s student F: – S: bBer 21b
Although mentioned only here in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and transmits traditions in the name of the Palestinian Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1685) E: Fictitious?
The text tells of Abdimi (1) (S-H/M in vol. 4, 318) coming to Babylonia and transmitting a tradition in his and Judah (47)’s name. Usually ר' יהודה ור' שמעון are the famous Judah (30) B/M vol.1, p. 113 and Simon (51) B/M vol. 1, p. 220, but they cannot be students of Yohanan (1). Thus I assume these are otherwise unknown students, from Palestine of course, although it cannot be ruled out that they are a literary invention of an early sage. D: 3rd C
See Introduction 7.4.1.

33. O: – Ds: Jacob (30)’s son, of Tyre
In Aramaic – דמן צור, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 531-33. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bBer 33a
Although mentioned only here and in bKet 7a in BT, his provenance is Syria (Tyre), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1711) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 19.

34. O: – Ds: Pazatos (6)’s son F: – S: bBer 45a
Though only mentioned in BT, he is Palestinian because he is always designated רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2), and transmits in the name of Palestinian sages, see Hyman, Toldoth, 1210, and Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1744) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 19.

35. O: – Ds: Of Sidon
In most mss – הצידוני, see Reeg, Ortsnamen, 533-5. In the Munich 95 Ms and the printed edition – השלוני. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: – S: bPes 118a
Although only mentioned here in BT, his provenance indicates his association with Palestine, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1684) E: –
Jewishness based on source in which he is mentioned, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.7, pp. 53-4. D: Pre-400
See above, n. 52.

36. O: ישמעאל
So in the printed versions to bAZ 30a, but in all mss שמעון. On this name see under Ishmael B/M. Ds: Ziroz (2)’s son F: – S: bSan 14b
Although mentioned only in BT, here and in bAZ 30 a, he bears the Palestinian title רבי (see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2) and is found in association with Palestinian rabbis, and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1707) E: – D: 3rd C
See above, n. 19.

37. O: – Ds: Gladiator?
In Aramaic – לודייא. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: – S: Exod Rab 3:5 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1226) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Simon (2), who was Rabbi Yohanan (1)’s companion, see Introduction 7.4.1.

38. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Quzot (1)’s son F: – S: S of S Rab. 8:3 (Hyman, Toldoth, 964) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Levi (6), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), , see Introduction 7.4.1.

39. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Isaac (35)’s father F: – S: Lam Rab 1:30 (Hyman, Toldoth, 797) E: – D: 3rd C
Rabbi Yohanan (1) transmits in his son’s name, see Introduction 7.4.1.

40. O: – Ds: Shiqfa (1)’s son F: – S: Eccl Rab 1:11 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1216) E: – D: 3rd-4th C
Judah (8), who transmits in the name of Samuel (3), also transmits in his name, see Introduction 7.4.2.

41. O: – Ds: Kefa, poet
In Aramaic – תפילות וסילחות שמסרו לנו רבותינו אנשי השם מימות שמעון כיפה שיסד סדר של יום הכיפורים (prayers and forgiveness-beggings that were handed down to us by our renown teachers from the days of Shimeon Kefa, who founded the ritual for the Day of Atonement). Who this Shimeon Kefa was is unclear, as perhaps the other reference to him in Mahzor Vitri demonstrates. In §66 someone who is also reputed to have written liturgical poetry (נשמת כל חי) is designated אותו נבל שמעון פטר חמור (that criminal Shimeon Peter [=also in Hebrew firstborn] of a donkey) and in Krauss, Leben Jesu, pp. 86-8, he is identified as Simon Peter (in vol. 1, Simon [35] B/M. p. 219), although his role as liturgical poet is maintained (עשה הרבה פזמונים גדולים לישראל וכולם קימים בשמו). I agree with H. Graetz, “Die Anfänge der neuhebräischen Poesie,” Monatsschrift für Geschichte und Wissenschaft des Judentums 9 (1860) 21-2 that “Simon Kephas ist aber keine Mythe, sondern der Name eine jüdischen Poetan.” F: – S: Mahzor Vitry §325 E: Late?
Although Graetz (see previous note) identifies him as a contemporary of the earliest paytanim, his name only shows up in medieval compositions. Thus we do not really know when to date him, and if he belongs to antiquity at all. D: –
See previous note.

42. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Simon (90) B/M, p. 221. Ds: Joseph (72)’s father F: Inscription, Tyre,
In southern Lebanon. Michon S: CIJ 880 E: Jew?
Jewishness suggested based on names, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

43. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Simon (36) B/M, p. 219. Ds: Jacob (44)’s son F: Epitaph, Caesarea, Sukenik S: CIJ 890 E: –
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35. D: –
See above, n. 79.

44. O: 
See above, n. 76. Ds: Alzan (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 905 E: – D: 3rd C

45. O: 
See above, n. 76. Ds: Tanḥum (32)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 920 E: – D: 3rd C

46. O: 
This form is not recorded anywhere, but obviously this is the name intended. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Euting S: CIJ 923 E: – D: 3rd C
47. O: – Ds: Eleazar (35) and Shelamzion (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 935 E: – D: 3rd C

48. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 76. The additional  is obviously a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.1, p. 20. Ds: Nahum (8)’s father F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 943 E: – D: 3rd C

49. O: 
For the form  see above, n. 83. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. Ds: Isaac (45)’s son F: Epitaph, Jaffa, Clermont-Ganneau S: CIJ 955 E: – D: 3rd C

50. O: 
See above, n. 83. Ds: Jacob (48)’s son, of Diospolis

See above, n. 79.

In Greek – . The editors suggest this refers to Arabeh (Arav) in Galilee. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1059 S: BS 2:46 E: – D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

See above, n. 95.

See above, n. 95.

See above, n. 95.

For the form סמון see vol. 1, under Simon (237) B/M, p. 226. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13. This is probably the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, although see Introduction 2.2.1. Ds: Abdai (2)’s son F: Epitaph, Tiberias S: Schwabe, Yohanan Levi, no. 3 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

The editors thought the inscription Jewish because of the names, but this is not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 79.

See above, n. 80. Ds: Jacob (61)’s son F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 174 E: –

In Greek – [][].On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 186 E: Jew?
See above, n. 78. D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For the form  see above, n. 87. On the interchange of  and  see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22. Ds: – F: Epitaph, Caesarea S: Lehmann & Holum, CMER 5, no. 287 E: Jew?

See above, n. 78. D: –
See above, n. 79.

69. O: שמע
On this sort of kern form see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29. This name is also recorded in the Bible, see 1 Chr 11:44. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Sepphoris S: Weiss, Sepphoris Synagogue, no. 9 E: – D: 5th-7th C
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.

70. O: 
See above, n. 76. Ds: Samuel (64)’s son F: Sarcophagus, Tiberias S: Ovadiah, IEJ 22 (1972) 231 E: Jew?
The editor gave his article the title, “A Jewish Sarcophagus at Tiberias” but he nowhere explains this claim, and the names are not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: 3rd C

71. O: 
See above, n. 76. Ds: Alexander (13)’s son, Archelais (1)’s father F: Sarcophagus, Ischar
In Samaria. S: Magen, Flavia Neapolis, 283 E: Samaritan
The location of the find and its nature suggest this, see Introduction 6.1.5.1. D: 2nd-3rd C

72. O: – Ds: Abbin (30)’s son, aged 26
In Aramaic – בר שנין כו. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21. F: Sarcophagus, Ein Nashot
See above, n. 118. S: Urman, Tarbiz 53 (1984) 527 E: – D: 5th C

73. O: ש[מע]ון
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: The quite
In Aramaic – שפי. On such designations see 3.1.3.7.2. F: Graffiti in a synagogue, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Naveh, Zion 54 (1989) 11 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

74. O: – Ds: Judah (107)’s father F: Synagogue inscription, Marot
In the Upper Jordan Valley. S: Naveh, EI 20 (1989) 305 E: – D: 4th-5th C

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Khirbet Ḥebra
Near Gaza. S: Naveh, EI 20 (1989) 307 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

See above, n. 118. S: Urman, Tarbiz 65 (1996) 520 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

77. O: – Ds: Jacob (74)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 20 E: – D: 416
The inscription is dated to 346 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

78. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Berabbi
In Aramaic – בירבי. On this title see Introduction 3.1.1. F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 22 E: – D: 455
The inscription is dated to 385 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

79. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Omabi (1)’s father F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Misgav & Stern, Tarbiz 74 (2005) no. 27 E: – D: 4th-6th C
Even when not dated, compared to other inscriptions in this cemetery one can approximately date the others, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.

80. O: שימעונא
On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2, p. 25.On the י as a vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. Ds: – F: Synagogue Inscription, Khirbet Wadi Hamam
West of the Sea of Galilee. S: Leibner, Qadmoniot 43 (2010) 36 E: – D: 2nd-3rd C

81. O: [שמ]עון
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Ds: Shiphra (2)’s son F: Amulet, Munich, private collection S: AMB no. 14 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

82. O: סימון
See above, n. 6. Ds: Cattia (1)’s son F: Amulet, Horvat Kannah
In Galilee. S: MSF no. 19 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

83. O: – Ds: Spinner?
In Aramaic – פלכה. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3. F: Jar S: Naveh, IOS 9 (1979) 28 E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

84. O: 
For this form see vol. 1, under Simon (90) B/M, p. 221. Ds: Aianus (1)’s son, agoranomus
In Greek – . On such titles see Introduction 3.1.3.4. F: Weight, Sepphoris S: Meshorer, BA 49 (1986) 17 E: Jew?
The editor wrote: “Simon – certainly a Jew – from a city with a Jewish population,” but this is not dsecisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.4, pp. 51-2. D: –
See above, n. 79.

85. O: 
See above, n. 96. Ds: Yohanan (32)’s son F: Oil lamp, Jersualem S: Loffreda, LA 44 (1994) 595 E: Jew?
The editor suggested that the persons mentioned on this lamp were Jewish because of their names, and because this type of lamp was idenitifed as being in use by Jews, but at this time, both are not decisive, see Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. D: –
See above, n. 79.

86. O: – Ds: Priest
In Aramaic – כהנה. On such titles see Introduction 3.3.2. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Aviam & Amitai, Cathedra 141 (2011) no. 10 E: – D: 2nd-4th C

87. O: – Ds: Rabbi
In Hebrew – רבי. On this title see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4, p. 41. F: Epitaph, Sepphoris S: Aviam & Amitai, Cathedra 141 (2011) no. 11 E: – D: 2nd-4th C

88. O: – Ds: – F: Inscription, Beth Govrin
West of Hebron. S: Yardeni, personal communication E: – D: –
See above, n. 79.

89. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
South of Beth She’an. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
In this publication there is a partial photograph of this inscription. Ada Yardeni read the entire inscription and kindly allowed me to make use of her readings. Not all the names she read can be seen in the photograph. E: – D: 4th-7th C

90. O: – Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Rehov
See above, n. 180. S: Vito, “Reḥob,” 93
See above, n. 181. E: – D: 4th-7th C

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 12:22.

div.p:
1. O: ישעיה
So in Vatican Ms. Most mss have שמעיה. On this name see Isaiah B/M, above. Ds: Jeremiah (12)’s father F: – S: Gen Rab 93:6 (Hyman, Toldoth, 815) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in in a Palestinian source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

2. O: שימעיי
Reading according to Naveh, OSM, no. 71. In the Bible the form שמעי is mentioned, e.g. Exod 6:17. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. Ds: Auxentius (1)’s son, master
In Greek in Hebrew characters – קוריס. In this title see Introduction 3.1.3.2. F: Synagogue inscription, Beth Govrin
West of Hebron. S: CIJ 1195 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

3. O: – Ds: Isaac (65)’s son F: Epitaph, Zoar S: Naveh, Tarbiz 69 (2000) no. 25 E: – D: 505
The inscription is dated to 435 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. Shafat was the name of the prophet Elisha’s father.

div.p:
1. O: –
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. Ds: Ṣavo (1)’s son, leader
On this list see Introduction 3.3.1. F: – S: Tulida, 135 E: Samaritan
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2. D: 3rd-4th C
Was a contemporary of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). These are his dates, see Introdution 7.2.3.

2. O: שפטיה
So in the Vilna Print. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. This being a biblical name e.g. 2 Sam 3:4, this is obviously a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18./שפטי
So in most versions, see previous note. On this suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1, p. 23./שפטאי
So in the Oxford Opp.Add. fol. 23 Ms, see n. 6. Ds: – F: – S: bMeg 32a
Although he appears only here in BT, he is designated רבי, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.2, and is found in association with Palestinian rabbis, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3. (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1750-1) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

note.p: Biblical, 1 Chr 4:12.

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: The pious
In Aramaic – חסידא. On such designation see Introduction 3.1.3.7.1. F: – S: Eccl Rab 9:7 (Hyman, Toldoth, 1238) E: – D: Pre-400
Mentioned in a Palestinian-amoraic source with no chronological context, see Introduction 7.4.4.

note.p: Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. The name is associated with a son of Ishmael – i.e. it may be of Arab extraction. The name תימא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 117).

div.p:
1. O: – Ds: Pappus (6)’s son F: – S: ySan 4:7, 22b (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 590) E: – D: 3rd C
Transmits in the name of Rabbi Hoshaya (2), who was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

2. O: 
The inscription is bilingual Greek and Latin. So in the Greek. In LXX this name is recorded as in Gen 25:15, see H & R Suppl, 69. This is a close enough rendition. / Thaemi
The inscription is bilingual Greek and Latin. So in the Latin. In the Vulgate the reading is for Gen 25:15 is Thema. This is a close enough rendition. Ds: Julianus (2), Saad (1)’s son, Syrian of Canotha
In Greek – [][]. In Latin – Septimiano Canotha (Septimiana being the Latin name of the town). Canatha is situated in Transjordan. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaph, France, Oehler S: CIJ 61* E: Jew?
Oehler, MGWJ 53 (1909) 449 writes “vielleicht ein Jude” probably based on the fact that he came to Gaul from Syria and had a Semitic name, but both criteria are not decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. CIJ thought he was a pagan. D: Post-211
The name of the town “[S]eptimiano,” is after the emperor Septimius Severus. This is the year in which he died, see Introduction 7.1.

3. O: 
The inscriptions are bilingual, Greek and Palmyran. This is the Greek (BS 2:11, 12). It is very different from the Greek renditions of this name in LXX, but the Palmyran version makes the idenitification with this name certain./תמא
The inscriptions are bilingual Greek and Palmyran. This is the Palmyran (BS 1:12), see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 19. On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13. Ds: Of Emesa
In Greek – . In Hebrew – אמשא. This is in Syria. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. F: Epitaphs, Beth She‘arim, catacomb 1, CIJ 1023, 1024, 1025 S: BS 1:12, 2. 2:11. 3. 2:12 E: –
The inscription was found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.5.7, pp. 49-50. D: Pre-352
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

4. O: תמה
On biblical names losing their vocalization see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13. On the replacement of the א suffix with ה see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. Ds: – F: Synagogue inscription, Ma‘on,
In the north-western Negev. Yeivin S: Naveh, OSM, no. 57 E: – D: –
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
